questions.text: Which of the following is true about renal tubular transport?

choices.text: Maximum reabsorption in the distal tubule
H+ is absorbed in the proximal tubule
Amino acid is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Amino acid is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

Explanation:

  • In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), most of the filtered substances, including amino acids, are reabsorbed. Nearly 100% of the amino acids that are filtered by the glomerulus are actively reabsorbed here using specialized transporters.

Amino acid is reabsorption:

  • Location: Amino acids are primarily reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron.
  • Reabsorption: Nearly 100% of filtered amino acids are reabsorbed by active transport mechanisms in the PCT.
  • Mechanism: Amino acids are transported from the tubular lumen into the renal cells through specific sodium-dependent co-transporters.
  • Significance: This process ensures that essential amino acids are retained in the body and not lost in urine.

 

Maximum reabsorption in the distal tubule (Option A): The proximal tubule is the primary site for reabsorption of most substances (like glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate). The distal tubule is more involved in fine-tuning reabsorption and secretion, particularly for ions like sodium, potassium, and calcium.

Urea is absorbed 100% in PCT (Option B): Urea is not absorbed 100% in the PCT. It is partially reabsorbed in the PCT, but most urea reabsorption occurs in the loop of Henle and distal tubule. Urea has a role in the kidney’s ability to concentrate urine.

H+ is absorbed in the proximal tubule (Option C): Hydrogen ions (H+) are not absorbed in the PCT; instead, they are secreted into the tubule to help regulate acid-base balance.

questions.text: What is the mediator of fast vibration sense?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pacinian corpuscles

Explanation:

  • Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors that detect rapid vibrations and deep pressure. They are located deep in the skin, particularly in the dermis and hypodermis, and are sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them the mediator of fast vibration sense.

Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Structure

Function

Location

Adaptation

Pacinian Corpuscle
 

Encapsulated nerve ending
  • Detect tissue vibration or other rapid changes in the mechanical state of tissues
  • Stimulated by rapid local compression of the tissue

Immediately beneath the skin and deep in the fascial tissues of the body

Adapts in a few hundredths of a second

Meissner Corpuscle
 

Elongated, encapsulated nerve ending of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber
  • Sensitive to movement of objects over the skin and low-frequency vibrations
  • crucial for spatial location discernment of touch sensations

Nonhairy skin, particularly abundant in fingertips and lips.

Adapts in a fraction of a second

Hair End

Nerve fiber entwined at the base of each hair

Detects :

  • Movement of objects on the body surface or
  • Initial contact with the body

Hairy skin

Adapts readily

 

 

 

Specialized mechanoreceptors

(Option C ruled out)

(Option A ruled out)

 

(Option D ruled out)

Superficial

Superficial

Deep

Deep

Discriminatory touch, Stroking

Texture, Edges, Braille

Pressure, Vibration

Sustained pressure

Rapidly adapting

Slowly adapting

Rapidly adapting

Slowly adapting

questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for increasing gastric motility?

choices.text: Presence of fatty food in the stomach
Presence of tryptophan in the stomach
The presence of acid in the stomach

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distension of the stomach

Explanation:

  • Distension of the stomach (i.e., stretching of the stomach wall) is a key factor that stimulates gastric motility. This occurs because the stretch activates mechanoreceptors in the stomach wall, which then trigger the release of signals that promote motility, helping the stomach to mix and propel its contents.

Factors responsible for increasing gastric motility:

Factor

Effect on Gastric Motility

Explanation

Distension of the stomach

Increases gastric motility

Stretching of the stomach wall activates mechanoreceptors, stimulating motility.

Gastrin

Increases gastric motility

Hormone released in response to food, especially proteins, that stimulates gastric motility.

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Increases gastric motility

Released by the parasympathetic nervous system, promoting smooth muscle contraction.

Peptides and amino acids

Increases gastric motility

Presence of partially digested proteins or amino acids triggers gastrin release.

Gastric emptying reflex

Increases gastric motility

Reflex activated when food enters the duodenum, regulating the rate of gastric emptying.

Increased secretion of digestive enzymes

Increases gastric motility

The release of gastric juices and digestive enzymes aids in the mixing and movement of food.

 

Presence of fatty food in the stomach (Option A): Fatty food in the stomach actually slows gastric motility because it triggers the release of cholecystokinin (CCK), which inhibits gastric emptying.

Presence of tryptophan in the stomach (Option C): While tryptophan is an amino acid, it is not a direct factor in increasing gastric motility. Its role is more related to the synthesis of serotonin, which can affect various aspects of gastrointestinal function, but not directly promote motility in the stomach.

The presence of acid in the stomach (Option D): The presence of acid in the stomach does not directly increase gastric motility. It is more involved in digestion and the regulation of gastric secretion.

questions.text: A child accidentally took a bottle full of iron tablets. Which of the drugs is used as an antidote for iron poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Deferoxamine

Explanation:

  • Acute iron poisoning can occur when a person ingests a toxic amount of iron tablets or other iron-containing substances.
  • Deferoxamine is a chelating agent that is used as the antidote for Acute iron poisoning.
  • Mechanism: Binds iron in the body and forms a stable complex that can be excreted through urine and faeces.
  • Deferoxamine helps to remove excess iron from the body and prevent its toxic effects.

Luspatercept (Option A) is a medication used for the treatment of anemia in certain blood disorders and is not indicated for the treatment of iron poisoning.

Deferiprone (Option C) is an oral chelating agent used to treat iron overload in disorders like thalassemia. However, deferoxamine is the preferred antidote for acute iron poisoning.

DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid) (Option D) is another chelating agent used for heavy metal poisoning, but it is not the preferred antidote for iron poisoning. It is more commonly used for lead or mercury poisoning.

questions.text: Adrenaline acting via beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation, whereas histamine acts through H1 receptors to cause bronchoconstriction. Which type of antagonism is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Physiological antagonism

Explanation:

  • Physiological antagonism refers to the interaction between two substances or pathways that have opposing physiological effects.
  • In this case, adrenaline (also known as epinephrine) acting through beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation, while histamine acting through H1 receptors causes bronchoconstriction.

Type of Antagonist

Description

Example

Physiological Antagonist

Involves two agents that produce opposite effects on the same physiological function without interacting directly with each other or the same receptor.

Histamine causes bronchoconstriction, while adrenaline causes bronchodilatation

Chemical Antagonist

(Option B)

Direct interaction between two drugs to form an inactive product.
  • Heparin works by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, which inhibits blood clotting.
  • Protamine sulfate binds to the negatively charged heparin, neutralizing its anticoagulant effect.

Non-Competitive Antagonist

(Option C)
  • Prevents the action of an agonist without competing with it for the binding site.
  • Irreversible binding to the receptor reduces the maximum effect of the agonist.

Phenoxybenzamine binds to α-adrenergic receptors, reducing the effect of adrenaline.

Competitive Antagonist

(Option D)
  • Competes with agonists for the same binding site, reducing the potency of the agonist.
  • Reversible binding to the same receptor site as the agonist.

Propranolol (β-blocker) binds to β-adrenergic receptors, reducing the effect of adrenaline.

questions.text: In the management of diabetes mellitus, lactic acidosis is caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Metformin

Explanation:

Metformin is a first-line oral hypoglycemic agent which can lead to lactic acidosis.

Metformin

MOA
  • Stimulates the AMP-dependent protein kinase (AMPK) in the presence of insulin.
  • It inhibits hepatic gluconeogenesis, fatty acid oxidation, and non-oxidative glucose metabolism and increases insulin sensitivity.
  • Inhibits the mitochondrial glycerol phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Reduces peripheral resistance to insulin in muscle and adipose tissues

Dose

500 mg OD to 2550 mg/day (max)

Uses

First-line oral hypoglycemic for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

DOC: Prophylaxis in prediabetes or impaired glucose tolerance

Metabolic syndrome

DOC: Diabetes due to insulin resistance

  • In PCOS: Metformin also promotes ovulation
  • Clozapine-induced DM/glucose intolerance.
  • Cushing syndrome
  • Gestational diabetes

Other benefits

  • Weight loss in obese patients and weight neutrality in thin patients.
  • There is no risk of hypoglycemia (No effect during the normoglycemic state).
  • Reduction of lipogenesis (decrease triglyceride and LDL levels).
  • Decreases micro- and macrovascular complications of DM
    • Micro: diabetic neuropathy, nephropathy, retinopathy
    • Macro: MI and stroke

Side effects
  • Nausea/Vomiting/Diarrhoea
  • Megaloblastic anaemia: reduces vitamin B12 absorption from GIT
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Avoid metformin in Renal disorder, liver disease, COPD, CHF, dehydration, and sepsis (hypoxia increases lactic acid production).

Incorrect Options:

Tolbutamide (Option A) is a sulfonylurea used to manage type 2 diabetes mellitus by stimulating insulin release from the pancreas. Its major side effect is hypoglycemia, and it is not associated with lactic acidosis.

Glipizide (Option B), a sulfonylurea for type 2 diabetes, primarily causes hypoglycemia and is not linked to lactic acidosis.

Pioglitazone (Option C), a thiazolidinedione for type 2 diabetes, improves insulin sensitivity. Lactic acidosis is a rare side effect, typically associated with significant kidney or liver dysfunction.

questions.text: Beta-blockers are ideally avoided in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Diabetes mellitus with hypertension
Explanation:

Beta-blockers should be ideally avoided in diabetes mellitus with hypertension due to.

  • Potential to mask symptoms of hypoglycemia and patients fail to recognise key symptoms of a hypoglycemic state and neglect getting appropriate treatment.
  • Increased risk of hypoglycemic episodes, as glycogenolysis in the heart, skeletal muscles, and liver that occurs due to sympathetic stimulation is attenuated.

Uses of beta-blockers

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis (Option D)
  • Essential tremors (Option A)
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina: Decrease the frequency of attacks and increase exercise tolerance. (Option C)
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: Used in both supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Congestive heart failure: Decreases mortality.
  • Thyrotoxicosis: Propranolol controls the sympathetic symptoms
  • Glaucoma: Timolol and Betaxolol are used.
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improves cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

questions.text: The therapeutic index of a drug serves as a measure for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Safety

Explanation:

  • Therapeutic Index (TI) is a measure used to assess a drug's safety.
  • It is defined as the ratio of the dose that produces toxicity to the dose that produces a therapeutic effect.

TI= median toxic dose/median effective dose ; (TD50/ED50)
  • The therapeutic window is the range of drug concentrations that can safely and effectively treat the disease.
  • If the TI window for a drug is narrow, it requires frequent monitoring.
  • E.g., Warfarin, Theophylline, Digoxin, Lithium (Warning These Drugs are Lethal)

Potency (Option B) is the amount of drug required to produce a given effect. The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.

  • The graph below helps us estimate the drugs' potency (The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency). The left shift of the graph indicates an increase in potency.
  • Thus the order of potency: Drug D > B > C > A.

Efficacy (Option C) is the maximal effect a drug can produce, represented by the Vmax /y-axis value. The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy.

  • The graph below helps us estimate the efficacy of the drugs (the higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy, Thus order of efficacy: Drug A > B >C >D.

questions.text: Renin is secreted by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) JG cells

Explanation:

  • Renin is secreted by the juxtaglomerular (JG) cells, which are specialized smooth muscle cells located in the walls of the afferent arterioles of the kidney, near the glomerulus.
  • These cells release renin in response to various stimuli, such as low blood pressure, low sodium levels, or sympathetic nervous system activation.

Location of JG Cells:

  • JG cells are specialized smooth muscle cells located in the afferent arteriole of the kidney, just before it enters the glomerulus.
  • These cells are part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA), which is responsible for regulating blood pressure and filtration rate.

Renin Secretion Trigger:

The JG cells secrete renin in response to several stimuli:

  • Low blood pressure (detected through baroreceptors in the JG cells).
  • Low sodium concentration in the distal tubule, which is sensed by the macula densa.
  • Sympathetic nervous system activation, which triggers the release of renin through β-adrenergic stimulation.

Function of Renin:

  • Renin is an enzyme that initiates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).
  • It converts angiotensinogen (released by the liver) into angiotensin I, which is later converted to angiotensin II in the lungs.
  • Angiotensin II raises blood pressure by constricting blood vessels and stimulating the release of aldosterone, which increases sodium and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Lacis cells (Option A): These are extraglomerular mesangial cells located near the JGA. While they are part of the JGA and play a role in supporting the JG cells, they do not secrete renin.

Macula densa (Option B): The macula densa cells are located in the distal convoluted tubule and detect sodium concentration in the filtrate. While they signal the JG cells to release renin when sodium levels are low, they do not secrete renin themselves.

Intraglomerular mesangial cells (Option D): These cells are located within the glomerulus and provide structural support. They do not secrete renin.

questions.text: Center controlling vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Area Postrema

Explanation:

  • The Area postrema is located in the medulla oblongata and is part of the vomiting center in the brain.
  • It plays a crucial role in detecting toxins or irritants in the blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and triggering the vomiting reflex.
  • This area has a "blood-brain barrier" that is less restrictive, allowing it to respond to circulating substances that may induce vomiting.

Vomiting pathway:

The vomiting pathway involves a complex coordination between multiple centers in the brain and peripheral structures. Here's a simplified pathway for vomiting (emesis):

1. Triggering Factors:

  • Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ): Located in the area postrema in the medulla, it detects toxins, drugs, or metabolic changes in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
  • Gastrointestinal Irritation: Distension, irritation, or inflammation in the stomach, intestines, or esophagus can send signals to the brain.
  • Vestibular System: Motion sickness or vertigo activates the vestibular system in the inner ear, sending signals to the vomiting center.
  • Higher Centers: Emotional stress, pain, or sights/smells (via the cortex and limbic system) can also induce vomiting.

2. Signal Transmission to the Vomiting Center:

  • Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ) and Gastrointestinal signals: These stimuli are relayed to the vomiting center in the medulla oblongata.
  • The vomiting center integrates signals from multiple sources, including the CTZ, vestibular system, and cerebral cortex.

3. Activation of the Vomiting Center:

  • The vomiting center (located in the medulla oblongata) coordinates the motor activities required for vomiting, such as contraction of the abdominal muscles and diaphragm, relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter, and retroperistalsis in the stomach.
  • Neurotransmitters involved in this process include serotonin (5-HT), dopamine, histamine, and acetylcholine.

4. The Vomiting Reflex:

  • Deep inspiration: The diaphragm contracts to create negative pressure.
  • Closure of the glottis: Prevents aspiration of vomitus into the lungs.
  • Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter: Allows the contents of the stomach to move upwards.
  • Contraction of abdominal muscles: Increases intra-abdominal pressure and forces stomach contents into the esophagus.
  • Ejection of gastric contents: Vomiting is completed with the expulsion of stomach contents.

 

Apneustic center (Option A): The apneustic center, located in the pons, is involved in the regulation of breathing patterns, not vomiting.

Pneumotaxic center (Option B): This center, also located in the pons, helps control the rate and pattern of breathing, not vomiting.

Pre-Bötzinger complex (Option D): Located in the medulla, this area is primarily responsible for generating rhythmic breathing and does not play a direct role in controlling vomiting.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not metabolized by acetylation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Phenytoin

Explanation:

  • Phenytoin is not metabolized by acetylation.
  • It is primarily metabolized by hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP2C9 and CYP2C19, via glucuronidation.
  • The main metabolic pathway involves the conversion of phenytoin to its inactive metabolite hydroxy phenytoin (p-HPPH).
  • p-HPPH undergoes further glucuronidation before excretion in the urine.

Options

Reaction

Examples

Acetylation

Acetylation: N-acetyltransferase (NAT), adds an acetyl group to drugs and compounds
  • Isoniazid (Option A)
  • Hydralazine (Option B)
  • Phenelzine
  • Dapsone
  • Procainamide (Option D)

Glycination

Glycination: The drugs are conjugated with glycine.
  • Salicylates.
  • Nicotinic acid.

Sulfation

Sulfation: The phenolic compounds and steroids are sulfated by sulfotransferases.
  • Chloramphenicol.
  • Methyldopa.
  • Adrenal & sex steroids.

Methylation

Methylation: The amines and phenols are methylated by methyl transferases.
  • Chloramphenicol.
  • Methyldopa.
  • Captopril.
  • Mercaptopurine.

questions.text: Enteropeptidase enzyme is secreted by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Duodenum

Explanation:

  • Enteropeptidase (also known as enterokinase) is an enzyme secreted by the duodenum, specifically by the brush border cells (enterocytes) in the small intestine.
  • Its main role is to activate trypsinogen (the inactive form of trypsin) into trypsin. Trypsin then activates other pancreatic enzymes that help in protein digestion.

Enzymes of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT):

Location

Enzyme

Function

Mouth

Salivary Amylase

Breaks down starch into maltose

Lingual Lipase

Begins digestion of lipids (mainly milk fat in infants)

Stomach

Pepsinogen (activated to Pepsin)

Breaks down proteins into smaller peptides

Gastric Lipase

Breaks down lipids, especially in infants

Small Intestine

Enteropeptidase (Enterokinase)

Activates trypsinogen to trypsin

Pancreatic Amylase

Continues carbohydrate digestion (starches to maltose and dextrins)

Pancreatic Lipase

Breaks down triglycerides into monoglycerides and free fatty acids

Pancreatic Proteases (Trypsin, Chymotrypsin, Carboxypeptidase)

Break down proteins into peptides and amino acids

Pancreatic Nucleases

Breaks down nucleic acids (DNA, RNA) into nucleotides

Disaccharidases (Sucrase, Lactase, Maltase)

Break down disaccharides into monosaccharides (e.g., glucose, galactose, fructose)

Aminopeptidases

Break down peptides into amino acids

Large Intestine

Bacterial Enzymes

Ferment carbohydrates (fiber) into short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) and gases

 

Stomach (Option A): The stomach secretes gastric juice containing pepsinogen (which is activated to pepsin) for protein digestion, but it does not secrete enteropeptidase.

Jejunum (Option C): While the jejunum is part of the small intestine involved in nutrient absorption, enteropeptidase is secreted in the duodenum, not the jejunum.

Ileum (Option D): The ileum is involved in absorbing nutrients, particularly bile salts and vitamin B12, but it does not secrete enteropeptidase.

questions.text: In the cardiac muscle, the inhibition of Na +K +ATPase results in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Depolarization

Explanation:

  • The Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump plays a crucial role in maintaining the resting membrane potential of cardiac muscle cells by actively pumping 3 Na⁺ ions out of the cell and 2 K⁺ ions in.
  • This maintains a high concentration of Na⁺ outside the cell and a high concentration of K⁺ inside the cell, contributing to a negative resting membrane potential.
  • Inhibition of the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump leads to a reduction in the gradient of sodium and potassium across the membrane. As a result:
    • Na⁺ accumulates inside the cell, making the inside less negative (more positive).
    • This causes depolarization, as the normal negative resting membrane potential is reduced or lost.

 

PHASES

OPENING AND CLOSURE OF CHANNELS

Phase 0- Depolarization

Opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels

Phase 1- Initial rapid repolarization

Closure of Na+ channels

Opening of K+ channel

Phase 2- Plateau phase

Slower but prolonged opening of L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels

K+ channel also remains open.

Phase 3- Late rapid repolarization

Closure of the Ca2+ channels

Slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux

 

Phase 4- Baseline

Resting Membrane Potential About −80 to −90 millivolts.

 

Hyperpolarization and then depolarization (Option A): Inhibition of Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase generally causes depolarization, not hyperpolarization, because the loss of the Na⁺ and K⁺ gradient makes the cell less negative inside.

Hyperpolarization (option C): Hyperpolarization would result from an increase in the efflux of K⁺ or an increase in the influx of Cl⁻, but Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase inhibition causes depolarization.

Repolarization (Option D): Repolarization refers to the return of the membrane potential to its resting negative value, which doesn't occur with Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase inhibition. Instead, depolarization occurs.

questions.text: What would be the subsequent diagnostic step for a 16-year-old girl who was brought to the hospital by her mother due to primary amenorrhea, where the evaluation revealed the presence of axillary and pubic hair along with normal secondary sexual characteristics, and an ultrasound scan indicated the absence of a uterus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Karyotyping

Explanation:

  • Karyotyping is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of primary amenorrhea with the absence of a uterus.
  • The presence of axillary and pubic hair, along with normal secondary sexual characteristics, suggests the presence of functional ovaries. However, the absence of the uterus raises the suspicion of a chromosomal abnormality, such as Turner syndrome (45,X), which is a common cause of primary amenorrhea with the absence of the uterus. Karyotyping helps in identifying any chromosomal abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Testosterone levels (Option A) are more relevant in cases of androgen excess or virilization, which is not indicated in this scenario.

Estrogen measurement (Option C): Since the patient has primary amenorrhea and the absence of uterus, the focus should be on evaluating chromosomal abnormalities rather than measuring estrogen levels.

LH and FSH measurement (Option D) can be helpful in the diagnosis of primary amenorrhea, but karyotyping takes priority in this case. LH and FSH levels can provide information about the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis and help differentiate between various causes of primary amenorrhea.

questions.text: Lysosomal enzymes are present ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cytosol

Explanation:

  • Lysosomal enzymes are primarily found within the lysosomes, which are membrane-bound organelles in the cytosol. These enzymes are responsible for breaking down a variety of biological polymers, such as proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates, into their constituent monomers.
  • Lysosomes contain around 50 types of hydrolytic enzymes, including proteases, lipases, nucleases, and glycosidases. These enzymes function in an acidic environment (pH 4.5 to 5.0) and are crucial for intracellular digestion, autophagy, and the degradation of cellular waste.

 

Mitochondria (Option B): Mitochondria are involved in energy production (ATP synthesis) and not in the storage of lysosomal enzymes.

Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) (Option C): The ER is involved in the synthesis of proteins, lipids, and the detoxification of harmful substances, but it is not the location of lysosomal enzymes.

Nucleus (Option D): The nucleus houses genetic material (DNA) and is involved in transcription and RNA processing, but it does not store lysosomal enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an alkylating agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 5-Fluorouracil

Explanation:

5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is not an alkylating agent, and it is a fluoropyrimidine antimetabolite that interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis.

5-Fluorouracil

MOA

Inhibits thymidylate synthase after conversion to FdUMP, leading to decreased thymidine production and inhibition of DNA synthesis

Uses

  • Colorectal cancer
    • FOLFOX Regimen: Folinic acid , Fluorouracil (5-FU), Oxaliplatin
    • FOLFIRINOX Regimen: Folinic acid, Fluorouracil (5-FU), Irinotecan, Oxaliplatin
  • All GIT cancer, along with platin
  • Breast cancer
  • Topical application on skin: For treatment of
    • Mycosis Fungoides (Sezary Syndrome)
    • Basal Cell Carcinoma
    • Actinic Keratosis

Side effects
  • Bone marrow suppression
  • Mucositis
  • Hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia)
  • Alopecia
  • Rarely - cardiotoxicity and neurotoxicity

Melphalan (Option A) is an alkylating agent. It belongs to the class of nitrogen mustards and works by forming covalent bonds with DNA, leading to cross-linking and damage to the DNA strands which ultimately inhibits cell division and growth.

Cyclophosphamide (Option B) is an alkylating agent. It is a prodrug that is metabolized in the body to its active form, phosphoramide mustard. Like other alkylating agents, cyclophosphamide forms covalent bonds with DNA, leading to DNA damage and disruption of cell division.

Busulfan (Option C) is an alkylating agent. Busulfan works by forming DNA cross-links and inhibiting DNA synthesis, leading to the suppression of abnormal cell growth.

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination his vitals were stable, but he could not speak. He had normal handwriting skills, and could understand what was being asked of him to which he responded by nodding. Where could be the lesion for this clinical condition?

choices.text: Occlusion of left internal carotid artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Broca’s area

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests a condition known as Broca's aphasia, which is characterized by non-fluent speech. The patient can understand speech and perform normal motor activities (such as handwriting), but cannot speak.
  • Broca's area, located in the left frontal lobe (in the posterior part of the frontal gyrus), is responsible for speech production. A lesion in this area leads to difficulty in speech production, but comprehension remains intact. This explains why the patient can understand what is being asked and respond by nodding, but cannot speak.

 

 

Brodmann Areas:

Definition

  • Numbered regions of the cerebral cortex identified by Korbinian Brodmann, based on neuronal structure and arrangement.
  • Linked to sensory processing, motor control, and cognitive functions.

Key Brodmann Areas and Functions

 

Brodmann Area

Function

1, 2, 3

Primary somatosensory cortex; processes tactile information.

4

Primary motor cortex; controls voluntary movements.

5, 7

Somatosensory association areas; integrate sensory input.

6

Premotor/supplementary motor areas; plan movements.

17

Primary visual cortex; processes visual data.

18, 19

Visual association areas; advanced visual processing.

22

Wernicke's area; facilitates language comprehension.

44, 45

Broca's area; involved in speech production.

 

Wernicke’s area (Option B): Lesions in Wernicke’s area, located in the left temporal lobe, cause fluent but nonsensical speech (Wernicke’s aphasia). The patient would have difficulty understanding spoken language, which is not the case here.

Primary motor cortex (Option C): A lesion in the primary motor cortex would cause motor deficits, such as weakness or paralysis, but would not specifically affect speech production in isolation.

Occlusion of left internal carotid artery (Option D): Occlusion of the left internal carotid artery can cause a stroke that might affect various brain regions, but it would likely cause more widespread neurological deficits, including motor and sensory impairments, not just selective speech impairment like in Broca's aphasia.

questions.text: Identify this movement that takes place in the intestine.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peristalisis

Explanation:

  • Peristalsis is a wave-like muscular contraction that occurs in the smooth muscle layers of the digestive tract, including the intestines. It propels food and chyme forward through the gastrointestinal tract in a unidirectional manner. This is the movement responsible for pushing the contents of the intestine through the digestive system.

Peristalsis:

  • Reflex response is initiated by the stretching of the gut wall due to the contents of the lumen.

Location:

  • It occurs throughout the gastrointestinal tract, from the esophagus to the rectum.

Mechanism:

  • Stretching triggers circular contraction behind the stimulus and relaxation in front of it.
  • The wave of contraction moves in an oral-to-caudal direction.
  • Propels the contents of the lumen forward at rates of 2 to 25 cm/s.

Regulation:

  • Peristaltic activity is influenced by autonomic input but occurs independently of extrinsic innervation.
  • Local stretch releases serotonin, activating sensory neurons that stimulate the myenteric plexus.
  • Cholinergic neurons in the myenteric plexus:
    • In retrograde direction: release substance P and acetylcholine, causing contraction behind the bolus.
    • In anterograde direction: activate the neurons releasing nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP), causing relaxation ahead of the bolus

Functional Integration:

  • Peristalsis is an example of the integrated activity of the enteric nervous system.

Neurotransmitters Involved in Peristalsis

 

Neurotransmitter

Role

Mechanism

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Stimulates contraction

Acts on muscarinic receptors, increases motility

Substance P

Promotes ascending contraction

Released by mucosal stimulation, enhances orad contraction

Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP)

Promotes relaxation

Acts on smooth muscle to induce relaxation during peristalsis

Serotonin (5-HT)

Regulates motility and initiates reflex

Released from enterochromaffin cells, activates 5-HT receptors

Nitric Oxide (NO)

Mediates relaxation

Released by inhibitory neurons, assists VIP in relaxation

Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP)

Influences sensory signaling

Modulated by serotonin, aids in coordinating reflexes

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 65-year-old woman who arrives at the outpatient department with symptoms of breathlessness and fatigue? She has no previous medical history of reactive airway disease or heart disease, but she has undergone breast cancer treatment including breast conservation surgery and chemoradiation. On examination, engorged neck veins and jugular venous pressure (JVP) indicate a rapid x and y descent. The chest x-ray findings are as follows.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Constrictive pericarditis.

Explanation:

  • Constrictive pericarditis is a condition where the pericardium (the sac surrounding the heart) becomes thickened, fibrotic, and less flexible. This restricts the heart's ability to expand fully during diastole, leading to heart failure-like symptoms such as breathlessness and fatigue. It often occurs after chest irradiation or cardiac surgery, both of which the patient has experienced due to breast cancer treatment.
  • The symptoms of engorged neck veins and a rapid x and y descent in the JVP are typical findings in constrictive pericarditis. These signs reflect impaired diastolic filling and rapid early filling of the heart during diastole due to the rigid pericardium.
  • The chest X-ray findings would typically show pericardial calcification, which is a classic feature of constrictive pericarditis.

 

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): This condition involves accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, leading to pressure on the heart. While it can also cause symptoms like engorged neck veins, jugular venous distension, and breathlessness, the JVP typically shows a prominent "blunted" y descent (rather than the rapid x and y descent seen in constrictive pericarditis). Cardiac tamponade is usually associated with more acute symptoms, not the chronic course that would follow radiation treatment for breast cancer.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option C): This condition involves enlargement and weakening of the heart muscle, leading to heart failure. However, it is less likely to present with the characteristic rapid x and y descent in the JVP, which is more specific to constrictive pericarditis.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option D): This is a condition where the heart's walls become rigid, but it is typically due to amyloidosis, fibrosis, or other systemic diseases. It can present with heart failure and engorged neck veins, but the pattern of JVP is usually different, with a prominent x descent and a slow y descent, unlike constrictive pericarditis which shows a rapid x and y descent.

questions.text: Proton pump inhibitor suppresses gastric acid secretion by acting on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) H+/K+ ATPase pump

Explanation:

  • Proton pump inhibitor suppresses gastric acid secretion by inhibiting the H+/K+ ATPase pump located in the parietal cells of the stomach.

Proton pump inhibitor

MOA

It inhibits the H+/K+ ATPase pump located in the parietal cells of the stomach, thus reducing acid secretion in the stomach.

Potency of PPI
  • Rabeprazole > Lansoprazole > Rabeprazole > Omeprazole > Pantoprazole
  • All PPIs have equal efficacy.

Properties

  • Acid production reduction persists for 2 to 4 days even after stopping the drug and resumes later.
  • Duration of action is typically 2 to 4 days.
    • Omeprazole is the fastest acting PPI.
    • PPIs are acid labile; Enteric coating can protect from acid degradation.
    • They should be taken on an empty stomach when only ~I0% of proton pumps are active, followed 1 hour later by a meal to activate the H+/K+/ATPase at a time when plasma concentration of the PPI is maximal.

Side effects

  • Chronic use of PPIs can lead to hypergastrinemia, which can further result in:
    • ECL hyperplasia
    • Fundic gland polyposis
    • Atrophic gastritis
  • Gastrointestinal upset (nausea, constipation, diarrhoea)
  • Increased microbial growth leads to a higher risk of bacterial infection
  • Increased risk of bone fractures due to hypocalcemia (reduced absorption of calcium)

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, point C denotes –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aortic valve opens

Explanation:

  • Point C specifically marks the opening of the aortic valve, allowing for the ejection of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta.

 

  • Point A: Represents the end-diastolic volume (EDV), just before the mitral valve closes and the ventricle begins to contract.
  • Point B: The point where the mitral valve closes and isovolumetric contraction begins, leading to an increase in pressure within the left ventricle without a change in volume. (Option A ruled out)
  • Point C: This is where the aortic valve opens and blood begins to be ejected from the left ventricle into the aorta during systole. This is typically the point marked after the isovolumetric contraction phase when pressure rises sufficiently to exceed the aortic pressure.
  • Point D: This is where the aortic valve closes, marking the end of the systolic ejection phase and the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation.(Option C ruled out)
  • Point E: The point where the mitral valve opens, allowing for the ventricular filling phase during diastole. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Arjun (32/M) comes to your clinic for a regular health check-up with his wife (28/F). He weighs 65 kgs and his lifestyle is predominantly sedentary. His wife weighs 55 kg, is pregnant, and is in her second trimester. Her lifestyle is sedentary too. According to the ICMR 2020, how many calories should Arjun and his wife respectively consume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2110 Kcal, 2010 Kcal

Explanation:

  • Caloric Requirement for Arjun (Sedentary Male): According to the ICMR 2020 guidelines, sedentary adult men require 2110 Kcal/day for maintaining energy balance.
  • Caloric Requirement for Arjun’s Wife (Sedentary Pregnant Woman in the Second Trimester): Sedentary adult women require 1660 Kcal/day, and during pregnancy, an additional 340 Kcal/day is recommended. This brings the total caloric requirement for a sedentary pregnant woman in her second trimester to 2010 Kcal/day.

During pregnancy, the nutritional requirements of the mother increase to support fetal growth and development. Here's the breakdown of energy needs during pregnancy:

  • First trimester: Energy requirements are generally the same as for non-pregnant women.
  • Second trimester: Energy intake should increase by 340 kcal per day, though 300 kcal is commonly recommended, according to ICMR guidelines.
  • Third trimester: Energy intake increases further by 452 kcal per day, with a recommended 300 kcal intake, according to ICMR.

Therefore, the recommended increase in caloric intake for a pregnant woman at 12 weeks (in the second trimester) is 300 kcal per day.

Recommended Dietary Allowances For Energy And Protein For Indians

Category

EAR - Energy (Kcal/D)

RDA - Protein (g/D)

Man

Sedentary work

2110

54

Moderate work

2710

54

Heavy work

3470

54

Woman

Sedentary work

1660

46

Moderate work

2130

46

Heavy work

2720

46

Pregnancy (2nd trimester)

+340

+9.5

Pregnancy (3rd trimester)

+452

+22

Lactation (0-6 months)

+600

530

Lactation (6-12 months)

+520

questions.text: What is the treatment of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Omeprazole

Explanation:

  • Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that can be used to treat Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, a condition characterised by excessive gastric acid secretion due to gastrin-secreting tumours (gastrinomas).
  • Its treatment is aimed at controlling acid hypersecretion to prevent complications such as peptic ulcers.
  • Omeprazole helps alleviate the symptoms and complications associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • Other PPls such as pantoprazole, lansoprazole, and esomeprazole may also be used.

Incorrect Options:

Cimetidine (Option A) is an H2 receptor antagonist, reduces stomach acid production and can provide symptomatic relief for GERD and peptic ulcers. However, it is not the first-line treatment for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which requires more potent acid-suppressing medications due to excessive gastrin-induced acid secretion.

Misoprostol (Option C) is a prostaglandin analogue that has cytoprotective properties and can help prevent gastric ulcers caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). While it may be used for certain conditions involving gastric ulcers, it is not typically considered a primary treatment for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Aluminium hydroxide (Option D) is an antacid that neutralizes stomach acid, providing temporary relief from symptoms like heartburn and indigestion. However, it does not address the underlying cause of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and can cause constipation with excessive use.

questions.text: What can be done to address the concerns of a woman who is 3 months postpartum, regularly breastfeeding, and experiencing amenorrhea for the past 3 months, before considering surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Reassure

Explanation:

  • Postpartum amenorrhea is common, especially in breastfeeding women.
  • During breastfeeding, prolactin levels increase, which suppresses the release of FSH and LH, leading to temporary amenorrhea.
  • Reassurance is the appropriate step before considering any invasive measures or treatment options.

Incorrect Options:

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (Option A) is not indicated for managing postpartum amenorrhea unless there are specific concerns such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Contraceptives (Option B) may not be necessary if the patient wishes to conceive or if there are no medical indications requiring contraception.

Pulsatile GnRH (Option C) is typically used for conditions like hypothalamic amenorrhea or specific hormonal imbalances but is not the first-line approach for postpartum amenorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not used in the management of bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Cholinergic drugs

Explanation:

Cholinergic drugs are not used in bronchial asthma management, as cholinergic stimulation can cause bronchoconstriction, worsening the condition.

Drugs used in asthma

Category

Examples

MOA

Uses

Short-acting beta-agonists (SABAs)

(Option C)

Albuterol (Salbutamol), Levalbuterol

Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchial smooth muscle relaxation.

Acute relief of bronchospasm in asthma attacks (rescue medication).

Long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs)

Salmeterol, Formoterol

Prolonged stimulation of beta-2 receptors for bronchodilation.

Maintenance therapy (always used with ICS).

Anticholinergics (Short-acting)

Ipratropium

Blocks muscarinic receptors, reducing bronchoconstriction.

Alternative or additive for acute asthma, especially with SABAs.

Inhaled Corticosteroids (ICS) (Option B)
 

Beclomethasone, Budesonide, Fluticasone

Reduces airway inflammation and prevents exacerbations

First-line maintenance therapy in persistent asthma.

Leukotriene Receptor Antagonists (LTRAs)

Montelukast, Zafirlukast

Blocks leukotriene receptors, reducing inflammation and bronchoconstriction.

Maintenance therapy, especially in mild asthma or aspirin-induced asthma.

Mast Cell Stabilizers

Sodium Cromoglycate, Nedocromil

Inhibits mast cell degranulation, reducing mediator release.

Preventive therapy for mild persistent asthma or exercise-induced asthma.

Biologics

Omalizumab

Binds to IgE, preventing its interaction with receptors on mast cells.

Moderate to severe allergic asthma uncontrolled with ICS and LABAs.

Methylxanthines

(Option A)
 

Theophylline, Aminophylline

Non-selective phosphodiesterase inhibition leads to bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects.

Add-on therapy in severe or difficult-to-control asthma.

Most commonly used in COPD rather than asthma.

questions.text: Pharmacodynamics deals with?

choices.text: Mechanism of action of a drug
Transport of drugs across the biological membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Mechanism of action of a drug

Explanation:

  • Pharmacodynamics deals with the mechanism of action of a drug.
  • The primary focus of pharmacodynamics is the study of how a drug produces its therapeutic effects at the molecular or cellular level.
  • It refers to the specific biochemical and physiological interactions between a drug and its target molecules in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Mode of excretion of a drug (Option A) refers to the process by which a drug is eliminated from the body. It involves the removal of drugs or their metabolites from the bloodstream through various routes, such as renal excretion (via urine), hepatic excretion (via bile), or pulmonary excretion (via breath). This process is part of pharmacokinetics.

Transport of drugs across the biological membranes (Option C) is related to pharmacokinetics, which deals with the absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion of drugs (often referred to as ADME).

The latency of onset (Option D) refers to the time a drug takes to produce its pharmacological effect after administration. This is influenced by factors such as drug formulation, route, absorption rate, and distribution. While pharmacodynamics can indirectly affect the onset, the primary focus of this discipline is on the drug's mechanism of action.

questions.text: Identify the type of pelvis shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anthropoid pelvis

Explanation:

  • The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by an oval shape with a longer anteroposterior diameter and a narrower transverse diameter. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with a favorable outcome for vaginal delivery, particularly when the baby is in the face-to-pubis position.

Pelvic Types

Feature

Gynecoid

(Option A)

Android

(Option C)

Anthropoid

Platypelloid

(Option D)

Shape

Round or slightly oval

Heart-shaped

Oval (anteroposterior)

Flattened oval (transverse)

Prevalence

Most common (~50%)

~20%

~25%

Rare (~5%)

Description
  • Transversely oval pelvic inlet
  • Broad, shallow sacrum
  • Blunt, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Wide subpubic angle (>90°)
  • Triangular or heart-shaped pelvic inlet
  • Flat, forward-inclined sacrum
  • Prominent, closely spaced ischial spines
  • Narrow subpubic angle (<70°)
  • Oval pelvic inlet (anteroposterior > transverse)
  • Long, narrow sacrum
  • Less prominent, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Narrow subpubic angle (~70°)
  • Wide, flat pelvic inlet (transverse > anteroposterior)
  • Short, flat sacrum
  • Blunt, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Wide subpubic angle (>90°)

Obstetric Significance
  • Ideal for vaginal delivery due to spacious cavity and optimal dimensions
  • Increased risk of obstructed labor
  • Associated with deep transverse arrest
  • Favors occipito-posterior fetal positions
  • Vaginal delivery usually possible
  • Delayed engagement of the fetal head
  • Higher likelihood of cesarean delivery

questions.text: Beta-blockers should be avoided in all except.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Glaucoma

Explanation:

Glaucoma can be treated with beta-blockers, such as betaxolol. Betaxolol works by blocking beta-2 receptors in the ciliary body, reducing cAMP levels and thereby decreasing aqueous humor production.

Types of beta-blocker

Examples

Uses

Non-selective beta-blocker

Propranolol, nadolol
  • Hypertension
  • Angina
  • Arrhythmias
  • Migraine prophylaxis

Beta-1-selective blockers

Metoprolol, Atenolol
  • Hypertension
  • Heart failure
  • Arrhythmias

Beta-1-with Alpha-1 blockade

Carvedilol, Labetalol
  • Hypertension
  • Heart failure
  • Post-MI

Side effects of beta-blocker

Cardiac side effects

  • Precipitation of an acute MI.
  • Sinus bradycardia and heart block. (Option C)
  • Heart failure may exacerbate symptoms in patients with decompensated heart failure or preexisting myocardial dysfunction.

Extracardiac side effects

  • Increased airway resistance; hence, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to bronchospasm. (Option A)
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease and worsen claudication and precipitate Raynaud's disease.
  • In Hypoglycemia, Beta-blockers mask the signs seen in a hypoglycemic patient, such as tachycardia.
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Depression, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction.
  • Weight gain

Hypothyroidism (Option D) is not an indication of beta-blockers; they can be used to provide symptomatic relief in hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A female patient presented with pain and redness in the great toe. The serum uric acid level is 9.4mg/dl. The physician prescribed a drug for the treatment. Which of the following enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Xanthine oxidase

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes a female patient with pain and redness in the great toe, which suggests gout, a condition caused by elevated uric acid levels.
  • The patient's serum uric acid level of 9.4 mg/dl is above the normal range, indicating hyperuricemia, which can lead to the formation of uric acid crystals in the joints, causing pain and inflammation.
  • The physician has prescribed a drug that helps manage gout by reducing uric acid levels.
  • The drug prescribed is allopurinol, which is known to inhibit xanthine oxidase, the enzyme responsible for converting hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid.
  • By inhibiting xanthine oxidase, allopurinol decreases the production of uric acid, effectively managing gout by lowering uric acid levels in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Phosphoribosyl transferase (Option A): Involved in purine metabolism, but not the target of allopurinol.

Thymidylate synthase (Option B): Involved in DNA synthesis, not related to gout treatment.

Dihydrofolate reductase (Option D): Involved in folate metabolism, and inhibited by drugs like methotrexate, not relevant to gout treatment.

questions.text: A new drug is introduced into the market after which phase of the clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Phase III

Explanation:

After phase III of the clinical trials, a new drug can be introduced into the market.
 

Clinical trials

Phases

Description

Phase 0
  • Design: An open-label trial
  • Purpose:
    • Check the target binding of a drug
    • Check the pharmacokinetics of the drug
  • Called a micro-dosing trial (100 micrograms dose)
  • Non-mandatory clinical trial

Phase I

(Option A)
  • Design: An open-label trial
  • Purpose:
    • Evaluate drug safety- the most important
    • Evaluate MTD (maximum tolerable dose), loading dose, and drug half-life.
    • Evaluate drug pharmacokinetics (absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion)
  • Called the first human trial

Phase II

(Option B)
  • Design: Randomized clinical trial (RCT)
  • Purpose:
    • Explore drug efficacy
  • Called a therapeutic exploratory trial or proof of concept trial

Phase III
  • Design: Double-blinded RCT
  • Purpose:
    • Find the optimal drug dose
    • Confirm efficacy
    • Safety is priority
  • Called a therapeutic confirmatory trial
  • Called multi-site trial (done on a heterogeneous population)
  • Drugs get market approval

Phase IV

(Option D)
  • Design: Open-label
  • Purpose:
    • Find hidden/missed/rare adverse effects.
    • Evaluate compliance: long-term side effects
    • Drug interactions
    • Food interactions
  • Called post-marketing surveillance

questions.text: What is the cause of dicrotic notch?

choices.text: Passive filling of blood in ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Closure of semilunar valves.

Explanation:

  • The dicrotic notch (incisura) is a small downward deflection seen in the arterial pressure waveform just after the systolic peak.
  • It occurs due to sudden closure of the aortic and pulmonary (semilunar) valves at the end of ventricular systole.
  • This closure causes a brief backflow of blood into the aorta and pulmonary artery, which is then halted, leading to a pressure rebound in the arteries.

Phases of the Arterial Pulse Wave

Phase

Event

Upstroke (Systolic Rise)

Ventricular ejection increases aortic pressure

Systolic Peak

Maximum arterial pressure

Dicrotic Notch

Semilunar valve closure and transient backflow

Diastolic Decay

Gradual pressure decrease as blood moves into periphery

 

Passive filling of blood in ventricles (Option A): Incorrect because ventricular filling occurs in diastole, unrelated to the dicrotic notch.

Rapid Ejection Phase (Option B): Incorrect because this phase occurs before the dicrotic notch, when blood is actively ejected.

Isovolumic Contraction (Option D): Incorrect because this occurs before semilunar valves open, while the dicrotic notch happens after they close.

questions.text: All of the following are lipotropic factors except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Arginine

Explanation:

  • Arginine is an amino acid involved in nitric oxide production and other functions but is not considered a lipotropic factor.

Lipotropic factors

  • Lipotropic factors are nutrients such as choline, betaine, and methionine that help improve liver function and detoxification. (Option A & D ruled out)
  • Lecithin contains choline as its primary active ingredient and is considered a lipotropic agent. (Option B ruled out)
  • These compounds promote the flow of fat and bile to and from the liver, aiding fat metabolism and liver health.
  • They are used to treat liver disorders like hepatitis, cirrhosis, and chemical-induced liver disease.
  • Lipotropic formulas may increase the liver's levels of S-adenosyl-methionine and glutathione, key compounds for liver function and detoxification.
  • Common lipotropic agents include choline, methionine, betaine, folic acid, and vitamin B12.
  • These formulas support detoxification, protect liver function, and enhance fat metabolism.
  • They may also play a role in methylation and epigenetics, influencing health at a molecular level.
  • Carnitine, another lipotropic agent, helps prevent alcohol-induced fatty liver disease by improving fatty acid metabolism.
  • Lipotropic formulas are also used in detoxification, especially in conditions like chronic candidiasis and liver damage.
  • Daily recommended doses for choline and methionine are 1000 mg each.
  • Lipotropic agents are often combined with other herbs and nutrients to support liver health and detoxification.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective estrogen receptor modulator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tamoxifen

Explanation:

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator.

Aspect

Tamoxifen

MOA

Estrogen Receptor (ER) Antagonist

        ↓

Binds to ER

       ↓

Tissue-specific effects such as :

  • Antagonist in breast tissue (prevents estrogen binding).
  • Agonist in bone and cardiovascular tissues (estrogen-like effects)

Clinical Use
  • Drug of choice for ER-positive breast cancer.
  • Decrease the risk of contralateral breast cancer.

Side Effects
  • Increased risk of endometrial cancer.
  • Thromboembolism
  • Hot flashes
  • Depression
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Cataracts.

Drug Interactions
  • It should not be combined with fluoxetine and other SSRIs.
  • SSRIs inhibit the CYP2D6 enzyme, essential for converting tamoxifen into its active form, endoxifen.
  • This interaction may lower endoxifen levels, diminishing tamoxifen's effectiveness against estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Estrogen (Option A) is a steroid hormone associated with the female reproductive organs and is responsible for developing female sexual characteristics. Estrogen or estradiol is the most common form of estrogen hormone for FDA-approved treatment as hormone replacement therapy in managing symptoms associated with menopause. It stimulates all estrogen receptors in all tissues.

Metformin (Option B) is a biguanide compound that is used for the treatment of diabetes, PCOS, and insulin resistance. Metformin can inhibit 17ß-estradiol-stimulated cell proliferation and the expression of estrogen receptors in a dose-dependent manner in cancer cells.

Adriamycin (Option D) is used alone or with other drugs to treat many types of cancer, including leukemia, lymphoma, neuroblastoma, sarcoma, Wilms tumor, and certain cancers of the lung, breast, stomach, ovary, thyroid, and bladder.

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protein folding

Explanation:

  • Chaperones are proteins that assist in the correct folding of other proteins.
  • When a protein is synthesized, it may adopt various three-dimensional structures, and only one of these structures will have biological activity.
  • Chaperones prevent the incorrect folding of proteins and ensure they achieve the correct structure necessary for proper function.
  • They are crucial in the assembly of tertiary and quaternary protein structures.
  • Chaperones, such as heat shock proteins (HSPs), are also produced in response to stress, including heat, toxins, or radiation, and help in maintaining protein integrity under these conditions.
  • Misfolded proteins can lead to diseases, including prion diseases and chaperonopathies.

Incorrect Options:

Ubiquitinization of proteins (Option A): Ubiquitinization refers to the process where a small protein called ubiquitin is attached to other proteins, typically marking them for degradation by the proteasome. This is unrelated to the function of chaperones, which focus on helping proteins fold correctly, not tagging them for destruction.

Protein modification (Option B) involves chemical changes to a protein after its synthesis, such as phosphorylation, glycosylation, or acetylation. While chaperones help proteins fold correctly, they do not directly modify them in terms of adding chemical groups or altering their structure after they are fully folded.

Protein cleavage (Option D) is the process of breaking down proteins into smaller peptides, often by enzymes like proteases. This process is not related to the role of chaperones, which help proteins fold into their correct structures rather than breaking them down or cleaving them into smaller parts.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Isovolumic relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) AV valves are closed.

Explanation:

  • Isovolumic relaxation is the phase of the cardiac cycle that occurs after ventricular systole when the ventricles relax but before they fill with blood.
  • During this phase:
    • Ventricles relax → Pressure falls.
    • Semilunar valves (aortic & pulmonary) close to prevent backflow.
    • AV valves remain closed until ventricular pressure drops below atrial pressure.
    • There is no volume change in the ventricles, only a pressure drop.

Cardiac Cycle Phases

Phase

AV Valves

Semilunar Valves

Event

Isovolumic Contraction

Closed

Closed

Ventricles contract but no ejection

Ventricular Ejection

Closed

Open

Blood ejected into aorta & pulmonary artery

Isovolumic Relaxation

Closed

Closed

Ventricles relax, no filling yet

Ventricular Filling

Open

Closed

Blood flows into ventricles

 

QT Interval (Option B): Incorrect because QT interval represents ventricular depolarization and repolarization, not just isovolumic relaxation.

'C' Wave of JVP (Option C): Incorrect because the 'C' wave occurs during ventricular systole due to bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium.

Semilunar Valves Open (Option D): Incorrect because semilunar valves are closed in isovolumic relaxation.

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody is used in cancer treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rituximab

Explanation:

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of certain cancers, such as non-Hodgkin lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and rheumatoid arthritis.

Rituximab

A chimeric murine/human monoclonal IgG1 antibody targets the CD20 B-cell surface antigen.

MOA

Upon binding to CD20, it induces B-cell lysis through two main mechanisms:

  • Complement-Dependent Cytotoxicity (CDC) and
  • Antibody-Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC).

Uses
  • CD-20 positive B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Pemphigus vulavaris

Pharmacokinetics

Half-life of 22 days

Side effects
  • Infusion reaction - fever, rash and joint pain
  • Upper respiratory tract infections
  • Steven johnson syndrome
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • HBV reactivation
  • Tumor lysis syndrome
  • Cytokine release syndrome

Note

Pretreatment with antihistamines, antipyretics and glucocorticoids reduces the risk of hypersensitivity reactions

Incorrect Options:

Omalizumab (Option A) is a recombinant, humanized, monoclonal antibody against human immunoglobulin E (IgE). It is used in Urticaria and Atopic Dermatitis.

﻿﻿Denosumab (Option B) is a fully human monoclonal antibody that binds the cytokine RANKL (receptor activator of NFKB ligand), an essential factor initiating bone turnover.
RANKL inhibition blocks osteoclast maturation, function and survival, thus reducing bone resorption. ﻿﻿It is used for the treatment of Osteoporosis.

Methotrexate (Option D) is an anti-metabolite, not a monoclonal antibody. It is most commonly used in chemotherapy and immunosuppressants in auto-immune diseases.

questions.text: On centrifugation of a cell, LDH will get deposited in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cytoplasm

Explanation:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is primarily located in the cytoplasm.
  • The enzyme exists in various isoforms, with LDH-5 being the most abundant in the cytoplasm.
  • About 99% of LDH activity is found in the cytoplasm, where it plays a critical role in the conversion of lactate to pyruvate and vice versa, part of the cell's metabolic processes.
  • While a small fraction of LDH can be found in the nucleus (involved in DNA binding and transcription), the vast majority of LDH activity occurs in the cytoplasm.

Incorrect Options:

Mitochondria (Option A): LDH is not primarily located in the mitochondria. Mitochondria contain enzymes like pyruvate dehydrogenase and enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle, but LDH, which is involved in anaerobic metabolism, is predominantly found in the cytoplasm.

Lysosome (Option B): LDH is not found in significant amounts in the lysosome. Lysosomes are involved in cellular digestion and degradation processes, and while some enzymes may be active there, LDH is not typically one of them. It is primarily cytoplasmic

Golgi complex (Option D) is responsible for modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins for secretion or use within the cell, but it is not a location where LDH is predominantly found. LDH is mainly active in the cytoplasm and plays its role in energy metabolism rather than processing or transporting cellular components like the Golgi.

questions.text: Nitrogenous waste is excreted from the body in the form of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Urea

Explanation:

  • Ammonia is produced during the breakdown of amino acids and by gut bacteria in humans.
  • However, ammonia is highly toxic, especially to the brain, if its levels in the blood rise too high.
  • To prevent this toxicity, the body converts ammonia into urea through the urea cycle.
  • This process occurs in the liver, where ammonia is safely transformed into urea, a less toxic substance.
  • Urea is then excreted from the body through the urine, effectively removing excess nitrogenous waste from the body.

Incorrect Options:

Nitric oxide (Option B): A signaling molecule involved in vasodilation and other processes, not nitrogenous waste excretion.

Ammonia (Option C): While ammonia is produced during amino acid breakdown, it is toxic at high levels and is converted into urea for excretion.

Glutamine (Option D): An amino acid involved in nitrogen transport but not directly excreted as a nitrogenous waste product.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urinary stream and frequent urination in small amounts and is on prazosin. He also mentions that he frequently feels light-headed and has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers would you prefer to give him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Tamsulosin
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and is experiencing postural hypotension, likely due to prazosin, a non-selective alpha-1 antagonist that affects both vascular and urogenital alpha-1 receptors.
  • Tamsulosin, an alpha-1A selective antagonist, primarily targets receptors in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urinary symptoms with minimal effects on blood pressure. This selectivity reduces the risk of postural hypotension

Types

Alpha blockers

Non-competitive + irreversible type

Phenoxybenzamine

Competitive + reversible type

 

Non-
selective
  • Phentolamine
  • Ergotamine
  • Ergotoxine
  • Chlorpromazine

 

 

 

 

 

Alpha 1 selective

Drugs

Location

Effects

Alpha 1 a

  • Tamsulosin
  • Silodosin

Internal urethral sphincter and Iris

Ejaculation failure/retrograde ejaculation, miosis, increased urine outflow

Alpha 1 b

  • Alfuzosin
  • Doxazosin
  • Prazosin
  • Terazosin

Vascular Smooth muscle

Vasodilatation, reflex tachycardia, reduced GFR (thus leading to RAAS activation)

Alpha 2 selective
  • Yohimbine
  • Idoxazon

Central nervous system

Penile erection (used in depression with sexual dysfunction)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Alfuzosin (Option A), Terazosin (Option B) and Doxazosin (Option D): Block A1B receptors, decrease peripheral vascular resistance and lower arterial blood pressure by causing relaxation of both arterial and venous smooth muscle, but it does not increase urinary outflow thus cannot be used in BPH.

questions.text: What is the probable vitamin deficiency in a patient who displays symptoms of diarrhea, memory impairment, and a distinctive rash as described?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Niacin

Explanation:

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea, and
  • Dementia.

The patient's symptoms, combined with a diet high in maize and sorghum, both known to contribute to niacin and tryptophan deficiencies suggest pellagra as the most likely diagnosis. Sorghum has high leucine content which inhibits the QPRTase enzyme required for synthesis of Niacin from tryptophan. Additionally, Maize is low in tryptophan.

Causes of pellagra:

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
    • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
      • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
      • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
      • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
      • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    • Malabsorption Syndromes

Incorrect Options:

Thiamine (Option A) deficiency causes beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, with symptoms like confusion, ataxia, and neuropathy, but not diarrhea or rash. Memory impairment in thiamine deficiency is usually associated with neurological issues, not the dermatitis seen in pellagra.

Cyanocobalamin (Option C) is vitamin B12, and its deficiency typically leads to pernicious anemia, neuropathy, and cognitive dysfunction. It does not present with diarrhea or a characteristic rash.

Ascorbic acid (Option D) is vitamin C, and its deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by gum bleeding, easy bruising, and poor wound healing, but not typically diarrhea or a rash like niacin deficiency.

questions.text: Diagnosis of Gout is confirmed by which test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Synovial Fluid Analysis

Explanation:

Gout

  • Inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and tissues due to hyperuricemia

Clinical Presentation:

  • Acute Gouty Attack- Sudden onset of intense joint pain, typically affecting the big toe, but can also involve other joints such as the ankle, knee, wrist, or elbow
  • Chronic Gout- Recurrent attacks of joint inflammation, development of tophi (deposits of urate crystals) in joints and soft tissues

Diagnosis:

  • Medical History- History of recurrent joint pain, sudden onset, and self-limiting nature of attacks.
  • Physical Examination- Joint examination revealing signs of inflammation (redness, swelling, warmth)
  • Synovial Fluid Analysis-Detection of monosodium urate crystals in synovial fluid aspirated from an affected joint
  • Serum Uric Acid Level- Elevated serum uric acid levels (>6.8 mg/dL) may support the diagnosis, but levels can be normal during an acute attack.

Treatment:

  • Acute Attack- Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, corticosteroids for pain relief and inflammation control
  • Long-term Management- Lifestyle modifications (dietary changes, weight loss), medications to lower uric acid levels (allopurinol, febuxostat) to prevent further attacks.

 

Serum Uric Acid Level (Option A): While elevated serum uric acid levels are often seen in individuals with gout, they are not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis on their own.

Urine Uric Acid Levels (Option C): Urine uric acid levels are not typically used as a diagnostic test for gout. Although increased urinary excretion of uric acid may be observed in some cases of gout, it is not a specific or reliable marker for diagnosing the condition.

X-Ray Changes (Option D): X-ray changes, such as the presence of joint erosions or bone damage, may occur in advanced stages of gout or if there have been recurrent episodes of inflammation over time.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not classified as a micromineral?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calcium

Explanation:

  • Minerals are crucial for normal growth and body maintenance. Those required in amounts greater than 100 mg/day are called macrominerals or major elements, while those needed in smaller amounts (less than 100 mg/day) are known as microminerals, trace elements, or minor elements.
  • Calcium is classified as a macromineral (major element), not a micromineral. It is required by the body in large amounts (greater than 100 mg/day) for functions like bone formation, muscle contraction, and nerve transmission.

Macrominerals

Microminerals (Trace elements)
  1. Calcium (Option A)
  2. Magnesium
  3. Phosphorus
  4. Sodium
  5. Potassium
  6. Chloride
  7. Sulfur
  1. Iron
  2. Iodine (Option C ruled out)
  3. Copper (Option D ruled out)
  4. Manganese
  5. Zinc
  6. Molybdenum
  7. Selenium (Option B ruled out)
  8. Fluoride

questions.text: Identifying finding seen in TB knee is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reduction of joint space

Explanation:

  • Joint space reduction is the characteristic finding in TB knee.

T.B. of Knee Joint:

  • Third common site of skeletal TB infection
  • The initial lesion formation is seen in Synovium (Last in Hip joint)

Stages:

  • Synovitis:Boggy swelling and pain
  • Early Arthritis
  • Late Arthritis or Pathological dislocation: Triple deformity
  • Flexion of knee: It is due to Hamstring spasm
  • Posterior subluxation of tibia:Due to Laxity of capsule
  • Lateral shift of tibia: Due to spasm of ilio-tibial band
  • External rotation of tibia: Due to spasm of ilio-tibial band

Treatment:

  • ATT (2HRZS + 7HR)
  • Traction
  • For early arthritis, along with ATT, Synovectomy and Joint debridement/Joint clearance can opt.

For pathological dislocation:

  • ATT
  • Arthrodesis (fusing of joint)
  • Total knee replacement

questions.text: A 13-year-old with acute flaccid paralysis, the pediatric resident orders an RT-PCR on a CSF sample to identify the causative virus. Which of the following described the enzyme correctly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) RNA-dependent RNA polymerase

Explanation:

  • RNA-dependent DNA polymerase enzyme is used by RNA viruses (like poliovirus, which can cause acute flaccid paralysis) to replicate their RNA genome. In these viruses, RNA-dependent RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from an RNA template, which is critical for viral replication and transcription.
  • In RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction), the key enzyme responsible for converting RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) is RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, also known as reverse transcriptase. This enzyme synthesizes DNA from an RNA template, which is a critical step in RT-PCR to amplify RNA sequences for further analysis.

Incorrect Options:

DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (Option A): This enzyme synthesizes RNA from a DNA template but is not involved in RT-PCR.

RNA-dependent DNA polymerase (Option B): This term typically refers to reverse transcriptase, which synthesizes DNA from an RNA template, making it a potential candidate. However, it is more commonly described as reverse transcriptase rather than RNA-dependent DNA polymerase.

DNA-dependent DNA polymerase (Option C): This enzyme replicates DNA from a DNA template and does not play a role in RT-PCR.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child complaining of pain and swelling is suspected with supracondylar fracture of right hand (Undisplaced). X-ray of right elbow was not significant. What is the next best step in this case?

choices.text: Compare with X-ray of left hand
Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion)
Closed reduction with K wire fixation Cast

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion)

Explanation:

Supracondylar fractures of the humerus are common injuries in pediatric patients.

  • These fractures occur just above the elbow joint and can result in pain, swelling, and deformity of the affected arm.
  • The initial evaluation typically involves an X-ray of the elbow to assess the fracture.
  • In this case, if the X-ray of the right elbow is not significant(undisplaced).
  • Therefore, the next best step would be Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab(90 degree flexion).

Supracondylar fractures:

  • Mechanism of injury: Supracondylar fractures typically occur due to a fall onto an outstretched hand with an extended arm, causing a significant force to be transmitted to the distal humerus.
  • Common in children: Supracondylar fractures are more common in children, particularly between the ages of 5 and 7 years.
  • Presentation: Patients with a supracondylar fracture often present with pain, swelling, and deformity in the elbow region. There may also be limited range of motion and tenderness upon palpation.
  • Types: Supracondylar fractures can be classified into different types based on the degree of displacement and the involvement of surrounding structures.

The most commonly used classification system is the Gartland classification, which includes three types:

  • Type I: Non-displaced or minimally displaced fracture.
  • Type II: Fracture with significant displacement but with intact posterior cortex.
  • Type III: Fracture with complete displacement and loss of alignment.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old male presents to the clinic for a routine checkup. Except for the mild generalized weakness, he does not have any symptoms. On assessment following findings are noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the above findings?


	
		
			
			Parameters
			
			
			Values
			
		
		
			
			ALP
			
			
			Normal
			
		
		
			
			Calcium
			
			
			High
			
		
		
			
			Phosphate
			
			
			High
			
		
		
			
			PTH
			
			
			Normal
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin D toxicity

Explanation:

  • The combination of high calcium, high phosphate, and normal parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in this patient suggests an excessive intake or production of vitamin D leading to vitamin D toxicity.
  • Excessive intake or production of vitamin D can lead to increased absorption of calcium from the intestines, resulting in elevated levels of both calcium and phosphate.
  • The normal PTH level indicates that the parathyroid glands are functioning properly and not contributing to the elevated calcium and phosphate levels.

Aspect

Vitamin D Toxicity

Cause

Overactivity or enlargement of parathyroid glands.

Levels

Increased

Increased (primary) / Normal or slightly increased (secondary)

Phosphate

Levels

Elevated (hyperphosphatemia)

Normal or decreased

Clinical Features

Generalized weakness, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, constipation, confusion, excessive thirst, frequent urination.

Fatigue, weakness, bone pain, kidney stones, abdominal discomfort, psychiatric symptoms.

questions.text: The biochemical form of amyloid in hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aß2m

Explanation:

  • Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis is caused by the accumulation of β2-microglobulin (Aβ2M) in tissues, particularly in osteoarticular tissue, the gastrointestinal tract, and the circulatory system.
  • β2-microglobulin is a small protein that accumulates in the blood during long-term hemodialysis, as it is not easily filtered by conventional dialysis membranes.
  • Over time, this leads to the formation of amyloid deposits, which can cause joint pain, stiffness, and other complications in patients undergoing long-term dialysis.
