questions.text: Three point bony relationship has a diagnostic value in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Elbow Fracture

Explanation:

  • The three-point bony relationship refers to the alignment of three specific landmarks in the elbow joint: the capitellum, the radial head, and the olecranon process. When these three points are aligned properly, it indicates that the elbow joint is in its normal anatomical position.
  • In the context of elbow fractures, assessing the three-point bony relationship is crucial in determining the presence of a fracture and evaluating its displacement or dislocation.
  • Any disruption in the alignment of these three points may indicate a fracture or joint injury.

Elbow Fractures:

Treatment options for elbow fractures depend on various factors, including the type and severity of the fracture, patient age, and overall health.

Treatment may involve:

  • Nonsurgical Treatment: Some fractures can be managed with immobilization, such as casting or splinting, followed by a period of rest and rehabilitation.
  • Surgical Treatment: Certain fractures may require surgical intervention, such as open reduction (realignment of the fractured bones) and internal fixation (use of screws, plates, or rods to hold the bones in place).
  • Rehabilitation: After treatment, rehabilitation plays a crucial role in the recovery process. Physical therapy and exercises help restore strength, range of motion, and function to the elbow joint.

questions.text: A 25 year old man fell down while running. He tried to sustain the fall on his elbow resulting in the injury shown below.What will be the appropriate management of the following fracture?

choices.text: Close reduction with Tension band wiring
Immobilization of elbow, Above elbow plaster slab with 30 degree flexion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Immobilization of elbow, Above elbow plaster slab with 30 degree flexion.

Explanation:

  • Immobilization of the elbow, Above the elbow plaster slab with 30-degree flexion is for type 1 olecranon fracture.
  • This is usually seen in adults.
  • It results from a direct injury, as in a fall onto the point of the elbow.
  • Pathoanatomy - The proximal fragment may be pulled proximally by the attached triceps muscle, thus creating a gap at the fracture site.

The fracture may be one of the three types:

  • Type I: Crack without displacement of fragments.
  • Type Il : Clean break with separation of fragments.
  • Type III: Comminuted fracture.

Treatment: It depends upon the type of fracture:

  • Type l: A crack without displacement is treated by immobilising the elbow in an above-elbow plaster slab in 30 degree of flexion After 3 weeks the plaster is removed and elbow exercises begun.
  • Type II: A clean break with separation of the fragments is treated by open reduction and internal fixation using technique of/tension-band wiring is not possible to keep the fragments together in the plaster alone because of the constant pull exerted by the triceps.
  • Type III: A comminuted fracture, if not separated, is treated in a plaster: slab as in type-1, but if the fragments are separated/tension-band wiring excision of the fragments may be required.With improvement in methods of internal fixation, fracture of the olecranon, being an intra-articular fracture is treated by internal fixator wherever possible. This helps in early mobilization of elbow, and hence achieving good range of movement.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in patients with acute intermittent porphyria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thiopentone

Explanation:

  • Thiopentone is contraindicated in patients with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). AIP is a disorder of heme biosynthesis, and thiopentone, a barbiturate used for induction of anesthesia, can trigger an acute attack of porphyria. It induces the synthesis of porphyrin precursors, exacerbating the disease and leading to symptoms such as abdominal pain, neuropathy, and mental changes.

Incorrect Options:

Propofol (option B) is considered safe for use in patients with acute intermittent porphyria. It does not induce the production of porphyrin precursors and is a commonly used anesthetic agent in these patients.

Etomidate (option C) is another anesthetic agent that is generally safe for use in patients with acute intermittent porphyria. It does not affect the heme pathway and is often preferred in situations where other agents might be contraindicated.

Ketamine (option D) can be used in patients with acute intermittent porphyria. It does not interfere with the porphyrin biosynthesis pathway and is often used in situations where general anesthesia is required, especially in cases of trauma or when other agents are contraindicated.

questions.text: The diagnosis of the given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scapho Lunate Instability

Explanation:

Scapholunate instability refers to an abnormal movement or separation of the scaphoid and lunate bones, which are two of the carpal bones in the wrist.

  • This instability can be caused by injury or ligamentous damage, leading to improper alignment and movement of these bones.
  • Mechanism of Injury- Fall on an outstretched hand- Repetitive wrist trauma or overuse.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Wrist pain or tenderness
  • Swelling or instability in the wrist
  • Signs of chronic instability may include a dinner fork deformity or widening of the scapholunate joint

Physical Examination:

  • Scaphoid shift test: Palpable clunk or abnormal movement of the scaphoid bone with ulnar deviation and wrist flexion
  • Watson test: Painful clunk or subluxation of the scaphoid during radial or ulnar deviation of the wrist
  • Terry Thomas sign: Increased scapholunate space on radiographic imaging, indicating abnormal alignment between the scaphoid and lunate bones

Radiographic Evaluation:

  • X-rays: Routine radiographs may reveal widening of the scapholunate joint space (>3mm) on a lateral view (Terry Thomas sign).

questions.text:
Football player gets blow to the outer knee during match.Which structure is most commonly associated with this type of injury?

Lateral lemniscus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Medial collateral ligament

Explanation:

  • The MCL is a ligament located on the inner side of the knee joint that helps stabilize the knee against excessive sideways or valgus stress.
  • It connects the femur (thigh bone) to the tibia (shin bone) and plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the knee joint.

 

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) (Option A): While the ACL is another important ligament in the knee, it is not directly associated with MCL injuries. The ACL is located inside the knee joint and is responsible for controlling rotational and anterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur.

Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) (Option C): The PCL is also an internal ligament of the knee, but it is not commonly associated with MCL injuries. The PCL helps stabilize the knee against posterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur.

Lateral meniscus (Option D): The lateral meniscus is the counterpart of the medial meniscus and is located on the outer side of the knee joint. It is not directly associated with MCL injuries. However, it can be injured independently or in conjunction with other knee injuries.

questions.text: Avascular necrosis of the femur head is due to which of the following artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Medial Circumflex Femoral Artery

Explanation:

Medial Circumflex Femoral Artery (MCFA): The MCFA is a branch of the deep femoral artery and provides the primary blood supply to the femoral head.

  • Disruption or occlusion of this artery can lead to compromised blood flow to the femoral head, resulting in avascular necrosis.
  • The diagnosis and management of avascular necrosis of the femoral head typically involve a combination of clinical evaluation, imaging studies (such as X-rays, MRI, or bone scans),
  • Treatment options ranging from conservative measures to surgical interventions, depending on the severity and stage of the condition.

questions.text: What is this device called?

choices.text: Endotracheal tubes equipped with bronchial blockers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Double-lumen endotracheal tube

Explanation:

  • A double-lumen endotracheal tube is designed with two separate lumens or channels. It allows independent ventilation of each lung during thoracic surgeries or procedures requiring lung isolation. The tube has one lumen that enters the trachea and provides ventilation to one lung, while the other lumen enters the bronchus of the opposite lung, allowing selective lung collapse and ventilation control.

Armored endotracheal tube (Option A): An armored endotracheal tube is a specialized type of endotracheal tube that has an internal wire coil or reinforcement. This provides rigidity and prevents kinking or collapse of the tube, ensuring a patent airway. Armored tubes are typically used in situations where there is a risk of tube compression or obstruction, such as during head and neck surgery.

 

 

Ring-Adair-Elwin (RAE) tube (Option C): The Ring-Adair-Elwin tube is a type of cuffed endotracheal tube that has a preformed curvature near the distal end. This curved design helps to facilitate placement and positioning of the tube within the trachea. RAE tubes are commonly used in anesthesia and critical care settings.


Endotracheal tubes equipped with bronchial blockers (Option D): These are endotracheal tubes that have an additional component called a bronchial blocker. A bronchial blocker is a small balloon-tipped catheter that can be inserted through the endotracheal tube and into one of the main bronchi. It is used to selectively block the airflow to one lung while allowing ventilation of the other lung. This technique is employed for lung isolation during thoracic surgeries or procedures.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 40-year-old male patient who was admitted to the ICU three days ago due to breathing difficulty and is currently experiencing restlessness and widespread tremors? The patient has reported seeing insects crawling on his bed and body and has had one seizure, which was successfully managed with lorazepam. Further investigation reveals that the patient is a chronic alcoholic.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Delirium tremens.

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms, including restlessness, tremors, tactile hallucinations (seeing insects crawling), a seizure, and a history of chronic alcoholism, strongly indicate delirium tremens (DT).
  • It typically occurs 48–72 hours after cessation or reduction of alcohol use.
  • It is a severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome characterised by tremors, agitation, confusion, and hallucinations.
  • It is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment.

Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

ICU psychosis (Option A) is a mental health condition that can develop in ICU patients due to stress, sedatives, and other medications. Symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, and agitation. Unlike ICU psychosis, delirium tremens (DTs) result from alcohol withdrawal.

Alcohol Intoxication (Option B): This diagnosis is unlikely since the patient has been sober for three days. Alcohol intoxication results from excessive alcohol consumption and presents with symptoms such as slurred speech, impaired coordination, confusion, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness or even death. The patient's current symptoms are more consistent with alcohol withdrawal rather than intoxication.

Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis (Option C) is a neurological disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It presents with symptoms such as confusion, memory loss, and ataxia. Wernicke's encephalopathy represents the acute phase, while Korsakoff's syndrome is the chronic stage. The disorder's main features are problems in acquiring new information or establishing new memories and in retrieving previous memories.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteosarcoma

Explanation:

Osteosarcoma is the most common type of cancer occurring in long bones and it's common amongst children in 2nd decade.

  • It is a metaphyseal tumor, usually located at Distal end of femur. It has a bimodal presentation and is the most radioresistant tumor
  • Characteristics: Codman triangle as seen in image (from elevation of periosteum) or sunburst pattern on x-ray (think of an osteocod [bone fish] swimming in the sun).
  • Treatment; Neoadjuvent chemotherapy followed by surgery/ limb ablation.

 

Ewing Sarcoma (Option B): Although Ewing sarcoma is also a bone-mediated tumor, it commonly affects pelvis, ribs, spine and long bones as opposed to Osteosarcoma which only affects the long bones of the arms and legs and the x-ray image is of the femur.

 

Osteiod Osteoma (Option C): In case of Osteiod Osteoma the x-ray imaging shows presence of nidus surrounded by sclerosis, which is not indicating the x-ray image.

 

GCT (Option D): Giant Cell Tumors are typically found at the ends of the long bones and extend into the epiphysis to surface of the joint, whereas the images show a tumor which is not located at the end of the bone.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Laryngeal mask airway

Explanation:

A laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device used to secure the airway in situations requiring anaesthesia or emergency management. It consists of:

  • A tube connected to an inflatable mask that is placed over the laryngeal inlet.
  • A cuff that is inflated to create a seal around the larynx.

It is commonly used in:

  • Daycare surgeries.
  • Scenarios requiring less invasive airway management than an endotracheal tube.
  • Patients where bag-mask ventilation is challenging.

Guedel airway (option A): This is an oropharyngeal airway device used to keep the tongue from obstructing the airway. It looks like a rigid, curved plastic or rubber tube.

Endotracheal tube (option C): This is a flexible tube inserted into the trachea through the mouth or nose to provide ventilation. It does not have an inflatable cuff like the LMA shown in the image.

Nasogastric tube (option D): This is a thin, flexible tube used for feeding or suctioning gastric contents, inserted through the nose and extending into the stomach.

questions.text: Postmenopausal woman slipped and fell down on an outstretched hand in the washroom. X-ray of her distal forearm is given below. Diagnose the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Colle's Fracture

Explanation:

  • Postmenopausal women are prone to develop osteoporosis due to decreased secretion of estrogen from ovaries.
  • Women suffering from osteoporosis are prone to Colles fracture, which is a type of wrist fracture.
  • This type of fracture usually happens after falling on an outstretched hand.
  • The given x-ray shows fracture of the distal end of radius at cortico- cancellous junction.

Fracture Name

Characteristic Findings

Sites Involved

Special History

Colles

Fracture

Dorsal displacement of the distal radius.

Distal radius

Falling on an outstretched hand

Fracture

Volar displacement of the distal radius.

Distal radius

Falling on a flexed wrist

Monteggia

Fracture

Proximal ulnar shaft fracture with radial head dislocation.

Proximal ulna, radial head

Direct blow to the ulna or forearm

Galeazzi

Fracture

Distal radial shaft fracture with distal radioulnar joint dislocation.

Distal radius, radioulnar joint

Fall on an outstretched hand with an ulnar deviation

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 35-year-old female patient presenting to the psychiatric outpatient department with symptoms of reduced sleep, excessive elation, and increased talkativeness lasting for one month? The patient is exhibiting disruptive behaviour by shouting at the nurses and is difficult to control. She also reports irritability and difficulty in staying focused. There is no known medical history for this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Haloperidol

Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with symptoms of an acute manic episode, which is a feature of bipolar disorder.
  • Symptoms such as excessive elation, reduced sleep, irritability, increased talkativeness, and disruptive behaviour are characteristic of mania.
  • In this scenario, haloperidol, a typical antipsychotic, is the most appropriate treatment that works by blocking dopamine D2 receptors, which helps to control the agitation, aggression, and psychotic features associated with mania. t provides rapid symptom relief and is effective in managing acute manic episodes.

Incorrect Options:

Lithium (Option A) is a mood stabiliser primarily used for long-term management of bipolar disorder. While it is effective in preventing manic and depressive episodes, it is not suitable for acute management due to its delayed onset of action. It also requires regular serum level monitoring to avoid toxicity, making it less ideal for immediate symptom relief in this case.

Lorazepam (Option B) is a benzodiazepine used to manage anxiety and agitation but does not directly treat the underlying symptoms of mania. While it may help calm the patient temporarily, it is not effective for controlling the psychotic or manic symptoms, such as excessive energy and impulsivity, that are present in this case.

Carbamazepine (Option C) is a mood stabiliser and anticonvulsant used to treat acute manic and mixed episodes of bipolar disorder. However, its onset of action is slower compared to antipsychotics like haloperidol. It is more commonly used for long-term management and prevention rather than for rapid symptom control in acute mania, making it a less suitable option in this case.

questions.text: Identify the shown image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Patella Tendon Bearing Brace.

Explanation:

  • A patella tendon bearing brace, also known as a patellar tendon brace or patellar tendon strap, is a specialized brace designed to provide targeted support and compression to the patellar tendon.
  • It is commonly used in conditions such as patellar tendonitis or jumper's knee, where there is pain or inflammation in the patellar tendon.

Ankle Knee Stabilizer (Option A): Type of brace or support that provides stability to both the ankle and knee joints. It is commonly used in cases of ligament injuries or instability in these joints.

 

Thomas Splint (Option C): Specific type of splint used for immobilization and stabilization of the femur or thigh bone. It is commonly used in cases of fractures or dislocations of the femur.

questions.text: What is the needle shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tuohy needle

Explanation:

The Tuohy needle is characterised by its curved, blunt tip, which is specifically designed to guide catheters into the epidural space for procedures such as:

  • Epidural anaesthesia.
  • Pain management (e.g., labour analgesia).

Key features of the Tuohy needle:

  • Blunt curved tip: Minimises the risk of puncturing the dura.
  • Epidural markings: Assist in depth estimation during insertion.
  • Side hole (lateral aperture): Allows the passage of an epidural catheter.

Incorrect Options:

Whitacre needle (option A): This is a pencil-point needle used for spinal anaesthesia. It has a non-cutting tip to reduce the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

Sprotte needle (option B): Another pencil-point needle designed for spinal anaesthesia with a longer side hole for smooth cerebrospinal fluid flow.

Quincke-Babcock needle (option D): A cutting-tip needle used for spinal anaesthesia. It creates a sharp puncture, which increases the risk of post-dural puncture headache compared to pencil-point needles.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl suspects that the college principal is making a conspiracy against her and is planning to fail her in the upcoming exam. She feels that other teachers have also joined the conspiracy and students are helping them too. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Delusion of persecution

Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with delusions of persecution, where she believes that others are conspiring against her, which is a key characteristic of this type of delusion.
  • Delusions of persecution involve the belief that one is being targeted, harmed, or harassed by others, often without any evidence.
  • In this case, the student believes that the principal, teachers, and other students are part of a conspiracy to harm her academically.

Types of delusions

Delusion

Description

Delusion of Persecution
  • Belief of being harassed, persecuted, or mistreated by others.
  • Most common type of delusion. (Option C)

Delusion of Reference
  • The belief that surrounding people are talking about them or spying on them. It is a form of delusion of persecution. (Option D ruled out)

Delusion of Grandiosity
  • Exaggerated belief in one's own importance, power, or identity.
  • Belief in being a significant figure who can help others or may claim to hear the voices of God, which reinforces their belief in their elevated status.
  • Seen in mania (as Mood-congruent delusion)

Nihilistic Delusion
  • Belief that the body/part of body/world or everything related to it has ceased to exist.
  • Also known as the delusion of negation.
  • seen in depression (most commonly) as (Mood-congruent delusion)
  • Cotard syndrome: Patient with depression having delusions of nihilism (specifically related to parts of the body).

Delusion of guilt
  • The patient firmly believes that he is a sinner, though not having committed any sin.
  • Seen in depression (as Mood-congruent delusion)

Delusion of Poverty
  • The patient is convinced that he is poor and in a state of destitution, although he is not.

Delusion of enormity
  • The patient believes that their action can produce catastrophe.
  • Eg, the patient refuses to urinate because he believes that it may flood the world.

Delusion of Infidelity
  • The belief that one's partner is unfaithful.
  • Associated factor: prolonged alcohol use
  • Also known as Othello syndrome/Morbid jealousy

De clerambault’s syndrome/ Erotomania
  • The patient (often a single woman) believes that a person of higher status is in love with her.
  • May be a feature of paranoid schizophrenia.

Hypochondriacal delusion/Delusion of ill health
  • Characteristically seen in depression, it may also be seen in schizophrenia.

Various forms of Hypochondriacal delusion:

Delusion of Infestation/ Parasitosis/ Ekbom syndrome:

  • The patient falsely believes that he is infested with insects,he does not experience sensation.
  • It affects both men and women equally and becomes more common with age.
  • ‘Empty matchbox sign’ may be present (when the patient attempts to catch the insect to show it to the clinician).

Delusional dysmorphophobia:

  • The patient believes that his body/part of his body is deformed and wants it to be corrected.

Delusional halitosis:

  • The belief that the patient has a malodorous body odour.

Incorrect Options:

Thought insertion (Option A) is a type of delusion where a person believes that someone else is forcing thoughts into their mind. The individual may feel that their thoughts are not their own and are being controlled by an external force. This symptom is commonly associated with schizophrenia but can also occur in other medical and psychiatric conditions.

Delusion of control (Option B) is characterized by the belief that an external force or agency is controlling or manipulating one's thoughts, actions, or body. The individual may feel as though they are not in control of their own behaviour and are being compelled to act against their will. This symptom is often seen in schizophrenia.

questions.text: Which surgery should be avoided in a patient with a fibroma and moderate to severe cardiac disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Laparoscopic hysterectomy

Explanation:

Laparoscopic hysterectomy should be avoided in patients with moderate to severe cardiac disease due to the physiological changes caused by pneumoperitoneum (insufflation of the abdomen with carbon dioxide), including:

  1. Increased intra-abdominal pressure:
    • Can lead to decreased venous return, increased afterload, and reduced cardiac output, which are particularly dangerous for patients with compromised cardiac function.
  2. Carbon dioxide absorption:
    • Can cause hypercapnia, leading to respiratory acidosis and increased cardiac workload.
  3. Positioning during surgery:
    • Trendelenburg position (head-down tilt) commonly used in laparoscopic surgeries can exacerbate hemodynamic instability.

Incorrect Options:

Abdominal hysterectomy (option B): Although it is more invasive, it avoids the hemodynamic complications of pneumoperitoneum and is relatively safer for patients with cardiac disease.

Total hysterectomy (option C): This term refers to the removal of the uterus and cervix and can be performed abdominally or vaginally. The abdominal approach is safer than laparoscopic surgery in patients with cardiac disease.

Subtotal hysterectomy (option D): This involves removing the uterus while leaving the cervix intact and can also be performed abdominally, which is safer for cardiac patients.

questions.text: Preoperative assessment of oral cavity for endotracheal intubation in an adult is done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mallampatti score

Explanation:

  • This score is used to evaluate the oral cavity preoperatively to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation. It is based on visualisation of the oropharyngeal structures (soft palate, uvula, and tonsillar pillars) when the patient opens their mouth widely without phonating. It is categorised into four classes, with higher classes indicating a more difficult airway. It is the standard tool for assessing oral cavity and airway accessibility.

Incorrect Options:

Cormack-Lehane (option B): This grading system evaluates the laryngeal view during direct laryngoscopy, not during the preoperative oral cavity assessment. It is useful for classifying intubation difficulty once the laryngoscope is in place.

ASA grading (option C): The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) grading assesses a patient’s physical status to estimate perioperative risk, not specifically for airway assessment.

AHA grading (option D): This grading does not exist for airway or oral cavity assessment and is irrelevant in this context.

questions.text: The parents of a 13-year-old boy have sought the assistance of a child psychiatrist due to their concerns. They have observed that the child frequently engages in dishonesty both at home and in school, displays disruptive behaviour towards his teacher, often intimidates younger children, and has been caught stealing money multiple times. What is the probable diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Conduct disorder.

Explanation:

Disorder

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)

Conduct Disorder

Definition

The persistent pattern of negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behaviour toward authority figures.

(Option A ruled out)

A persistent pattern of behaviour involving aggression, violating others' rights, and disregarding social norms.

(Option B)

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5)

  • Duration: ≥6 months.

  • Symptoms (≥4):

    • Losing temper.

    • Easily annoyed/sensitive.

    • Angry/resentful.

    • Argues with authority figures.

    • Refuses requests/rules.

    • Deliberately annoys others.

    • Blames others for their own mistakes/behaviors.

    • Spiteful/vindictive (at least 2x in 6 months).

    • No severely aggressive or delinquent behaviours.

  • Duration: ≥12 months, with 1 symptom present in the last 6 months.

  • Symptoms (≥3):

    • Physical aggression or threats.

    • Destruction of property.

    • Deceitfulness or theft.

    • Harming animals.

    • Violation of rules (e.g., truancy, running away).

Types (DSM-5)

  • Angry/Irritable Mood: Frequent temper loss, persistent irritability.

  • Argumentative/Defiant Behavior: Argues, refuses to comply, blames others.

  • Vindictiveness: Spiteful/vindictive actions ≥2x in 6 months.

  • Childhood-onset: Symptoms before age 10.

  • Adolescent-Onset: Symptoms after age 10.

  • Unspecified-Onset: Age of onset unknown

Severity Specifiers

  • Mild: Symptoms in 1 setting.

  • Moderate: Symptoms in 2 settings.

  • Severe: Symptoms in ≥3 settings.

  • Mild: Few conduct problems, minor harm.

  • Moderate: Intermediate symptoms.

  • Severe: Many symptoms, significant harm caused.

Treatment

  • Family Interventions: Parent training in child management, reinforcing positive behaviour.

  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Parents are taught to discourage the child's oppositional behaviour by not paying much attention to it.

  • Parenting Techniques: Focus on reducing harsh punishment and increasing positive interactions.

  • Psychosocial Interventions: Early intervention, CBT, school-based programs.

  • Pharmacologic Interventions: Antipsychotics (risperidone, quetiapine), SSRIs for impulsivity/irritability, sodium valproate.

Antisocial personality disorder (Option C) is diagnosed in adults (18 years and older), making it inappropriate to diagnose in a 13-year-old. While the child’s behaviour may resemble ASPD, the diagnosis requires a history of symptoms extending into adulthood.

Disruptive mood dysregulation (Option D) primarily involves severe temper outbursts and a consistently irritable mood, not the antisocial behaviours observed here. The child’s actions, such as stealing and bullying, suggest Conduct Disorder rather than mood regulation issues.

questions.text: What should be the next course of action for a 31-year-old woman who recently went through a divorce and is currently experiencing symptoms such as palpitations, sweating, chest heaviness, and pain? She has had several similar episodes over the past few weeks, but her blood test results, ECG, and chest X-ray show no abnormalities.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Use benzodiazepines for symptom relief

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, such as palpitations, sweating, chest heaviness, and pain, suggest a panic attack, with no abnormalities in blood tests, ECG, and chest X-ray ruling out organic causes.
  • Benzodiazepines are the drug of choice for acute relief of panic attacks, providing rapid symptom control by enhancing GABA activity in the brain.
  • For long-term management, SSRIs and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) are recommended.

Treatment of Panic attack:

Pharmacological, psychological, and combined treatments.

  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Drug of choice – Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.
    • Other first-line: Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) venlafaxine.
    • Second-line: Tricyclic antidepressants, MAOIs
    • Other Psychotropics - Agomelatine, Buspirone, Mirtazapine.
    • Benzodiazepines: Short-term use as an adjunct to SSRIs.
    • Acute phase – Benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam & Clonazepam.
  • Psychosocial therapies:
    • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
    • Interpersonal therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Admit for detailed investigations (Option A): It is not required as the investigations in the past showed no abnormality.

Start counselling sessions (Option B): Counselling sessions are started only once the panic attack is under control.

Use beta-blockers (Option C): They are more so used in social anxiety and do not play a significant role in panic attacks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of recurrent headaches presented for further evaluation. On further workup, haemoglobin and total WBC count were normal, while an elevated platelet count was seen. Bone marrow aspiration showed increased megakaryocytes and a JAK2 mutation. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Essential thrombocytosis

Explanation:

  • The high platelet count and JAK 2 mutation with increased megakaryocytes in the bone marrow aspiration point to the diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia.

Essential Thrombocythemia (ET)

  • This is a type of myeloproliferative neoplasm.

Aetiology:

  • Caused by mutations in JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes, known as "driver mutations."
  • Other mutations associated: SH2B3, TP53, IDH2, 20q-, etc.

Pathophysiology:

  • JAK2V617F mutation (valine to phenylalanine) activates hematopoietic cytokine receptors, leading to myeloproliferation.
  • CALR mutations result in abnormal protein, affecting cellular proliferation and differentiation.
  • MPL mutations affect thrombopoietin receptor function, increasing thrombocytosis risk.
  • Extreme thrombocytosis (>1 million platelets) can lead to bleeding episodes due to acquired von Willebrand disease.

Symptoms & Risks:

  • Characterized by high platelet count and megakaryocytic hyperplasia in bone marrow.
  • Risks include thrombosis, haemorrhage, and potential progression to myelofibrosis or leukemic transformation.

Diagnosis:

  • Platelet count >450,000 and presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation.
  • Bone marrow examination may show megakaryocytic hyperplasia.

Management:

  • Cytoreduction may be necessary to manage thrombocytosis and prevent complications like thrombosis.
  • Regular monitoring of platelet count and mutation status is key for management.

 

Polycythemia vera (Option A) is a myeloproliferative disorder and patients have uncontrolled RBC production. These patients may have raised WBC and platelets due to stimulation of megakaryocyte and myeloid lineages but the most definite feature is the elevated RBC mass.

Primary myelofibrosis (Option C): This is a myeloproliferative neoplasm leading to the deposition of fibrous connective tissue in the bone marrow resulting in bone marrow failure.

Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (Option D): Characterized by the presence of the BCR-ABL1 gene, it is a type of myeloproliferative disorder mainly involving the overproduction of granulocytes. It is defined by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t(9;22)(q34;q11.2)).

questions.text: The colour of the nitrous oxide cylinder is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Blue

Explanation:

  • Nitrous oxide cylinders are color-coded blue.

Gasses and their PIN Indices:

Gas

Cylinder color

PIN Index system

Air

Black body with black & white shoulder

1,5

Oxygen

Black body with white shoulder

2,5

N2O

Blue

3,5

Carbon dioxide

Grey  

1,6 (> 7.5%) ; 2,6 (< 7.5%)

Entonox

Blue body with white shoulders

7

Cyclopropane

Orange

3,6

 

Entonox:

Composition:
  • 50% N2O + 50% O2
Cylinder color:
  • Blue body with white shoulders
PIN Index:
  • 7
Uses:
  • Only provides analgesia
  • Used for short-term pain relief such as labor analgesia/dental procedures
Disadvantage:
  • No anesthesia effect

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 35-year-old woman who experiences heightened anxiety and recurrent thoughts about her hands being contaminated, leading her to frequently wash her hands? Despite finding these thoughts distressing, she is unable to resist them, and attempting to refrain from washing only worsens her anxiety.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with repetitive behaviour of thoughts of washing her hands and doubts of them being contaminated, which are features of Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.

Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions.
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

 

Major symptom patterns:

Symptom Pattern

Description

Contamination/Cleansing

Obsession with contamination, followed by washing/avoidance.

Pathological Doubt/Checking

Obsession with doubt, followed by compulsive checking.

Intrusive/Forbidden Thoughts

Intrusive thoughts of aggression or sexual acts, without compulsion.

Symmetry/Ordering

Need for symmetry or precision, leading to compulsive slowness.

Other Symptoms

Religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

 

Treatment

Description

Pharmacotherapy

First line: SSRIs (preferred), Clomipramine. Treatment for 1-2 years.

Augmenting agents: Antipsychotics (Risperidone, Aripiprazole), Memantine, Riluzole, Ketamine, Lamotrigine, N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Psychotherapy

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Exposure and response prevention (ERP).

Other therapies: Desensitization, Thought-stopping, Flooding, Aversive conditioning, Psychodynamic psychotherapy, and Family therapy.

CBT is preferred in younger patients. Combination of CBT and pharmacotherapy is useful.

Somatic Therapies

Anterior cingulotomy, Capsulotomy, Deep brain stimulation with electrodes.

Incorrect Options:

Phobia (Option A) involves a morbid and irrational fear with acute anxiety and panic-like symptoms.

Forced thinking (Option B) is seen in the pre-ictal stage and is relieved after a seizure.

Generalized anxiety disorder (Option D) involves continuous, free-floating anxiety and is not situation-dependent.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 37-year-old man who experienced symptoms after a sudden financial loss? He reported feeling fearful of harm, having sleep and appetite disturbances, and hearing abusive voices. These symptoms lasted for about a week. The patient has no relevant medical history, drug abuse history, or past medical history.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Brief psychotic episode

Explanation:

  • Acute psychotic disorder is characterised by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganised speech, or grossly disorganised or catatonic behaviour that lasts for < 1 month (ICD 11) or < 6 months (DSM 5).
  • DSM-5 classifies further:
    • Brief Psychotic disorder: Symptoms < 1 month
    • Schizophreniform disorder: Symptoms > 1 month- < 6 month
  • It is an acute condition that is common in the 20s to 30s, especially in women comparatively and in lower socio-economic populations.

Disorder

ICD-11 Criteria

DSM-5 Criteria

Schizoaffective Disorder
(Option D ruled out)

Symptoms of both schizophrenia and mood disorders for

≥ 1 month

Psychotic symptoms without mood disturbances for ≥ 2 weeks.

Delusional Disorder

 

Delusions present for more than three months.

Delusions are present for at least one month.

Schizophrenia

(Option A ruled out)

Two or more symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) present for ≥ one month

Two or more symptoms present for ≥ six months

Schizophrenia requires two or more symptoms, with at least one from delusions, hallucinations, thought disorder, or distortion of self-experience. Additional symptoms include negative symptoms, disorganised behaviour, or psychomotor disturbances.

Schizophreniform Disorder (Option B). According to DSM, the duration of symptoms must be more than one month but less than 6 months.

questions.text: What is a macrovascular complication that develops in the advanced stages of diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coronary artery disease

Explanation:

  • The macrovascular complication that develops in the advanced stages of diabetes is coronary artery disease.

Macrovascular Complications of Diabetes Mellitus

  • Major causes of morbidity and mortality in type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
  • Involves large blood vessels, leading to:
    • Coronary circulation: Myocardial ischaemia/infarction.
    • Cerebral circulation: Transient ischaemic attack, stroke.
    • Peripheral circulation: Claudication, ischaemia.

Key Points:

  • Excess mortality: Mainly due to myocardial infarction and stroke.
  • Accelerated atherosclerosis: Earlier onset and more severe in diabetics.
  • Amplified risk factors: Smoking, hypertension, dyslipidemia.
  • Metabolic syndrome: Common in type 2 diabetes, with additional cardiovascular risk factors due to insulin resistance. Criteria for metabolic syndrome are
    • Hypertension
    • High Fasting glucose
    • Elevated TG
    • Low HDL
    • Central obesity

Statistics:

Condition

Increased Rate in Diabetics

Cardiovascular death

1.7 times higher

Myocardial infarction

1.8 times greater

Stroke hospitalisation

1.5 times higher

Non-traumatic amputations

60% occur in diabetics

First cardiovascular event (type 1)

3 times higher in women, 2.3 times higher in men

Mechanisms linking hyperglycemia to macrovascular disease:

  • Increased vascular permeability: Due to high blood glucose.
  • Lipoprotein deposition: Hyperinsulinemia and hypertension increase atherogenic lipoprotein deposits in large vessels.

Risk Management:

  • Glycaemic control: Reduces both microvascular and macrovascular complications.
  • Blood pressure control: ACE inhibitors/ARBs are protective.
  • Dyslipidemia management: Statins are recommended to lower cardiovascular risks.
  • Lifestyle modifications: Smoking cessation, weight management, and regular physical activity are crucial.

Diabetic Microvascular Complications

  • Diabetic microangiopathy affects small blood vessels in diabetes, leading to significant morbidity and mortality.
  • Key clinical syndromes include:
    • Diabetic retinopathy (Option D)
    • Diabetic nephropathy (Option C)
    • Diabetic neuropathy

Foot ulcer (Option B) is a microvascular complication of diabetes.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause for a 22-year-old man who has a high-grade fever, a purpuric rash, and a CSF sample showing gram-negative diplococci?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neisseria meningitidis

Explanation:

The above image is that of a purpuric rash which is seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitides.

  • Neisseria meningitidis is a gram negative diplococci.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia presents with a very high fever and hemorrhagic rash.

Acute Bacterial Meningitis

  • Definition: Acute purulent infection in the subarachnoid space (SAS) leading to CNS inflammation.
  • Causes:
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes.
    • Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.
  • Presentation: Can be acute and fulminant or subacute, with the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Fever
    • Headache
    • Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck)

Clinical features

Description

Consciousness

Decreased level of consciousness occurs in >75% of cases, ranging from lethargy to coma.

Kernig's Sign

Positive when passive extension of the knee elicits pain; indicative of meningeal irritation.

Brudzinski's Sign

Positive when passive flexion of the neck results in spontaneous flexion of the hips and knees; also indicative of meningeal irritation.

Pupils

May present as dilated and poorly reactive due to increased intracranial pressure (ICP).

Posturing

Possible decerebrate posturing as a sign of severe CNS dysfunction.

Signs of Increased ICP

Includes elevated CSF opening pressure (>180 mmH2O), papilledema, and potential cerebral herniation (1–8% incidence).

Additional Symptoms

Nausea, vomiting, photophobia; seizures in 15–40% (focal or generalized).

Meningococcemia Rash

Erythematous maculopapular rash that quickly becomes petechial, commonly on the trunk and lower extremities.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option B) is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C) is a gram-positive, spherical bacteria.

E. Coli (Option D) is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria.

questions.text: Stain used to demonstrate fungal elements are?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Methenamine silver

Explanation:

  • Methenamine silver stain is commonly used to demonstrate fungal elements in tissue samples. This stain binds to the cell wall of fungi and highlights the fungal structures, allowing them to be clearly visualized under the microscope. It is particularly useful in detecting fungal infections in tissues, as it stains the fungi in a black color against a light background, making identification easier.

Detection Methods for Fungi:

Method

Description

Use

Direct Microscopic Examination

KOH Preparation

Dissolves keratin in clinical specimens (e.g., skin scrapings, nail clippings) to visualise fungal elements.

Diagnosing dermatophyte infections

Calcofluor White Staining

Enhances fungal visibility by binding to chitin in cell walls, causing them to fluoresce under UV light.

Observing fungal morphology

Gram Stain

Traditionally for bacterial identification; also useful for yeasts, which typically stain Gram-positive (purple).

Detecting certain fungi

India Ink Preparation

Negative staining method for encapsulated yeasts (e.g., Cryptococcus neoformans), revealing a clear halo around cells.

Identifying encapsulated yeasts

Methenamine Silver and PAS Staining

Histochemical techniques that stain fungi black (methenamine) or magenta (PAS) in tissue sections.

Highlighting fungi in tissues

Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB) Mount

Enhances contrast in teased fungal colonies for morphological observation.

Microscopic examination of fungi

Serology

Antibody Detection

Identifies antibodies produced by the host in response to fungi using methods like ELISA.

Tracking immune response to fungal infections

Antigen Detection

Detects fungal antigens in body fluids using techniques such as latex agglutination tests.

Identifying fungal presence in the body

Skin Tests

Delayed-Type Hypersensitivity (DTH)

Assesses previous exposure to fungi through localised reactions to injected antigens.

Evaluating past fungal exposure

Newer Rapid Diagnostic Tests

Nucleic Acid Hybridisation

Uses labelled DNA probes for rapid fungal DNA detection in clinical samples.

Quick identification of fungal pathogens

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Amplifies specific fungal DNA sequences, enabling early diagnosis even with low fungal loads.

Early detection of fungal infections

 

Acid fast stain (Option A): This is used primarily for Mycobacterium species (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis), not fungi. The acid-fast stain highlights acid-fast bacilli by coloring them red, but it is not useful for fungal elements.

Gabbet's stain (Option B): This is not a commonly used stain for fungi. It is a variant of Gram staining, primarily used for bacterial identification, not for fungi.

Leifson & Ryu's stain (Option D): This is a staining method for bacteria, especially to highlight flagella in bacterial samples, and it is not used to stain fungal elements.

questions.text: A 72-year-old former pilot visits a neurologist, accompanied by his wife, exhibiting symptoms of rapidly advancing dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual impairments. The provided FLAIR MRI scans can assist in confirming the diagnosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Variant CJD

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and the FLAIR MRI in the scenario showing the “hockey stick” sign is found in variant type Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is a rare, rapidly progressing brain disorder affecting coordination, memory, and mental functions.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) findings

 

 

 

 

 

Electroencephalography (EEG)
  • Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC)
  • These can be either lateralized in earlier stages or generalized in later stages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

MRI findings
  • DWI or FLAIR MRI has a sensitivity of 98% and specificity of 93%
  • DWI: Increased intensity in the basal ganglia, thalamus, and cortex
  • Cortical ribboning
  • Hockey stick or pulvinar sign is seen in variant, infectious, or acquired CJD

 

In the initial stages, the MRI is normal in Alzheimer’s (Option A), and in the later stages shows temporal and parietal atrophy.

There is no history of stroke; hence vascular dementia (Option B) is unlikely to be the diagnosis

The hockey stick sign is not and indicator of sporadic CJD (Option C).

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis & WHO clinical stage of HIV?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral candidiasis & WHO stage 3

Explanation:

  • The lesion shown in the picture is that of oral candidiasis and according to WHO, HIV with oral candidiasis or thrush is categorized as clinical stage 3.

Complications of HIV/AIDS

Gastrointestinal tract

Candidiasis

  • Oral, Esophageal and Tracheal candidiasis
  • Presents with odynophagia
  • Treatment: IV fluconazole

Black hairy tongue

  • Due to the Ebstein-Barr virus.

Chronic diarrhoea

  • Due to Cryptosporidium or Isospora Belli
  • Investigation: Microscopy reveals
    • Cyst < 10 μm - Cryptosporidium
    • Larger cyst - Isospora belli
  • Treatment
    • Cryptosporidium: Nitazoxanide
    • Isospora: Cotrimoxazole

Neoplastic diseases

Kaposi sarcoma
  • Due to HHV-8
  • Vascular tumours on the skin, mucus membrane or organs

Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma

  • Immunoblastic lymphoma
  • Burkitt’s lymphoma
  • Primary CNS lymphoma

Respiratory system

Pneumocystis pneumonia

  • Due to pneumocystis jirovecii
  • Presents with non-productive cough, fever and weight loss
  • Investigation
    • CXR: Bilateral perihilar opacities
    • Beta-1,3-glucan test positive
    • Broncho-alveolar Lavage (BAL): Giemsa staining or methenamine staining shows oval-shaped fungi.
  • Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

Others

Renal

HIV associated Nephropathy

CVS

Myocardial infarction, cardiomyopathy

 

WHO clinical staging of HIV

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

  • Unexplained moderate weight loss (< 10% of body weight)
  • Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections
  • Herpes zoster
  • Angular cheilitis
  • Recurrent oral ulceration
  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis
  • Fungal nail infections

Stage 3

  • Unexplained severe weight loss (> 10% of body weight)
  • Unexplained chronic diarrhoea for > 1 month
  • Unexplained persistent fever (> 37.5°C for > 1 month)

Persistent oral candidiasis

  • Oral hairy leucoplakia
  • Pulmonary tuberculosis
  • Severe bacterial infections
  • Acute necrotising ulcerative stomatitis, gingivitis or periodontitis
  • Unexplained anaemia (< 80 g/L (8 g/dL)), neutropenia (< 0.5 × 109 /L)
  • and/or chronic thrombocytopenia (< 50 × 109 /L)

Stage 4

  • Candidiasis of oesophagus, trachea, bronchi or lungs
  • Cervical carcinoma – invasive
  • Cryptococcosis – extrapulmonary
  • Cryptosporidiosis, chronic (> 1 month)
  • Cytomegalovirus disease (outside liver, spleen and nodes)
  • Herpes simplex chronic (> 1 month) ulcers or visceral
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • HIV wasting syndrome
  • Cystoisosporiasis (formerly known as isosporiasis), chronic (> 1 month)
  • Kaposi’s sarcoma
  • Lymphoma (cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin)
  • Mycobacterial infection, non-tuberculous, extrapulmonary or disseminated
  • Mycosis – disseminated endemic (e.g. coccidioidomycosis, talaromycosis (formerly penicilliosis), histoplasmosis)
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Pneumonia, recurrent bacterial
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Toxoplasmosis – cerebral
  • Tuberculosis – extrapulmonary (CDC includes pulmonary)
  • Sepsis, recurrent (including non-typhoidal Salmonella) (CDC only includes Salmonella)
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated cardiomyopathy
  • Leishmaniasis, atypical disseminated

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: As seen below, a 49-year-old man presents with flu-like symptoms and a palmoplantar rash. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary syphilis

Explanation:

  • The classical rash and other symptoms point to the diagnosis of secondary syphilis.

Classic Manifestations of secondary syphilis:

  • Mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized non-tender lymphadenopathy.
  • The primary chancre may still be present in ~15% of cases, more common in HIV-infected individuals.

Skin Rash:

  • Macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides.
  • Lesions may be subtle, and 25% of patients with a visible rash may not recognize it.
  • Lesions initially present as pale red or pink, non-pruritic macules on the trunk/extremities.
  • Progress to papular lesions, often affecting palms and soles.
  • Severe necrotic lesions (lues maligna) may occur in HIV patients.

Hair and Mucosal Involvement:

  • Patchy alopecia of the scalp, eyebrows, or beard in 5% of cases.
  • Condylomata lata (moist, infectious lesions) may form in intertriginous areas (e.g., perianal, vulva, scrotum) in 10% of cases.
  • Mucous patches (painless silver-grey erosions) occur in 10-15% of patients, commonly in the oral or genital mucosa.

Constitutional Symptoms:

  • Sore throat (15–30%), fever (5–8%), weight loss (2–20%), malaise (25%), anorexia (2–10%), headache (10%), and meningismus (5%).
  • Acute meningitis occurs in 1-2% of cases, with up to 40% of early syphilis cases showing CSF abnormalities.

Ocular and Otic Involvement:

  • Ocular symptoms: pupillary abnormalities, optic neuritis, iritis, or uveitis; may lead to permanent blindness if untreated.
  • Otic symptoms: sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, or tinnitus.
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial for preventing long-term damage.

Less Common Complications:

  • Hepatitis, nephropathy, gastrointestinal issues (e.g., hypertrophic gastritis, proctitis), arthritis, and periostitis.
  • Hepatic involvement is common but typically asymptomatic.
  • Renal involvement results from immune complex deposition, leading to proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome.

Resolution:

  • Most secondary syphilis manifestations resolve spontaneously within 1–6 months.

 

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the condition in which the cherry red spot, as shown in the image below, is observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)

Explanation:

  • The presentation of sudden, painless vision loss with a cherry-red spot at the macula is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

  • Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)

    • The central retinal artery is blocked, causing widespread retinal ischemia. Sometimes, if a cilioretinal artery is present, it can continue to supply the macula, preserving central vision even when the central retinal artery is occluded.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss
  • Painless, except in GCA: GCA-associated CRAO may present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple

Clinical Signs:

  • Visual Acuity (VA): severely reduced, often to counting fingers or worse
  • Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD): Profound and sometimes total (amaurotic pupil)

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina , particularly in the posterior pole
  • Cherry-Red Spot): Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation
  • Cattle truck appearance: Due to segmentation of blood column in retinal veins
  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles
  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia is seen in chronic cases.

 

Fluorescein Angiography (FA)

  • Arterial Filling: Delayed
  • Masking of Background Fluorescence: Edematous retina blocks normal fluorescence from the choroid
  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion if a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision

Other Diagnostic Tests

Reveals retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery and other systemic causes.

  • Cranial MRI or CT
  • Carotid duplex scanning
  • Echocardiography
  • Thrombophilia screening

Incorrect Options:

Central retinal venous occlusion (CRVO) (Option B) occurs when the central retinal vein, becomes blocked. It typically presents with sudden, painless vision loss and may be associated with retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and retinal edema.

Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO) (Option C) occurs when one of the branches of the central retinal artery becomes blocked, leading to a localized area of retinal ischemia. The affected area of the retina may appear pale, with associated retinal hemorrhages.

Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO) (Option D) occurs when one of the branches of the central retinal vein becomes blocked, resulting in impaired venous drainage from a particular area of the retina. It can lead to retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and macular edema.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a penetrating injury to the left eye was treated with corneoscleral suturing. Two months later, he returned with complaints of reduced near vision, pain, redness, and sensitivity to light in his right eye. Direct ophthalmoscopy revealed nodules in the fundus. Which part of the eye is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Uvea

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of penetrating injury to the left eye and subsequent reduced near vision, pain, redness, and photophobia along with nodules on fundus i.e., Dalen-Fuchs nodules are suggestive of Sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO)

Definition

Bilateral, granulomatous, panuveitis (Option A) occurring after penetrating trauma where uveal prolapse may have been a feature of the trauma

Etiology and pathogenesis
  • Trauma to one eye (exciting eye) — 2 weeks to 3 months — Uveitis in the uninjured eye (sympathizing eye).
  • T-cell mediated autoimmune hypersensitivity reaction to Retinal S antigen.
  • Maximum risk upon injury to the ciliary body.

Histopathology
  • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the choroid.
  • Scattered aggregates of epithelioid cells are seen, many of which contain fine granules of melanin.
  • Dalen–Fuchs nodules - granulomas located between Bruch membrane and the RPE (also seen in VKH syndrome)

Clinical features
  • The exciting eye is frequently red and irritable.
  • The sympathizing eye develops irritation, blurred vision, photophobia and loss of accommodation causing difficulty in near vision (first symptom)
  • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, which may be mild or severe and is usually granulomatous

Investigations
  • Fundus exam: Dalen–Fuchs nodules, Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis and optic disc swelling.
  • As inflammation settles, residual chorioretinal scarring may confer a ‘sunset glow’ appearance similar to VKH.
  • B-scan ultrasonography: Choroidal thickening and retinal detachment

Treatment
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye within 10 to 14 days of the injury is effective in preventing or reducing the severity of SO
  • Steroids are the basis of initial treatment. Intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to response. Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics may be given

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the patient having the following type of karyotype, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Down Syndrome

Explanation:

  • The karyotype is showing three copies of chromosome 21, which indicates it is a case of Down syndrome. Down Syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21, resulting in a total of 47 chromosomes instead of the normal 46.

 

Key features of Karyotyping:

  • A karyotype is a visual representation of an individual's chromosomes, arranged in pairs by size and position of the centromere.
  • In a normal human karyotype, 46 chromosomes are arranged in 23 pairs (22 pairs of autosomes and 1 pair of sex chromosomes).
  • The chromosomes are photographed during metaphase, when they are most condensed and visible.
  • They are then arranged in descending order of size, with the sex chromosomes placed last.
     

Turner Syndrome (Option A) is characterized by monosomy X, which means there is an absence or partial deletion of one of the X chromosomes, resulting in a karyotype of 45, XO. The presented karyotype shows three copies of chromosome 21, not a missing X chromosome. Turner syndrome affects only females and is associated with short stature and ovarian dysfunction.

Klinefelter Syndrome (Option C) presents with an extra X chromosome in males, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XXY. The karyotype image clearly shows trisomy 21, not an extra X chromosome. Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by tall stature, infertility, and delayed puberty.

Edward Syndrome (Option D) also known as Trisomy 18, is caused by an extra copy of chromosome 18, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XX+18 or 47, XY+18. The provided karyotype shows an extra chromosome 21, not chromosome 18. Edward syndrome is associated with severe developmental delays and multiple congenital anomalies.

questions.text: In which diseases are microaneurysms observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diabetic retinopathy

Explanation:

  • Microaneurysms are localized outpouchings of the capillary wall that may form by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop.

Diabetic retinopathy Clinical Features:

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm (Option B)
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

Incorrect Options:

Retinal detachment (Option A) involves the separation of the sensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Uveitis (Option C) is inflammation of the uveal tract (iris, ciliary body, and choroid) and can cause symptoms such as pain, photophobia, and redness.

Glaucoma(Option D) primarily involves increased intraocular pressure, leading to optic nerve damage.

questions.text: Which medication can be administered to a patient diagnosed with acute anterior uveitis, presenting with symptoms of photophobia and blurred vision?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atropine

Explanation:

Treatment for Anterior Uveitis:

  • Topical Steroids (Treatment of Choice):
    • Prednisolone: Commonly used for reducing inflammation.
    • Loteprednol: Less potential for increasing intraocular pressure.
  • Cycloplegics (Topical):
    • Rest the ciliary muscles to relieve pain.
    • Prevent and break posterior synechiae (adhesions of the iris to the lens).
    • Improve blood supply, leading to better healing.
    • Eg.:Atropine.
  • Non-Steroidal Treatment:
    • Voclosporin: Part of the Luminate program, used as a non-steroidal option.
  • For Chronic or Vision-Threatening Uveitis:
    • Monoclonal Antibodies:
      • Adalimumab: TNF-alpha inhibitor, used for severe or chronic cases.
      • Infliximab: TNF-alpha inhibitor.
    • Interferon Alpha: An option for severe cases, helps modulate the immune response.

Incorrect Options:

Moxifloxacin (Option A) is an antibiotic commonly used to treat bacterial infections.

Acetazolamide (Option C) is a medication primarily used to treat glaucoma by reducing the production of aqueous humor and lowering intraocular pressure.

Methotrexate (Option D) is an immunosuppressive medication commonly used in the treatment of various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions. It may be prescribed for severe or chronic cases of uveitis that do not respond to other treatments.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of rickets

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) PHEX gene is affected

Explanation:

  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH) is characterized by mutations in the PHEX gene. This gene encodes the phosphate-regulating endopeptidase homolog X-linked (PHEX) protein, which plays a crucial role in phosphate homeostasis.
  • When the PHEX gene is mutated, it leads to increased FGF-23 levels, resulting in impaired phosphate reabsorption in the renal tubules and subsequent hypophosphatemia.
  • XLH is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern and presents with characteristic features including lower limb deformities, dental abnormalities, and skeletal manifestations without typical hypocalcemic symptoms.

 

X-Linked Hypophosphatemic (XLH) Rickets

Prevalence

1 in 20,000. Most common among genetic disorders causing rickets

Inheritance

X-linked dominant

Gene Mutated
  • PHEX (phosphate-regulating gene with homology to endopeptidases on X chromosome)
  • Normally, product of this gene appears to have an indirect role in inactivating FGF-23

Pathophysiology

 

 

Clinical Manifestations
  • Lower limb deformities:
    • Coxa vara
    • Genu valgum
    • Genu varum
  • Poor growth
  • Maxillofacial abnormalities
  • Skull deformities: Due to premature fusion of cranial sutures
  • Delayed dentition
  • Short stature

Laboratory Findings
  • High renal phosphate excretion
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
  • Normal PTH and serum calcium
  • Low or inappropriately normal levels of 1,25-D

Treatment
  • Phosphorus Supplementation:
    • 1-3 g elemental phosphorus daily, divided into 4-5 doses
    • Can be given in the form of Joulie solution (30.4 mg phosphate/mL) or as neutral phosphate effervescent tablets
    • Frequent dosing helps to prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus because there is rapid decline after each dose
  • Calcitriol: 30-70 ng/kg/day in 2 doses
  • Burosumab-twza: Monoclonal antibody targeting FGF-23, an alternative for children >1 year

Prognosis

Generally good response to therapy, though frequent dosing can affect compliance

 

FGF-23 levels decreased (Option A): This is incorrect because XLH is characterized by elevated levels of FGF-23, not decreased levels. The increased FGF-23 leads to phosphate wasting and decreased active vitamin D production, which are hallmark features of the condition.

It is the most common cause of rickets (Option C): This statement is incorrect because while XLH is the most common inherited form of rickets, nutritional deficiencies, particularly vitamin D deficiency, remain the most common overall cause of rickets worldwide.

Excretion of phosphorus is decreased (Option D): This statement contradicts the pathophysiology of XLH, where there is increased renal phosphate wasting leading to elevated urinary phosphorus excretion. This increased phosphate excretion is a direct result of elevated FGF-23 levels and is a key diagnostic feature of the condition.

questions.text: For which of the subsequent diseases is collagen cross-linking therapy utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratoconus

Explanation:

Treatment of Keratoconus:

  • Spectacle Correction:
    • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
    • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.
  • Contact Lenses:
    • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
    • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.
  • Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL) (Option A) :
    • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
    • Involves riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
    • Riboflavin induces cross-linking of corneal collagen to stabilize the stroma and improve contact lens tolerance.
  • Keratoplasty :
    • Recommended if disease progresses or in cases of acute hydrops (Descemet's membrane tear).
    • Reserved for more advanced diseases or when other treatments fail.
    • Penetrating keratoplasty is common, but Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is preferred if Descemet's membrane and endothelium are intact, reducing rejection risk.
  • Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) :
    • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
    • Less effective in halting progression.

Incorrect Options:

Corneal ulcer (Option B) are treated with antibiotics, antivirals, or antifungals, depending on the cause.

Band keratopathy (Option C) involves calcium deposition in the superficial cornea and is treated with chelation therapy or surgical interventions like superficial keratectomy.

Uveitis (Option B) is inflammation of the uveal tract and is typically managed with corticosteroids, immunosuppressive agents, or biologics.

questions.text: A patient has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis, which has very little interference with his daily activities. Based on further workup, a diagnosis of a mild case of ITP is made. How will you manage the patient?

choices.text: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Education, counseling, and watchful expectancy

 

Explanation:

In a patient with mild ITP who has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis but minimal interference with daily activities, the preferred approach is watchful expectancy.

  • Most cases of mild ITP in children resolve spontaneously without treatment.
  • Regular follow-up visits can help assess the progression of the disease and determine the need for intervention if symptoms worsen or if there is an increase in bleeding risk.
  • The observation period involves providing education and counseling to the patient and closely monitoring platelet counts and symptoms over time.
     

Management of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura in children

Based on platelet count:

  • Platelet Count >30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding- Monitor closely
  • Platelet Count < 30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding + Platelet Count ≥ 5,000 cells/μL: Glucocorticoids (e.g., Prednisone, Dexamethasone)
  • Platelet Count < 5,000 cells/μL or Severe Bleeding: i.v.i.g.+ Glucocorticoids

Other modalities:

 
  • Immediate Need to Raise Platelet Count like surgery or trauma- Platelet Transfusion
  • Persistent or Severe Cases- Monitor with intermittent i.v.i.g.
  • If necessary, consider Splenectomy

Alternative Medications:
  • Anti-CD20 Antibody: Rituximab
  • TPO Receptor Agonists: Romiplostim, Eltrombopag

 

Short course corticosteroid therapy (Option A) is not indicated as the first-line treatment for mild ITP with minimal symptoms. While corticosteroids like prednisone are effective, their side effects outweigh the benefits in mild cases. Corticosteroids are typically reserved for cases with more severe thrombocytopenia or significant bleeding risk.

Intravenous anti-D administration (Option B) is an intervention reserved for Rh-positive patients with more severe ITP requiring rapid platelet count elevation. In mild cases with minimal symptoms, this aggressive approach is unnecessary and carries potential risks.

A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin (Option C) represents an aggressive and costly intervention that is not warranted in mild ITP cases. IVIG is typically reserved for severe cases with significant bleeding risk or very low platelet counts (<5,000/μL).

questions.text: What's the main risk for a 37-year-old man with blurred vision and severe pain in his right eye? He revealed that recently, he went swimming in a pond. During examination, a ring-like lesion was found, as seen in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Soft Contact lenses:

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of blurred vision, severe pain after swimming in a pond with ring like lesion on examination is suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis:

It is caused by Acanthamoeba, a free-living amoeba found in water, causes severe corneal infections

Risk Factors:

  1. Contact Lens Use (Primary Risk Factor)
  2. Exposure to Contaminated Water
  3. Trauma
  4. Immunosuppression
  5. Use of Homemade Saline Solutions.
  6. Poor Lens Storage Conditions

Examination Findings in Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

Symptoms:

  • Blurred Vision: Common in corneal conditions due to the disruption of the cornea's transparent surface.
  • Discomfort: Significant discomfort in the affected eye.
  • Severe Pain: Pain is often out of proportion to clinical signs, a key clinical clue.

Signs:

Early Disease:

  • Irregular and Greyish Epithelium: Early sign indicating amoebic invasion.
  • Pseudodendrites: Lesions resembling herpetic keratitis
  • Limbitis and Stromal Infiltrates: Inflammation at the corneal-scleral junction with diffuse or focal infiltrates in the anterior stroma.
  • Perineural Infiltrates (Radial Keratoneuritis): Hallmark sign, radial streaks extending towards the cornea's centre, pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Advanced Disease:

  • Ring Abscess: Characteristic of advanced infection, where infiltrates form a ring-shaped abscess.
  • Stromal Opacification and Vascularisation: Corneal opacity and new blood vessel growth, leading to significant vision impairment.
  • Corneal Melting: Serious complication where corneal tissue breaks down, often at the infiltrate edges.
  • Scleritis: Reactive inflammation of the sclera, not a direct infection extension.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the specific sign that is pathognomonic for acute anterior uveitis among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Keratic precipitates

Explanation:

Anterior Uveitis:

Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs) (Option B):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle
  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil
  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

Incorrect Options:

Aqueous flare (Option A) refers to the presence of protein and inflammatory cells in the aqueous humor, which may be seen in anterior uveitis.

Festooned pupil (Option C) is a characteristic feature of posterior synechiae in chronic uveitis.

Bussaca’s nodules (Option D) are larger, granulomatous nodules that are seen in conditions like chronic anterior uveitis, especially in sarcoidosis or tuberculosis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a female patient, aged 65, who has a history of chickenpox and presents at the clinic with the following findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Herpes zoster ophthalmicus

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a patient with history of chickenpox and cutaneous lesions seen along the course of trigeminal nerve is suggestive of Herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO)

  • Affects the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Anterior uveitis occurs in 40-50% of cases, usually within 2 weeks of skin rash onset.
  • Symptoms: mild iritis, vesicular rash on the nose, small KPs, mild aqueous flare, possible hemorrhagic hypopyon.
  • Complications: iris atrophy, secondary glaucoma, complicated cataracts.

Incorrect Options:

Chicken pox exacerbation (Option A), caused by the varicella-zoster virus, usually occurs in children and presents with a generalized vesicular rash. Reactivation of the virus in adults leads to herpes zoster rather than an exacerbation of chickenpox.

Drug allergy to acyclovir (Option B), a common antiviral medication used to treat herpes zoster, would typically present with skin rashes, itching, or swelling after drug exposure.

Herpes zoster oticus (Option D) (Ramsay Hunt syndrome) involves the facial nerve and affects the ear, causing pain, vesicular rash in the ear canal, and facial paralysis. It does not primarily affect the eye or lead to keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the following malignant tumors, commonly found in children, has a high tendency to spread to the bone marrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neuroblastoma

Explanation:
