  • Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumor arising from neural crest cells and is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood.
  • It frequently presents with widespread metastatic disease at diagnosis, with bone marrow being one of the most common sites of metastasis. This characteristic bone marrow involvement often leads to pancytopenia and is a factor used for disease staging and prognosis.

Neuroblastoma

Definition & Epidemiology
  • Neural crest-derived tumor
  • Most common extracranial solid tumor in children
  • 7-8% of all childhood cancers
  • Most common in first year of life
  • Median age at diagnosis: 19 months

Genetic Features
  • MYCN amplification (~20% of cases)
  • Loss of heterozygosity: 1p, 11q, 14q, 17q
  • TERT and chromatin remodeling genes
  • 1-2% show family history
  • Higher MYCN copy number indicates worse prognosis

Clinical Presentation

Primary Sites:

  • Abdominal (65%)
  • Mediastinal (40%)
  • Paraspinal (19%)
  • Head/neck (5%)

 

Symptoms:

  • Pain, fever, irritability
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal distension
  • Periorbital ecchymosis
  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (rare)

International Staging

Stage L1: Localized tumor, complete excision

Stage IIA: Incomplete gross excision

Stage IIB: Complete/incomplete excision with positive lymph nodes

Stage III: Midline crossing or bilateral involvement

Stage IV: Distant metastasis (Bone marrow (MC), bone, liver, regional lymph nodes)

Stage IVS: Localized primary with limited dissemination (infants)

Diagnostic Markers

Immunohistochemistry:

  • Synaptophysin
  • Tyrosine hydroxylase
  • PHOX2B
  • Neuron-specific enolase

 

Other Markers:

  • Desmin
  • Myogenin
  • Keratin
  • CD99

Treatment Options

Primary Treatments:

  • Surgery
  • Chemotherapy
  • Radiation therapy

 

Chemotherapy Regimens:

  • OPEC (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, cisplatin)
  • CADO (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin)
  • PECADO (cisplatin, etoposide)

 

Additional Therapies:

  • 13-cis retinoic acid
  • Autologous bone marrow transplantation

 

Wilms tumor (Option A) primarily metastasizes to the lungs, liver, and regional lymph nodes. While it is the most common renal tumor in children, bone marrow involvement is not a characteristic feature. The typical pattern of spread follows hematogenous routes to the lungs and liver.

Adrenal gland tumors (Option C), such as adrenocortical carcinomas, typically spread to local lymph nodes, liver, and lungs. Bone marrow metastasis is not a common feature of these tumors.

Granulosa cell tumor of ovary (Option D) typically spreads within the peritoneal cavity and to regional lymph nodes. It is rare in children, and bone marrow metastasis is not a characteristic feature. These tumors are more commonly seen in adults.

questions.text: In a patient who has had contact with a COVID-19 patient, presenting with symptoms such as redness, sensitivity to light, excessive tearing, and overall discomfort, a thorough examination was conducted with no eye abnormality. Based on this information, which specific part of the eye is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Conjunctiva:

  • The symptoms of redness, sensitivity to light (photophobia), excessive tearing, and discomfort are characteristic of conjunctivitis, commonly known as pink eye. Conjunctivitis has been observed as a common ocular manifestation of COVID-19, with the conjunctiva being the most likely part of the eye to be affected. This is usually a mild viral conjunctivitis that resolves with symptomatic treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Uvea (Option B) is typically affected in uveitis. While uveitis can cause redness, sensitivity to light, and discomfort, it is less common to occur solely as a result of COVID-19. Also, uveitis typically presents with more severe signs upon examination, such as cells in the anterior chamber or posterior synechiae, which were not noted in this case.

Choroid (Option C) is a deeper structure within the eye and is not typically affected in viral conjunctivitis or mild ocular manifestations of COVID-19. Choroiditis would present with more severe symptoms and would be visible on specialized imaging such as fluorescein angiography.

Retina (Option D) would typically not be directly affected by COVID-19 or the symptoms presented in this patient. Retinal conditions, such as retinitis, often present with more severe visual changes, such as visual field defects or floaters, which were not reported here.

questions.text: Arlt’s line is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Trachoma

Explanation:

Signs in Trachoma:

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line (Option C)
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis : Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

Lacrimal apparatus sequelae:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis
  • Chronic dacryoadenitis

 

Images:

Active Trachoma

 

Follicles in upper palpebral conjunctiva

 

Trachomatous pannus

Progressive pannus

Cicatricial

Trachoma

​​​​​​

 

 

Regressive pannus

 

Conjunctival concretions

 

Trichiasis

Tylosis (thickening of tarsal border of eyelid)

Incorrect Options:

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (Option A) is characterized by intense itching, redness, watery discharge, and cobblestone appearance of upper palpebral conjunctiva.

Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis (Option B) is characterized by the formation of small nodules called as phlycten near limbus or ulcers on the cornea.

Pterygium (Option D) is conjunctival degeneration characterized by triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of bulbar conjunctiva over the limbus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented the findings shown in the given image. What is this physical finding called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clubbing

Explanation:

  • The image shows typical findings of clubbing of fingers, seen in various cardiopulmonary conditions. Clubbing is not always irreversible and can be reversible in certain conditions.

Clubbing of fingers

Definition
  • Enlargement of distal segments of fingers and toes
  • Proliferation of connective tissue
  • Particularly on the dorsal surface
  • Changes at the base of clubbed nail

Pathophysiology
  • Connective tissue proliferation
  • Exact mechanism unknown
  • Platelet-derived growth factors implicated

Clinical Signs
  • Bulbous Enlargement of the Distal Phalanges
  • Loss of the Normal Angle Between the Nail and the Nailbed (Lovibond’s Angle)
  • Increased Sponginess of the Soft Tissue at the Base of the Nail
  • Nail Changes:
  • Nail flattening/nail curvature
  • Hippocratic fingers: The tips of the fingers become enlarged, and the nails curve downward

Clinical tests

Schamroth’s Sign:

  • Normal: A small diamond-shaped window should be visible between the nails when the fingers are positioned in this way.
  • Positive Schamroth’s Sign: The window disappears, and there is no gap between the nails, indicating the loss of the normal angle at the nail bed.

Associated Conditions
  • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Cystic Fibrosis
  • Lung cancer
  • Tuberculosis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease

Key Features
  • Can be hereditary or acquired
  • May be reversible in certain circumstances
  • Associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy
  • Can cause pain and arthritis-like changes

 

Spoon-shaped nails (koilonychia) (Option A): The nail abnormality is characterized by thin, fragile nails with a concave appearance, either horizontally or vertically oriented. The nail plate appears to be depressed in the centre and bent outward at the edges.

Raynaud's phenomenon (Option B) presents as repeated constriction of blood vessels in the fingers and toes, typically triggered by cold temperatures or stress.

Pallor (Option C) refers to a noticeable decrease in the normal colour and tone of the skin or mucous membranes, which may occur due to changes in blood flow, anaemia, or other unclear factors.

questions.text: What is the disease depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cushing’s syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations in the image is of Cushing’s syndrome which is caused due to prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids.

Cushing's syndrome

  • Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids.
  • Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma.
  • It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis.

Clinical Features of Cushing syndrome

  • Physical:
    • Weight gain and central obesity: Particularly around the face ("moon facies") and the back of the neck ("buffalo hump").
    • Skin changes: Thin and fragile skin prone to bruising, broad purple stretch marks, acne, and hirsutism.
    • Musculoskeletal Issues: Osteoporosis (leading to fractures, especially in the spine) (Option B), muscle weakness, proximal myopathy (difficulty climbing stairs or rising from a chair), and decreased deep tendon reflexes.
  • Metabolic: Glucose intolerance or diabetes and dyslipidemia (abnormal blood lipid levels).
  • Cardiovascular: Hypertension, hypokalemia, and oedema.
  • Reproductive: Decreased libido, and amenorrhea in women due to suppressed gonadotropin release.
  • Psychological: Irritability, emotional instability, depression, cognitive impairment, and in severe cases, psychosis.
  • Other features:
    • Increased susceptibility to infections, elevated white blood cell count, eosinopenia
    • Hypercoagulable state, increasing the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Which laser is considered the most appropriate for cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Femtosecond laser

Explanation:

  • The Femtosecond laser is the most suitable laser for cataract surgery presently. It is used in a procedure called Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery (FLACS).

Femtosecond lasers:

  • Mechanism: They use ultra-short pulses of laser light to ionize tissue, creating a plasma bubble that expands and allows for precise, controlled cutting of the tissue.
  • Advantages: It provides high precision, reduces thermal damage, and improves safety compared to traditional surgical methods.
  • Limitations: Femtosecond lasers are costly and require specialised surgeon training, which can limit their accessibility and increase the overall cost of surgery.
  • Applications:
    • Femtosecond lasers are commonly used in Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery (FLACS) and Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis (LASIK) for precise lens fragmentation, corneal flap creation, and refractive correction.
    • PRK (photorefractive keratectomy)
    • SMILE (small incision lenticule extraction) for correction of myopia
    • Creation of tunnel for intracorneal rings
    • Arcuate incisions to correct corneal astigmatism
    • Keratoplasty incisions
    • Lamellar and full-thickness corneal transplants

Incorrect Options:

Nd-YAG laser (Option A) is primarily used for posterior capsulotomy for the management of posterior capsular opacification.. Nd-YAG laser is not the primary laser used for cataract removal.

Diode laser (Option B) are used in iridotomy for the management of glaucoma.

Excimer laser (Option C) are primarily used in refractive surgeries such as LASIK (laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis) to reshape the cornea and correct refractive errors

questions.text: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rickets

Explanation:

  • The radiographical features such as widened or irregular growth plates in the phalanges and metacarpals & metaphyses near the growth plates showing a cupped or flared appearance indicate the diagnosis of Rickets.
  • Rickets is a condition that primarily affects growing children and is caused by a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.

 

Radiological Changes:

  • Decreased Calcification: Leads to the thickening of the growth plate.
  • Fraying: Initial change is the loss of the normal zone of provisional calcification adjacent to the metaphysis, which appears as a blurring or frayed appearance of the metaphyseal margin.
  • Cupping: Edge of the metaphysis changes from a convex or flat surface to a more concave surface, particularly noticeable at the distal ends of the radius, ulna, and fibula.
  • Splaying: Cartilage hypertrophy leads to the widening of the growth plate resulting in the widening (splaying) of the metaphyseal ends.
  • Generalized reduction in bone density: Osteopenia
  • Widening of the Metaphysis

 

Scurvy (Option A): Shows different radiological features, including ground-glass appearance and Wimberger's ring sign.

Osteomalacia (Option C): Similar to rickets but occurs in adults and radiographically suggests growth plate closure.

Osteopetrosis (Option D): Shows increased bone density rather than the decreased density seen here.

questions.text: Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for biting a 10-year-old child who presented with symptoms of tachycardia, hypertension, tongue fasciculation, hypersalivation, dilated pupils, and mild erythema at the site of the wound? The child recalls that the animal had a curved tail pointing upwards.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Scorpion

Explanation:

  • The clinical features and the characteristics of the animal with a curved tail pointing upwards point to the possibility of the animal being a scorpion.

Less dangerous scorpions:

  • Local pain, swelling, and burning sensation
  • Symptoms resolve in a few hours
  • Possible allergic reactions to venom

Bark scorpions (e.g., Centruroides species):

  • Intense pain, paresthesia, and hyperesthesia (worsened by tapping)
  • Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements
  • Excessive salivation, sweating, and difficulty handling secretions
  • Nausea, vomiting, slurred speech
  • Muscle twitching, jerking, and shaking (may resemble seizures)
  • Tachycardia, arrhythmias, hypertension, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis
  • Respiratory arrest, especially in children and the elderly

Venomous scorpions (e.g., Tityus serrulatus, Leiurus quinquestriatus):

  • Hypertensive crises, arrhythmias, myocardial damage
  • Pulmonary oedema, central nervous toxicity

Other species (e.g., Hemiscorpius lepturus):

  • Pain, hemolysis, tissue necrosis (delayed onset)
  • Systemic complications: hemoglobinuria, acute kidney injury

General symptoms of envenomations:

  • Immediate sharp local pain
  • Edema, ecchymosis, and burning sensation
  • Symptoms generally resolve within hours for most species

Treatment of scorpion sting:

  • Identification of the scorpion species is essential for determining treatment, as stings from non-lethal species typically only require basic care.
  • Non-lethal stings: Most stings cause local discomfort and can be managed at home with ice packs, analgesics, or antihistamines. Patients should return to the emergency department if cranial-nerve or neuromuscular symptoms develop.
  • Severe envenomations: Aggressive supportive care and careful use of antivenom can prevent deaths from more dangerous stings.
  • Initial measures: Keeping the patient calm, applying pressure dressings, and using cold packs can reduce venom absorption.
  • Treatment for symptoms: Continuous IV infusion of midazolam can control agitation and muscle movements, but close monitoring is needed due to the risk of respiratory arrest, especially when sedatives or narcotics are used.
  • Management of complications:
    • Hypertension and pulmonary oedema: Managed with nifedipine, nitroprusside, hydralazine, or prazosin.
    • Bradycardia: Managed with atropine.
  • Antivenin: FDA-approved antivenin (C. sculpturatus IgG F(ab')2 in horse serum) is available in some countries and can rapidly reverse cranial-nerve dysfunction and muscular symptoms when administered intravenously.

 

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What does the picture depict in terms of the investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fundus fluorescein angiography

Explanation:

Fundus fluorescein angiography:

Principle: Based on the detection of fluorescent light emitted by fluorescein dye in circulation.

  • Absorption & Emission Wavelengths:
    • Irradiating light: 420–490 nm.
    • Emitted fluorescence: 510–530 nm.
  • Retinal pigments and red blood cells can absorb fluorescent light, masking deeper structures. Pigment migration allows visibility of deeper layers.

Diagnostic uses:

  • Diabetic Retinopathy: Reveals neovascularization, and assesses vascular tree integrity.
  • Fundus Disorders: Identifies depth of pathological involvement.
  • Optic Nerve Pathologies: Useful in detecting optic nerve issues such as papilloedema.
  • Neovascularization of Iris: Detects leakage from iris vessels, an early sign of rubeosis.

Normal Study

Abnormalities Detected by Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA)

Fluorescence Type

Cause

Examples

Hyperfluorescence

Window defect in retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Atrophy showing background choroidal fluorescence

Pooling of dye under detached RPE

Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD)

Pooling of dye under sensory retina

Central serous retinopathy (CSR)

Leakage into the neurosensory retina due to the breakdown of the inner blood-retinal barrier

Cystoid macular edema (CME)

Leakage from choroidal or retinal neovascularization

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy, subretinal neovascular membrane in ARMD

Staining (long retention of dye by tissues)

Drusen, normal optic disc

Leakage from optic nerve head

Papilloedema

Hypofluorescence

Blockage of background fluorescence

Retinal hemorrhage, hard exudates, pigmented clumps

Occlusion of retinal/choroidal vasculature

Central retinal artery occlusion , diabetic retinopathy capillary occlusion

Loss of vasculature

Choroideremia, myopic degeneration

Incorrect Options:

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) (Option B) is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses light waves to produce cross-sectional images of the retina.It is particularly useful in assessing conditions like macular edema, macular holes, and retinal detachment.

Retinal CT (Option C) is not a recognized imaging modality in ophthalmology, as computed tomography (CT) is generally not suitable for the detailed visualization of retinal layers.

Retinal MR (Option D) can be used to assess orbital or optic nerve conditions, it does not provide the level of detail required for retinal imaging

questions.text:
Which of the following agents is most likely causing the condition in a 60-year-old woman, who had a kidney transplant 2 months ago, and is now experiencing a high fever, severe difficulty in breathing, and a dry cough with a hacking sound?

A chest x-ray shows widespread interstitial infiltrates in both lungs, and urine examination reveals the presence of cells with an 'owl-eye' appearance.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cytomegalovirus

Explanation:

  • Cytomegalovirus infection is the most common opportunistic infection post renal transplantation, and it usually occurs within 1- 6 months of transplantation.

Complications following Renal transplant

Graft rejection

Hyperacute, acute and chronic

Opportunistic infections

 
  • < 1 Month: Wound infection, HSV, UTI, Oral candidiasis
  • 1-6 Months: CMV (most common), HBV, HCV, Pneumocystis carinii, Listeria
  • >6 Months: BK Virus, Aspergillus, Nocardia, HBV, HCV, HZV

Hypercalcemia

This may indicate failure of parathyroid gland regression post-transplant.

Anemia

Common post-transplant, often due to immunosuppressive medications. Gastrointestinal bleeding can occur from steroid use.

Chronic hepatitis

Particularly from hepatitis B virus, which can progress over time.

Skin and lip cancers

Most common malignancy

The leading causes of death among kidney transplant recipients include:

  • Cardiovascular events (29%)
  • Infections (18%)
  • Malignancies (17%)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and labile moods. During a physical exam, the neurologist notices the findings shown in the image below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wilson’s disease:

Explanation:

  • The above image shows fine pigmented and granular deposits, suggesting Wilson’s disease. These are Kayser-Fleischer rings due to copper deposits in the descemet’s membrane.

Wilson's disease

  • Wilson's disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by the abnormal accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, eyes, and other organs. This results in elevated free copper levels, along with increased copper levels in the liver and urine, while serum ceruloplasmin levels are decreased.

Gene Affected:

  • The disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase responsible for excreting copper from the liver into bile.

 

Pathogenesis :

 

 

Neurofibromatosis 2 (Option A) presents with juvenile cataracts in children, retinal hamartomas, etc.

Neurofibromatosis 1 (Option C) presents with Lisch nodules that are small, raised brown spots in the iris.

Cataracts (Option D) present as wedge-shaped opacity (cortical cataract) or as dark or black lenses (nuclear cataracts) with other specific findings. The given scenario is not associated with cataracts.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room with a history of alcohol abuse, altered sensorium, and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended with palpable hepatomegaly and splenomegaly and sclerae are icteric. The other examination findings are given below. Laboratory tests show that the AST: ALT ratio is 3:1. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alcoholic liver disease

Explanation:

  • The clinical features along with the history of alcohol abuse point to the diagnosis of alcohol liver disease.

Alcohol liver disease

Pathophysiology

Alcohol Metabolism
  • Ethanol is primarily metabolized in the liver by enzymes, particularly alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1).
  • This metabolism produces acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate, which can cause cellular damage.

Oxidative Stress
  • The metabolism of alcohol generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increases oxidative stress within liver cells.
  • This oxidative damage leads to lipid peroxidation, protein modifications, and DNA damage, contributing to hepatocyte injury and inflammation.

Inflammatory Response
  • Alcohol consumption stimulates the activation of immune cells (e.g., Kupffer cells) leading to the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6).
  • These cytokines promote inflammation and can further damage hepatocytes.

Altered Lipid Metabolism
  • Alcohol disrupts normal lipid metabolism, leading to fat accumulation in liver cells (steatosis).
  • This accumulation can progress to steatohepatitis, where inflammation and liver cell injury occur.

Fibrosis and Cirrhosis
  • Chronic inflammation and injury stimulate the activation of hepatic stellate cells, which produce collagen and lead to fibrosis.
  • Over time, repeated injury can result in cirrhosis, characterized by scarring and loss of normal liver architecture.

 

Clinical features:

General
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Fever, malaise, jaundice, history of alcohol intake + (at least within last 8 weeks before symptom onset)

Abdominal
  • Right upper quadrant pain, tender hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites
  • Caput medusae: enlarged veins radiating from the umbilicus
  • Bleeding varices (portal hypertension)

Dermatological
  • Spider angioma, palmar erythema, ecchymosis

Reproductive
  • Gynaecomastia, gonadal atrophy, loss of libido, amenorrhea

Neurological
  • Peripheral neuropathy: tingling and numbness usually over feet
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: Ophthalmoplegia, confusion, ataxia + anterograde amnesia
  • Hepatic encephalopathy: Asterixis (most prominent finding), altered sensorium, sleep disturbances, lethargy

Others
  • Dupuytren’s contracture, temporal muscle wasting, parotid gland enlargement

 

Alcoholic liver disease LFT:

AST (Aspartate aminotransferase)

Non-specific ; ↑ (<300-400)

ALT (Alanine aminotransferase)

Specific for liver injury ; ↑ (<300-400)

AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1

Specific for ALD

ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)

Elevated in bile duct pathologies

GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase)

Non-specific marker of ALD

5’-Nucleotidase

Specific marker for bile duct pathologies

S.Bilirubin

Usually normal/mildly ↑

S.Albumin

↓ in chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)

Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT)

Best serum marker for alcoholic liver disease.

 

Hepatitis refers to the inflammation of the liver, which can be caused by various factors, including excessive alcohol consumption, autoimmune conditions, medications, or toxins. However, the most common cause of hepatitis is a viral infection, known as "viral hepatitis" (Option B).

Autoimmune hepatitis (Option C) is a condition characterized by chronic and progressive liver inflammation of unknown origin. It is believed to arise from a combination of genetic factors, environmental triggers, and a malfunction in the immune system, leading to ongoing inflammation of liver cells and eventual liver fibrosis. The primary symptoms of autoimmune hepatitis include fatigue, general discomfort, jaundice, abdominal pain, and occasionally joint pain.

Acetaminophen poisoning (Option D) can present as asymptomatic or vomiting in the first stage, vomiting with right upper quadrant pain and hypotension in the second stage, or liver dysfunction, renal failure, coagulopathies, metabolic acidosis, and encephalopathy and reemergence of GI symptoms in the 3rd stage. The 4th stage is marked by recovery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is experiencing chronic pain in his hands, knees, and hips, with increased pain in the hands during writing or typing. Additionally, he has morning stiffness in his joints that lasts for about 30 minutes. On examination, Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible in the hands, and an X-ray of the knee shows narrowed joint space with osteophytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Osteoarthritis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations in the given scenario and the presence of Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes point to the diagnosis of osteoarthritis.

Joint involvement in different types of arthritis:

Characteristic

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

(Option C)

Osteoarthritis (OA)

(Option B)

Psoriatic Arthritis

Gout

Reactive Arthritis

Joint Involvement Pattern

Symmetrical involvement of small joints (MCP, PIP)

Asymmetrical involvement, especially DIP joints

Asymmetrical involvement, often DIP joints

Typically involves a single joint (e.g., big toe)

Asymmetrical involvement, often larger joints

Morning Stiffness

Lasts over 1 hour

Resolves within 30 minutes

Varies, often significant

Rarely significant

Variable often follows infection

Key Symptoms

Swelling, tenderness, deformities (e.g., ulnar deviation)

Pain and stiffness with use

Dactylitis, nail changes

Sudden, severe pain and swelling

Joint pain following an infection

Affected Joints

MCP, PIP, wrists, knees

Knees, hips, hands (DIP, PIP)

MCP, PIP, and can include spine and tendons

Typically big toe (1st MTP joint)

Larger joints (e.g., knees, ankles)

Radiographic Findings

Soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing

Osteophytes, joint space narrowing

Erosions, possible nail changes

Erosions and tophi possible

Similar to RA but typically larger joints

Osteoporosis (Option A) is a condition where there is a reduction in bone mineral density and mass or a change in the quality and structure of bone. This results in weakened bones, making them more prone to fractures. Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are not seen in osteoporosis.

Bone tumour (Option D): The clinical presentation is unlikely of a bone tumour.

questions.text: A girl experiences prolonged menstrual bleeding and has normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT, but an increased bleeding time, which was determined to be due to a deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa after further analysis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia

Explanation:

In this scenario, the clinical history and laboratory findings are consistent with Glanzmann Thrombasthenia, a congenital platelet disorder characterized by defective platelet aggregation due to a lack of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors (aids in platelet-platelet adhesion).

  • rFVIIa is helpful for patients who are undergoing surgery or are refractory to platelet transfusions as it enhances thrombin generation at the site of vascular injury and can promote hemostasis despite platelet dysfunction.

Glanzmann Thrombasthenia

  • Congenital bleeding disorder
  • History of high consanguinity in marriage of the parents

Pathology:

  • Autosomal recessive inheritance
  • Mutations involving chromosome 17
  • Absence of the platelet Gp IIb/IIIa receptor
  • These receptors are essential for platelet aggregation and hemostasis

Clinical Features:

  • Lifelong mucocutaneous bleeding episodes
  • Epistaxis is very common in children
  • Gingival bleeds
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding
  • Menorrhagia

Investigations:

Tests

Results

aPTT, PT, and ristocetin cofactor activity

Normal

Bleeding time

Increased

Light transmission aggregometry (LTA) (gold standard test)

Altered platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and epinephrine.

Normal aggregation with ristocetin.

Flow cytometry

Defective expression of alpha IIb beta 3 integrin

Molecular genetic tests

Gene mutations in ITGA2B or ITGB3

 

Treatment:

Therapy

Clinical setting

Desmopressin

Mild bleeding

Platelets and/or recombinant activated clotting factor VII (rFVIIa)

Surgery prophylaxis

Tranexamic acid

Mucocutaneous bleeding

Recombinant FVIIa

Platelet refractoriness cases
  • Platelet transfusions have the risk of alloimmunization. So, HLA-matched single donor platelets for transfusion are preferred.

 

Bernard-Soulier syndrome (BSS) (Option A), also referred to as Hemorrhagiparous Thrombolytic Dystrophy, is a rare genetic bleeding disorder marked by the presence of abnormally large platelets, a low platelet count (thrombocytopenia), and extended bleeding time. It usually presents at birth and continues throughout life.

Hemophilia A (Option C): Severe haemophilia typically presents in the first few months of life, while mild or moderate forms are usually detected later in childhood or adolescence, often incidentally or after trauma, with two-thirds of cases confirmed shortly after the birth of an affected son to a carrier mother. The aPTT is abnormally elevated with a normal PT.

Not all individuals with von Willebrand disease (Option D) experience clinically significant bleeding issues, leading many cases to go undiagnosed. In the coagulation profile, aPTT may be prolonged and PT is normal. The von Willebrand factor

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated fractures for the past 2 years. On examination, blue sclera and dental abnormalities are noted. There is a family history of similar complaints. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteogenesis imperfecta

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) based on the classic triad of repeated fractures, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities, along with a positive family history.

 

Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI):

  • It is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for producing type I collagen, which is the primary component of the bone matrix. This defective collagen synthesis leads to brittle bones, resulting in frequent fractures from minimal trauma. Additional clinical features like blue sclerae, hearing loss, and joint hypermobility are also seen in OI.

 

 

Features of Osteogenesis Imperfecta:

Pathophysiology

Defective type I collagen synthesis

Genetic Mutations

Type I-IV: COL1A1, COL1A2

Type V: IFITM5

Type VI: SERPINF1

Key Clinical Features

Recurrent fractures from minimal trauma, blue sclerae, hearing loss, joint hypermobility, osteopenia

Complications

Cardiopulmonary issues (pneumonia, cor pulmonale), neurological complications (basilar invagination, brainstem compression)

Differential Diagnosis

Rickets, osteopetrosis, and disorders related to abnormal calcium metabolism

Treatment

Physical rehabilitation, Bisphosphonates, growth hormone, orthopedic management (fracture care, surgery)

 

Scurvy (Option A) is a vitamin C deficiency disorder characterized by weakness, fatigue, joint pain, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. While it can cause bone abnormalities, it does not present with blue sclera or repeated fractures.

Rickets (Option B) results in impaired bone mineralization and skeletal deformities due to vitamin D deficiency or metabolism disorders, but does not present with blue sclera and dental abnormalities.

Osteomalacia (Option D) is characterized by softening of bones due to impaired mineralization caused by vitamin D deficiency in adults. However it does not present with repeated fractures in children.

questions.text: A patient exhibits symptoms of increased urination, nighttime urination, and involuntary urination, along with a recorded 24-hour urine volume of 7 litres. He has a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L. The ADH assay shows a recorded value of 0.8 pg/ml, and an MRI of the brain reveals the absence of a bright spot on T1-weighted imaging. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pituitary DI

Explanation:

  • The above case is most suggestive of pituitary diabetes insipidus. The absence of a pituitary bright spot is suggestive of central DI.

Feature

Central DI

(Option C)

Nephrogenic DI

(Option A)

Primary Polydipsia

(Option B)

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake suppresses AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection does not affect severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

The posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioural therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment is usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause
  • Lithium-induced NDI may persist.
  • Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause.
  • Usually, it resolves after delivery.

 

In mannitol infusion (Option D), the urine osmolality is >300 mOsm/L.

questions.text: A patient was asked to copy the face of a clock and his drawing is shown below. What is the correct term to be used here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hemispatial neglect

Explanation:

  • The given image represents the patient suffering from hemispatial neglect where there are missing details in the left side of the line drawing.

Hemispatial Neglect:

  • Hemispatial neglect is the inability to report, respond, and orient to stimuli in one-half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits.

Types and location of lesions:

  • Contralesional Hemispatial Neglect:
    • Result of damage to cortical or subcortical components of the spatial attention network.
    • Not always caused by parietal lobe lesions, as traditionally believed.
  • Spatial Attention Model:
    • Right hemisphere: Directs attention to the entire extrapersonal space.
    • Left hemisphere: Directs attention mostly to the right hemispace (contralateral).
    • Left hemisphere lesions: Minor neglect, as the right hemisphere compensates.
    • Right hemisphere lesions: Severe neglect of the left hemispace due to lack of ipsilateral attentional mechanisms in the left hemisphere.

Clinical Examination:

  • Patients may neglect grooming, eating, and reading on the left side.
  • Line drawing and writing often have missing details on the left side.
  • Tests for neglect:
    • Simultaneous Bilateral Stimulation: Patients fail to detect bilateral stimuli and experience extinction (only detecting stimuli from the right side).
    • Target Detection Task: Difficulty detecting targets on the left side, reflecting a motor and attentional deficit rather than sensory input loss (hemianopia).
  • Some patients may deny the existence of hemiparesis or even the paralyzed limb (anosognosia).

Clinical Observation:

  • Neglect is more common, severe, and long-lasting after right hemisphere damage.
  • Severe neglect of the right hemispace is rare even with left hemisphere lesions.

 

Confabulation (Option A) is a phenomenon in which the patient fills in memory gaps with made-up stories and inaccurate facts.

Kinetic apraxia (Option C) is the inability to perform a fine movement or task despite having the desire and physical capability to do it. The lesion lies in the paracentral cortex.

Asterixis (Option D) is a type of negative myoclonus where irregular lapses of the posture of body parts are noted.

questions.text: A male patient in his youth comes to the clinic complaining of a persistent high fever over the past 5 days. During the examination of his hands, painless lesions are observed, and a new regurgitant murmur is detected. The echocardiogram reveals the existence of a mass on the mitral valve. Based on these findings, which of the following abdominal findings would be expected in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Splenomegaly

Explanation:

  • The presence of high-grade fever, painless lesions on the hands (Janeway lesions), and a new regurgitant murmur suggests the possibility of infective endocarditis. The most likely abdomen finding in this case would be splenomegaly.

Acute Bacterial Endocarditis

  • Aggressive course compared to subacute endocarditis.
  • Causative organisms: S. aureus (Most common cause) (including MRSA), S. pneumoniae, L. monocytogenes, Haemophilus species, streptococci (groups A, B, G).
  • Risk factors: Comorbid conditions like malignancy, diabetes mellitus, IV drug use, or alcoholism.
  • Presentation:
    • Fever, fatigue, and malaise within <2 weeks of infection.
    • Changing heart murmur, potential congestive heart failure.
    • Possible signs:
      • Janeway lesions (hemorrhagic macules on palms/soles), petechiae
      • Roth’s spots
      • Splinter haemorrhages
      • Splenomegaly (rare). (Option B)
  • Peripheral manifestations:

Janeway lesions:

Painless, erythematous macules on palms and soles. Related to septic microembolization,

 

Osler’s nodes:

Small painful pea-shaped nodules located at the tips of fingers and toes (Immune complex-mediated).

Subungual haemorrhages/Splinter haemorrhages;

More common in acute S. aureus IE. Haemorrhages below nails- multiple linear lesions, initially red then turning brown or black.

Roth spots:

Pale-centred retinal haemorrhages that are seen in the fundus examination
  • Arterial emboli: Occur in up to 50% of patients, often preceding IE diagnosis, causing organ dysfunction (e.g., stroke, kidney, spleen, or limb ischemia).
  • Neurologic complications: Strokes complicate 15-35% of cases; also include encephalopathy, seizures, meningitis, intracranial haemorrhage, mycotic aneurysms, and brain abscesses.
  • Renal complications: Hypocomplementemic glomerulonephritis due to immune complex deposition, often improving with antimicrobial therapy; renal infarcts may cause flank pain and hematuria.

 

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Defibrillation

Explanation:

  • The given ECG shows ventricular fibrillation and the next step of management is defibrillation since this is a shockable rhythm.

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Ventricular Fibrillation

Asystole

Ventricular Tachycardia

Pulseless Electrical Activity

 

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation (Option A)

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (Option C) (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Immediate Recognition

Identify Non-Shockable Rhythm: Recognize asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA).

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓
Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓
Establish intravenous or intraosseous lines for medication administration.

↓
Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Administer IV/IO after the first 2 minutes of CPR.

↓

Identify Rhythm

  • Non-Shockable Rhythm: Continue CPR and administer epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.

Goal: To increase the likelihood of developing a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is necessary for effective defibrillation.

  • Shockable Rhythm: Administer a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

↓
Advanced Airway Management

Airway: Secure the airway with endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation for adequate oxygenation.

↓
Continue CPR

Resume chest compressions for 2 minutes.

↓
Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Primary Focus: Address reversible causes, especially hypothermia.

↓
Repeat CPR and Epinephrine

Cycle: Continue repeating CPR and epinephrine administration every 3-5 minutes.

 

Synchronized cardioversion (Option B) is used to reset the abnormal heart rhythm and is given in synchronisation with the R wave in the ECG (delivered at the peak of the R wave). It is performed in arrhythmias where the heart is still contracting but irregularly, such as Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT), Atrial Fibrillation (AF), and Atrial Flutter.

0.5 mg atropine (Option D) is indicated for symptomatic bradycardia and bot in a pulseless patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pheochromocytoma

Explanation:

  • The elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine with the given clinical features suggests phaeochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Epidemiology
  • Estimated to occur in 2 to 8 of 1 million persons per year.
  • The mean age at diagnosis is 40 years, although the tumours can occur from early childhood until late in life.
  • The classic ‘rule of tens’ is 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal (Paragangliomas), and 10% metastatic. It is not used nowadays.

Etiopathogenesis
  • These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1,
    • multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and
    • Von-Hippel Lindau disease.
  • Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).
  • Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Norepinephrine is released continuously and can result in persistent hypertension, while epinephrine is released in a paroxysmal pattern resulting in tachyarrhythmias.
    • Ryanodine-2 receptors (RyR2).
    • Beta-2 adrenoceptors
    • Alpha(1)-adrenoreceptors

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • The dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection.
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

 

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

 

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

 

Fibromuscular dysplasia (Option A) is a systemic vascular disease that is the cause of 10% to 20% of renal artery stenosis. This presents with resistant hypertension, hematuria, flank pain, renal infarct, hypokalemia, and abdominal bruit.

Renal artery stenosis (Option C) can cause hypertension, but it does not typically present with sudden-onset headaches, palpitations, and profuse sweating.

Hyperthyroidism (Option D) can cause symptoms such as palpitations and sweating. However, sudden-onset headaches and episodes of high blood pressure are not typical features of this condition.

questions.text: A patient who is 66 years old and has a history of chronic hypertension, arrives at the emergency room with changes in mental state and high blood pressure measuring 210/110 mm Hg. A brain CT scan shows bleeding within the brain tissue. The typical location of this bleeding in similar cases is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Putamen

Explanation:

The features are of intraparenchymal hemorrhage due to hypertension which occurs in the deep tissues of the brain. The most common site of this is putamen.

  • The sudden elevation in blood pressure can overwhelm cerebral autoregulation
  • Most commonly affects small penetrating arteries (lenticulostriate arteries)

Common causes of intracerebral haemorrhage include:

  • Hypertension (most common - affecting basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, cerebellum)
  • Drug use (cocaine, methamphetamine) - especially in young patients
  • Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (elderly, lobar haemorrhages)
  • Coagulopathy
  • Vascular malformations
  • Head trauma
  • Hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke

Direct vessel wall damage:

  • While cocaine can cause endothelial dysfunction over time
  • Direct vessel wall damage is more associated with chronic use
  • Acute haemorrhage is primarily due to pressure effects
  • More relevant in chronic vasculopathy

Vasculitis:

  • This can occur with chronic cocaine use
  • Usually presents with multiple vascular territories
  • More commonly causes ischemic events
  • Takes time to develop and isn't the acute mechanism

Amyloid deposition:

  • Typically occurs in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Associated with lobar haemorrhages
  • Caused by β-amyloid deposition in vessel walls

Feature

Cerebral Amyloid

Angiopathy (CAA)

Berry Aneurysm Rupture

Hypertensive Crisis

Venous Sinus Thrombosis

Age Group

Elderly (>60 years)

Younger

Older, with chronic HTN

Younger, hypercoagulable states

Hypertension

None

None

Chronic HTN

None

Hemorrhage Type

Multiple lobar haemorrhages

Subarachnoid, single-event

Deep (e.g., putamen, thalamus)

Hemorrhagic infarction

Hemorrhage Location

Cortical-subcortical regions

Subarachnoid space

Deep brain structures

Venous infarction

Imaging

Lobar haemorrhages, microbleeds

Single, subarachnoid bleed

Deep hemorrhage

Venous infarction pattern

Symptoms

Acute neurological symptoms

Thunderclap headache

Often no symptoms

Seizures, focal deficits

Onset

Acute neurological presentation

Sudden, thunderclap headache

Acute, with chronic HTN

Acute, gradual progression

Distribution

Spares deep structures

Focal

Deep brain

Venous infarction

While intraparenchymal haemorrhage can occur in other brain regions, such as the thalamus (Option B), pons (Option C), or cerebellum (Option D), the putamen is the most commonly affected site in cases of chronic hypertension-associated haemorrhage.

  • The positive Anti-HBc and negative HBsAg indicate an infection in the near/ remote past but has resolved now.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with changes in the hand as shown below. There is decreased motion in the small joints and loss of wrinkle lines on the facial skin. Her chest radiograph showed prominent bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Scleroderma

Explanation:

  • The changes in the hand as given below and the absence of wrinkles on face and other features point to the diagnosis of scleroderma or systemic sclerosis showing its dermal manifestations.

Dermal Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc)

  • Bilateral Symmetrical Skin Thickening: Begins distally in the fingers and progresses proximally.
  • Skin Pigmentation Changes:
    • Early diffuse tanning without sun exposure.
    • Hypopigmentation with a "salt-and-pepper" appearance on the scalp, upper back, and chest is common in dark-skinned individuals.
  • Sclerosis of Skin and Loss of Appendages:
    • Leads to hair loss, reduced sweating, xerosis, and itching.
    • Disappearance of transverse finger creases and fixed flexion contractures causing muscle atrophy.
  • Fixed Contractures: Affects wrists, elbows, and knees due to skin and tendon fibrosis.
  • Neck Skin Ridges: Firm adherence to platysma muscle limits neck extension.
  • Facial Changes ("Mauskopf"):
    • Taut, shiny skin with loss of wrinkles and reduced mobility.
    • Thinned lips, prominent perioral radial furrows, and microstomia.
    • Pinched, beak-like nose.
  • Telangiectasia: Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity.
  • Skin Ulcerations:
    • Chronic ulcers on fingertips, PIP joints, and bony prominences heal slowly and may become infected.
    • Fingertip ischemia leaves fixed digital "pits."
  • Acro-Osteolysis: Resorption of terminal phalanges due to ischemia.
  • Calcinosis Cutis:
    • Dystrophic calcifications in the skin and soft tissues, commonly in patients with anti-centromere antibody–positive lcSSc.
    • Calcific deposits vary in size and may ulcerate, causing pain, infections, or nerve compression.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A) has symmetrical involvement of small joints, morning stiffness lasting for more than 1 hour, and classical deformities in severe cases. The given scenario does not include symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option C) presents with fatigue, joint pain, photosensitive rash, mouth ulcers, and hair loss. The given clinical scenario is not of SLE.

Pneumonia (Option D) is an infection of the pulmonary parenchyma, classified into community-acquired (CAP), hospital-acquired (HAP) and ventilator-associated (VAP). It does not present as the given scenario. It presents with fever, cough with characteristic sputum, chest pain, headache, chills, etc.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with weakness in right arm for 6 hours. The weakness gradually became lesser and later resolved. She is a known case of diabetes and hypertension and is obese. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transient ischaemic attack

Explanation:

  • Based on the given clinical presentation, the probable diagnosis in this case is Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA).

Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA)

  • Defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction due to the focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without acute infarction or tissue injury.
  • A TIA typically lasts less than an hour, more often minutes.
  • Usually resolves within 24 hours.
  • Risk is highest in the first 48 hours following a transient ischemic attack.

Etiology:

  • Common risk factors for all TIA include diabetes, hypertension, age, smoking, obesity, alcoholism, unhealthy diet, psychosocial stress, and lack of regular physical activity.
  • A previous history of stroke or TIA will increase substantially the subsequent risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

Pathophysiology:

TIA subtypes, classified according to the pathophysiological mechanisms

  • Large artery atherothrombosis (M/C): This may be intracranial or extracranial atherothrombosis. The mechanism may be a lack of blood flow distal to the site of arterial stenosis or an artery-to-artery embolism.
  • Small vessel ischemic diseases: The underlying pathology is either lipohyalinosis or small vessel arteriolosclerosis. The commonest risk factor is hypertension, followed by diabetes and age.
  • Cardiac embolism: A clot in the cardiac chamber, most commonly in the left atrium, is secondary to atrial fibrillation.
  • Cryptogenic: This is usually a cortical pattern of ischemia without any identifiable large artery atherothrombosis or cardiac source of emboli. More recently it is often referred to as ESUS (embolic stroke of unknown source).
  • Other uncommon causes such as arterial dissection or vasculitis.

ABCD2 Score for TIA (Transient Ischemic Attack): The Risk of Stroke

Parameter

Criteria

Points

Age

> 60 years

1 point

Blood Pressure

BP ≥ 140/90

1 point

Clinical Features

Speech disturbance without weakness

1 point

Unilateral weakness

2 points

Duration

10–59 minutes

1 point

≥ 60 minutes

2 points

Diabetes

Presence of diabetes

1 point

 

Stroke Risk Based on Score:

Score

Stroke Risk

Day 2

Day 7

Day 90

0–3

1%

1.2%

3.1%

4–5

4.1%

5.9%

9.8%

6–7

8.1%

11.7%

17.8%

 

Compressive neuropathy typically (Option A) results in persistent symptoms rather than transient symptoms as described in the case.

Ischaemic stroke (Option C) involves a more prolonged disruption of blood flow to a specific area of the brain, leading to persistent neurological deficits that do not resolve within 24 hours.

Diabetic neuropathy (Option D) is unlikely to cause transient weakness limited to one side of the body, as seen in this case.

questions.text: What is the formula of crude birth rate?

choices.text: (Total number of births / Estimated midyear Population) 1,000
(Number of live births / Estimated midyear women Population) 1,000
(Number of live births/ Estimated midyear Population) 1,000
(Number of live births / Estimated midyear Population) 1,0000

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) (Number of live births/ Estimated midyear Population) 1,000.

Explanation:

 

Crude birth rates

Definition

Number of live births per 1000 estimated

mid-year population in a given year.

Formula

Statistics

India’s current CBR is 19.5/1000 mid-year population. (2020)

Drawbacks

It gives a rough measure of fertility by giving birth rates, and not everyone in the population is exposed to childbirth.

Note: The crude birth rate does not include stillbirths.

questions.text: What clinical examination is being performed in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fluid thrill

Explanation:

  • The examination being done here is fluid thrill or fluid wave test which helps determine the presence of large volumes of fluid in the abdomen.

Clinical manifestations

  • Initially asymptomatic
  • Approximately 1-2 litres of fluid show signs and symptoms, including:
    • Abdominal distension, discomfort, pain.
    • Weight gain (sudden)
    • Nausea, vomiting
    • Respiratory distress having shortness of breath, dyspnea
    • Edema of body parts
    • Everted umbilicus (due to an increase in ascitic fluid)

                                       Ascites (Option B)

  • Clinical signs:
    • Puddle sign (Peritoneal fluid >100ml) (Option C) The puddle sign detects small amounts of fluid in the abdomen. In a sitting position, tapping the abdomen produces a distinct sound over fluid, indicating ascites.

 

Shifting dullness (peritoneal fluid >500ml) (Option A) In a supine position, a healthcare provider percusses the abdomen to identify dullness (fluid) and resonance (air). When the patient turns to one side, the fluid shifts, causing dullness to move to the dependent side and resonance to appear on the upper side, indicating ascitic fluid.

Fluid thrill or fluid wave test (Option D) The fluid thrill is a sign of large abdominal fluid volumes (more than 1.5 Liters). It occurs when a provider taps one side of the abdomen while feeling the opposite, creating a wave indicating ascites.

 

 

  • Hepatic hydrothorax
    • Fluid from the abdomen, usually due to cirrhosis, accumulates in the pleural cavity, typically on the right side, causing shortness of breath and chest discomfort.
  • Abdominal compartment syndrome (intra-abdominal hypertension) can occur if the pressure due to ascites is more than 25 mm Hg.

questions.text: Which of the following leads to a continuous murmur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Peripheral Pulmonic stenosis

Explanation:

  • Peripheral Pulmonic stenosis produces a characteristic continuous murmur due to persistent turbulent blood flow through narrowed pulmonary artery branches. This congenital condition creates turbulence in blood flow that begins in systole, peaks near the second heart sound, and continues through diastole. The continuous nature of the murmur occurs because the pressure gradient between the pulmonary artery and its branches remains throughout the cardiac cycle, maintaining constant turbulent flow.

Continuous murmur

Definition
  • Murmur that persists across systole and diastole
  • Begins in at S1, continues through second heart sound (S2) and tapers at next S1

Causes
  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
  • Peripheral Pulmonic stenosis
  • Valsalva aneurysm
  • Aortopulmonary window
  • Great vessel arteriovenous fistula
  • Coronary to pulmonic fistula

 

Severe Pulmonary artery hypertension (Option B) typically causes leakage of blood into the RV during the diastole due to the high pressure in the pulmonary arteries, characteristically producing a diastolic murmur.

Type A aortic dissection (Option C) is a medical emergency and the presentation mainly accompanies classical signs like blood pressure discrepancies between the upper extremities, pulse deficits & hypotension. Murmur is rarely seen and if seen its mostly diastolic murmur.

Rupture of cardiac chamber (Option D) is a medical emergency. The hemodynamic compromise would be severe and acute, leading to cardiogenic shock and unrecordable BP. No murmur will be heard.

questions.text: Which factor has the greatest impact on positive predictive value?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Prevalence

Explanation:

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease it detects, i.e., PPV increases as the prevalence increases provided the sensitivity and specificity of the test remains unchanged over the course of time (since prevalence can be considered as the pre-test probability of a disease)

Example:

  • Total population of a town is 2000.
  • Prevalence of a disease at three different time periods are 10,20 and 30% based on a definitive investigation.
  • Sensitivity and specificity of a new test are 40% & 70% respectively

Since the sensitivity & specificity are going to be considered as constants throughout, the number of true positives and hence the positive predictive values will increase proportionately to the given prevalences over these three different time periods.

 

Sensitivity (Option A): Sensitivity impacts the true positive rate, not PPV.

Specificity (Option C): Specificity affects the true negative rate, not PPV.

Relative Risk (Option D): Relative risk does not affect PPV.

questions.text: Yaws is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - T. Pertunae

Explanation:

Yaws is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Treponema pertenue, which is a subspecies of the Treponema genus. It primarily affects the skin, bones, and joints and is transmitted through direct, non-sexual contact with the lesions of an infected person, commonly in tropical regions.

Treponema is a genus of spiral-shaped bacteria that are pathogenic to humans.

Spirochetes are spiral hair-like organisms. They are classified as follows.

Shape- Treponemes are corkscrew-shaped cells 6 to 15 μm long and 0.1 to 0.2 μm wide.

Structure- Treponemes have an outer membrane, a peptidoglycan-cytoplasmic membrane complex, and a protoplasmic cylinder.

Movement: Treponemes have flagella that extend from motors at the pole, producing undulating movement through fluids: corkscrew motility.

  • Treponema pallidum: The causative organism of Venereal syphilis. It is generally acquired by close sexual contact.
  • Treponema pertenue: Causes yaws. It is acquired via skin-to-skin contact. (Option A)
  • Treponema carateum: Causes pinta. It is acquired via skin-to-skin contact. (Option C ruled out)
  • Treponema endemicium: Causes endemic syphilis. It is acquired via kissing. (Option B ruled out)
  • Treponema paraluiscuniculi: Associated with syphilis in rabbits.
  • Treponema phagedenis- Normal GUT flora- Reiter’s strain
  • Treponema refringens- Normal GUT flora- Noguchi’s strain

Hemophilus (Option D): This genus refers to Haemophilus species, which are bacteria responsible for different infections like Haemophilus influenzae, causing respiratory infections, but it is not related to yaws.

questions.text: Which of the following is a crucial element involved in activating the complement through the alternative pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - C3:

Explanation:

  • The alternative pathway of complement activation is primarily initiated by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 to form C3(H2O), which then binds to factor B. This activates the pathway and leads to the formation of the C3 convertase, which plays a key role in the amplification of the complement cascade.
  • In the alternative pathway, C3 is crucial for both the activation and amplification of the complement system, as it is cleaved to form C3a and C3b, which further participate in opsonization, inflammation, and cell lysis.

Complement System:

  • Definition: A complex network of at least 30 proteins in the blood, crucial for innate and acquired immunity.
  • Functions:
    • Lysis: Directly kills pathogens by forming membrane pores.
    • Opsonization: Coats pathogens to enhance recognition and uptake by phagocytes.
    • Immune Clearance: Removes immune complexes from circulation.
    • Inflammation: Triggers release of mediators, recruiting immune cells.

Pathways of Complement Activation:

Pathway

Trigger Mechanism

Key Components Involved

Classical Pathway

Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes

C1q (Option A ruled out), C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC)

Alternative Pathway

Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens

C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase

Lectin Pathway

Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose

MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4 (Option D ruled out), C2 (Option B ruled out), C3 convertase

Key Points:

  • Convergence: All pathways converge at the formation of the C3 convertase.
  • C3 Convertase: Cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b, leading to the formation of C5 convertase and, ultimately, MAC.
  • Regulation: The complement system is tightly regulated to prevent excessive activation and damage to host tissues.
  • Regulatory Proteins: Include inhibitors and inactivators that control the cascade.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an enrichment medium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - All of the above

Explanation:

Enrichment Broth:

  • Liquid media with inhibitory agents selectively promote the growth of specific organisms and inhibit others.
  • Used for isolating pathogens from clinical specimens containing normal flora (e.g., stool, sputum).

Examples:

  1. Tetrathionate broth – Used for Salmonella Typhi isolation.
  2. Gram-negative broth – Used for Shigella isolation.
  3. Selenite F broth – Used for Shigella isolation. (Option C)
  4. Alkaline peptone water (APW) – Used for Vibrio cholerae isolation. (Option A)
  5. Lim Broth is an enrichment broth specifically used to enhance the growth of group B streptococci. It provides the necessary nutrients and conditions for the selective multiplication of these organisms.
  6. Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water (Option B)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about tremors are true?


	PD is characterized by resting tremor
	Tremor consist of alternate contraction of agonist and antagonist muscle in an oscillating rhythmic manner
	Essential tremor is an uncommon movement disorder.
	Normal individuals can have physiologic tremors that manifest as mild high frequency, postural or action tremors
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1,2,4 only

Explanation:

Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder, affecting approximately 5-10% of the general population, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. It usually presents as a bilateral postural 6 to 12 Hz tremor of the hands and head. The Movement Disorders Society diagnostic criteria include:

  • Tremor is bilateral, symmetrical, and postural
  • The tremor involves the forearms and hand
  • Is persistent and visible
  • It may be associated with isolated head tremor

Causes and characteristics of tremors

Type of Tremor

Cause

Characteristics

Exacerbating Factors

Alleviating Factors

Resting Tremor

Parkinson's disease
  • Occurs at rest
  • Pill-rolling movement
  • Asymmetrical
  • Emotional stress
  • Fatigue

Voluntary movement

Action Tremor
  • Cerebellar disorders
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Tremor occurs with voluntary movement
  • Intention tremor (worsens near target)

Movement initiation

Rest

Postural Tremor
  • Essential tremor
  • Physiologic tremor
  • Tremor when maintaining posture against gravity
  • Fine or coarse oscillations
  • Anxiety
  • Fatigue
  • Caffeine
  • Alcohol
  • Beta-blockers

Intention Tremor

Cerebellar damage

Increases in amplitude as the target is approached

Goal-directed movements

Rest

Physiologic Tremor

Normal individuals

Fine, rapid, low-amplitude tremor
  • Anxiety
  • Caffeine
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Rest
  • Sleep

Essential Tremor (Most Common Tremors)

Unknown (often familial)
  • Bilateral, symmetric
  • Affects hands, head, voice
  • Stress
  • Fatigue
  • Alcohol
  • Beta-blockers

Dystonic Tremor

Dystonia
  • Irregular tremor
  • Associated with abnormal postures

Movement or sustained posture

Sensory tricks (geste antagonists)

Drug-induced Tremor
  • Lithium
  • Valproate
  • SSRIs
  • Symmetric, postural, or action tremor

Drug use

Dose reduction or discontinuation

Psychogenic Tremor

Functional neurologic disorder
  • Sudden onset
  • Inconsistent tremor
  • Disappears with distraction

Psychological stress
  • Distraction
  • Psychotherapy

 

Parkinson's Disease (PD) is characterized by a classic resting tremor (Statement 1 Ruled Out) which occurs at rest and decreases with intentional movement.

Tremor physiology involves the alternating contraction of opposing muscle groups (agonist and antagonist) in a rhythmic pattern. (Statement 2 Ruled Out)

Physiologic tremors are a normal phenomenon that can occur in healthy individuals, particularly during certain postures or actions. (Statement 4 Ruled Out)

Statement 3 regarding essential tremor being uncommon and affecting 5% of the population is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is amplified in an RT-PCR test for the COVID-19 virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - DNA

Explanation:

  • In an RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR) test for COVID-19, the RNA of the virus is first reverse-transcribed into DNA by the enzyme reverse transcriptase. This step is essential because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) works with DNA, not RNA. The RNA is converted into complementary DNA (cDNA), which is then amplified in the PCR process to detect the presence of the virus.

Real-Time RT-PCR for COVID-19 Diagnosis

  • Real-time reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) is the gold standard for diagnosing COVID-19.
  • Turnaround Time: The average time from sample receipt to result generation is approximately 4-5 hours.
  • Capacity: Can process up to 90 samples in a single run, making it efficient for frontline testing.
  • Gene Targets:
    • Screening (Genus Specific):
      • Spike protein (S)
      • Envelope protein (E)
      • Membrane protein (M)
      • Nucleocapsid protein (N)
    • Confirmation (Species Specific for SARS-CoV-2):
      • RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp)
      • Open reading frames (ORF1a/b)
      • N2 nucleocapsid
  • Principle of Testing:
    • Qualitative real-time PCR amplifies target genes in the specimen using a thermocycler.
    • Fluorescence is generated when the amplicon binds to the probe, with the cycle threshold (Ct) indicating positivity.
    • A sample is considered positive if both screening and confirmatory genes are detected with a Ct value ≤ 40 cycles.
  • Detectability: NAAT can be positive as early as day 1 of symptom onset (usually 5 days post-infection) and generally declines by the third week, often becoming undetectable thereafter.

Automated Real-Time RT-PCR

  • Systems include Truenat and CBNAAT (Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test, e.g., GeneXpert).
  • Widely accessible
  • Turnaround Time: Quick results in 30-60 minutes.
  • Automation: Fully automated with minimal handling, reducing biosafety hazards.
  • Gene Targets:
    • CBNAAT: E gene for screening, N2 gene for confirmation.
    • Truenat: E gene for screening, RdRp gene for confirmation.
  • Disadvantages: Limited to 1-4 samples per run, suitable for low sample loads (24-48 samples/day).

Antigen Detection

  • Rapid chromatographic immunoassay (SD Biosensor) for qualitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein.
  • Sample Collection: Nasopharyngeal swab immersed in viral extraction buffer to inactivate the virus and release the antigen.
  • Point-of-Care Testing: Conducted at the bedside within one hour; antigen stability is limited to one hour.
  • Performance: Highly specific (99–100%) but moderate sensitivity (50–84%); symptomatic but negative patients should be referred for RT-PCR testing.

Incorrect Options:

RNA (Option A): In an RT-PCR test for COVID-19, the viral RNA is converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase enzyme. This cDNA is then amplified through PCR.

Structural Protein (Option C): Structural proteins are components of the virus, but they are not the target of RT-PCR testing. RT-PCR is designed to detect and amplify the genetic material of the virus.

Envelope (Option D): The envelope is a protein that is part of the virus structure. However, the envelope protein itself is not directly amplified in RT-PCR. The test targets the viral RNA, not the proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important pathophysiological mechanism for Berry aneurysm?

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

Explanation:

  • Berry aneurysms primarily develop due to disruption of the internal elastic lamina of cerebral blood vessels. The internal elastic lamina is a critical structural component that provides tensile strength and elasticity to blood vessels. When this layer is compromised, the vessel wall becomes weakened and less able to withstand normal hemodynamic stresses, leading to outward bulging and eventual aneurysm formation.

Berry Aneurysm

Definition
  • Saccular outpouching of intracranial arterial wall
  • Represents 90% of cerebral aneurysms
  • Primary location: Circle of Willis
  • Most common sites:
    • Anterior communicating/anterior cerebral junction
    • Posterior communicating/internal carotid junction
    • Middle cerebral artery bifurcation
    • Basilar apex

Pathophysiological Mechanisms

Structural Changes:

  • Most important- Internal elastic lamina disruption
  • Media layer thinning
  • Adventitial layer remodeling

Molecular Mechanisms:

  • Inflammatory mediator activation
  • Matrix metalloproteinase upregulation
  • Vessel wall extracellular matrix degradation

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Wall shear stress elevation
  • Flow-related endothelial injury
  • Intramural stress distribution alterations

Histopathological Classification

1. Mycotic:

  • Infectious arterial wall damage
  • Distal vessel predilection
  • Inflammatory cell infiltration

2. Arteriosclerotic:

  • Intimal hyperplasia
  • Media degeneration
  • Elastic fiber fragmentation

3. Traumatic:

  • Transmural disruption
  • False lumen formation
  • Adventitial hemorrhage

Rupture Risk Stratification

Morphological Criteria:

  • Size >7mm: high risk
  • Aspect ratio >1.6
  • Daughter sac presence
  • Wall irregularity

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Systolic BP >140 mmHg
  • Flow pattern alterations
  • Intrasaccular pressure gradients

Genetic Markers:

  • Collagen deficiency
  • Elastic fiber abnormalities
