  • Matrix metalloproteinase polymorphisms

Clinical Manifestations

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Hunt-Hess grading scale correlation
  • Fisher scale for CT findings
  • Modified Rankin Scale outcomes

Mass Effect:

  • Cranial nerve compression syndromes
  • Brainstem compression sequelae
  • Hydrocephalus development

Thromboembolic Events:

  • Watershed infarction patterns
  • Perforator occlusion syndromes
  • Distal embolization phenomena

 

Endothelial injury due to HTN (Option A) while hypertension can exacerbate aneurysm formation and increase rupture risk, it is not the primary underlying cause of berry aneurysms. Hypertension acts as a contributing factor rather than the initiating defect.

Endothelial layer defect (Option C) although the endothelium can be involved in aneurysm progression, the primary defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina rather than the endothelial layer. The endothelial dysfunction is usually secondary to the underlying structural abnormality.

Adventitia defect (Option D) the adventitial layer is the outer layer of blood vessels and is not the primary site of berry aneurysm formation. The key pathology begins in the internal elastic lamina and medial layer of the vessel wall.

questions.text: Which of the options below could have been discarded in the white bag by the compounder as biomedical waste?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Sharp waste

Explanation:

  • Biomedical wastes disposed of in white bags contain sharps. They are not pretreated and they are recycled or reused after shredding.

 

Colour

Waste Type

Type of bag or container to be used

Method of disposal

Yellow
  • All infectious waste.
  • Human anatomical waste. (Option A ruled out)
  • Animal anatomical waste
  • Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags).
  • Expired or discarded medicines
  • Chemical waste.
  • Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Incineration
  • Plasma pyrolysis
  • Deep burial

Red
  • Contaminated waste (recyclable): Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves. (Option D ruled out)
  • Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

Blue
  • Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste. (Option C ruled out)
  • Metallic body implants.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

White
  • Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. (Option B)
  • Puncture proof and leak proof containers.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

questions.text: A 45-year patient working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asbestosis

Explanation:

The clinical presentation indicates asbestosis, a form of pneumoconiosis caused by prolonged asbestos exposure. The key diagnostic features in this case include the patient's 20-year occupational exposure in a factory setting, presenting symptom of breathlessness, and most importantly, the HRCT findings of pleural thickening and fibrosis.

Pleural involvement is a characteristic feature of asbestos-related lung disease, distinguishing it from other occupational lung diseases.

Workers in the shipbuilding and construction trades, including pipe fitters and boilermakers, are occupationally exposed to asbestos.

  • Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung.
  • Past exposure to asbestos is specifically indicated by pleural plaques on chest radiographs, which are characterized by either thickening or calcification along the parietal pleura, particularly along the lower lung fields.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • Complications include carcinoma of lung and mesothelioma.

 

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option B) is characterized by small nodules diffusely distributed throughout the lungs, with upper lobe predominance and eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes. The presence of pleural thickening rather than nodular opacities makes this diagnosis less likely.

Silicosis (Option C) typically presents with multiple small nodules in the upper lung zones with a characteristic "ground-glass" appearance. The absence of these findings and the presence of pleural thickening make silicosis an unlikely diagnosis.

Berylliosis (Option D) presents with early-stage parenchymal nodules and later develops lymphadenopathy and interstitial fibrosis. The prominent pleural involvement seen in this case is not typical of berylliosis, and the exposure history doesn't suggest beryllium exposure.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with headache and cola-colored urine. His parents report throat pain 2 weeks ago. On examination, red blood cells are present in urine and his KFT is increased two fold. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis. This condition typically occurs after an infection, most commonly caused by Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. The diagnosis is supported by the classic presentation of cola-colored urine and recent history of throat infection. The condition develops due to formation of immune complexes by streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin B (SPEB), which get distributed in renal parenchyma and damage blood vessels, leading to increased protein excretion and hematuria.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)

Cause

Group A β-Hemolytic streptococci

Pathogenesis

Immune-complex mediated (Type III hypersensitivity reaction)

Clinical manifestations
  • It is more common in children and young adults.
  • History of impetigo (2-6 weeks) or pharyngitis (1-3 weeks).
  • Pulmonary oedema (shortness of breath, cough, chest pain)
  • Periorbital and pedal oedema
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy:
    • Abrupt rise in BP
    • Headache
    • Loss of consciousness
  • Features of uremia include fatigue, weakness, confusion, swelling over body parts, shortness of breath, abnormal urine output, nausea, and vomiting.

Test for antibodies
  • Anti- DNAse
  • Anti-Hyaluronidase
  • ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer

Lab findings

  • Urine analysis: Red-colored urine, which turns dark (cola-colored) on standing (hematuria).
  • Raised values of renal function test (serum creatinine, urea, etc).
  • Raised serum potassium
  • Low serum levels of C3, IgG & CH50
  • Normal serum C4 level.

Pathological findings
  • Gross findings: Flea-bitten appearance of kidneys

 

  • Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli (increased number of neutrophils, macrophages, endothelial and mesangial cells).

 

  • Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps (due to immune complex deposition)

 

  • Immunofluorescence study: A starry-sky appearance (Granular) is observed (due to immune complex deposition).

Management

  • Self-limiting disorder
  • Conservative and supportive management involves:
    • HTN crisis: Labetalol (IV), sodium nitroprusside
    • Pulmonary edema: Furosemide
    • Antibiotics (Benzathine penicillin)
    • Dialysis if needed

 

Minimal change disease (Option A) is characterized by minimal changes in the glomeruli on microscopic examination and commonly presents in children with proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. The absence of significant proteinuria and presence of hematuria rules out this diagnosis.

Membranous Glomerulonephritis (Option B) typically presents with thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposits, causing proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. The acute onset and recent history of throat infection makes this diagnosis less likely.

IgA nephropathy (Option D) is characterized by IgA deposits in the mesangium and typically develops within 48 hours after an upper respiratory tract infection. The timing of symptoms (2 weeks after throat pain) and the classic cola-colored urine presentation makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: Which of the following fertility indicator can change with changes in age-specific mortality rates?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Net reproductive rate

Explanation:

Net reproductive rate (NRR)

Definition

NRR is the number of daughters or girls a newborn will bear or have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates.

Interpretation

  • It is the most sensitive indicator to evaluate National family planning program
  • It is a mortality-dependent fertility indicator. (Option D)
  • It is the best measure of growth of a population.

 

General Fertility Rate (Option A): General fertility rate (GFR) measures total live births per 1,000 women in reproductive age, not affected by mortality rates.

Total Fertility Rate (Option B): Total Fertility Rate (TFR) estimates average children per woman throughout reproductive age, unaffected by mortality rates.

Gross Reproduction Rate (Option C): Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR) estimates average girls per woman throughout reproductive age, but doesn't consider mortality rates.

questions.text: In a village with a given population, the total number of live births in a year is 4000. 40 newborns died within the first 7 days of life whereas 40 died due to various causes between 8 to 28 days of life. There were 50 deaths between the age of 1 month to 6 months of life and O of them died in utero. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) 20

Explanation:

Neonatal mortality rate (NMR) calculation:

  • NMR = (Number of neonatal deaths/Total number of live births) x 1,000
  • Given:
    • Total live births = 4,000, Deaths (0-7 days) = 40
    • Deaths (8-28 days) = 40 NMR ((40+40)/4,000) x 1,000 = (80/4,000) x 1,000 = 0.02 x 1,000 = 20
  • Interpretation: The NMR in this population is 20 per 1,000 live births, indicating 20 deaths within the first 28 days of life per 1,000 live births.

 

Causes of Neonatal deaths:

Most common cause - Birth Asphyxia or Hypoxia

Other causes: Prematurity and low birth weight, neonatal pneumonia, sepsis, congenital anomalies, diarrhea, injuries, and other non-communicable diseases.

Danger Signs: Refusal to feed, lethargic, cold to touch, difficult or rapid breathing, convulsions, persistent vomiting, jaundice at birth, blue color of extremities.

 

Other Neonatal Mortality Indicators:

Early neonatal mortality rate

 

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 0 – 7 days of life / live births) x 1000)

Late neonatal mortality rate

 

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 8th – 28 days of

life / live birth) x 1000)

Post neonatal mortality rate

 

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 29th day - 1 year of life / live births) x 1000)

questions.text: How many individuals are allocated to one ASHA worker for the population in rural areas?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) 1000

Explanation:

  • An ASHA worker is a grass root level worker who is elected by a village panchayat and under the supervision of a medical officer. The existing population norm is 1/1000. The proposed population norm is 2/1000.

 

ASHA should be:

  • A resident of the same village
  • A married/divorced/single woman
  • Preferably from the age group 25-45
  • Educated up to class 10
  • One ASHA for 1000 population/per habitation

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Cryptococcus

Explanation:

  • The India ink stain (A type of negative stain) is specifically used to visualize the capsule surrounding Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF samples.

  • A clear halo around the yeast cells indicates the presence of the capsule, which is an important virulence factor.

  • Urease test positive

  • Maltese cross appearance under polarising microscope

Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis .

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors

  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.

  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.

  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:

    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.

    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

 

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells

  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture

  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.

  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.

  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine

  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.

  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.

  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

Incorrect Options:

Aspergillus (Option A): Aspergillus species are molds, not yeasts, and they do not have a thick capsule. They do not stain well with India ink.

Penicillium (Option B): Penicillium is also a mold, and like Aspergillus, it lacks a thick capsule and is not typically identified using India ink.

Candida (Option D): While Candida species are yeasts, they do not have the same thick, gelatinous capsule that would be visible with India ink staining. Candida is typically diagnosed using other methods like Gram staining or culture.

questions.text: Which organism is the cause of perianal itching in a child who experiences symptoms primarily at night, leading to sleep disturbances? The eggs of the responsible organism can be observed in the accompanying image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Enterobius vermicularis

Explanation:

  • The parasite infestation in the given scenario is of Enterobius vermicularis or the pinworm which causes intense itching in the perianal region due to the female worm laying eggs in this region at night. The infective stage of this is the embryonated egg. The eggs are often observed on the perianal skin, and when the child scratches the area, they can spread the eggs to others or other surfaces. The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained

Enterobius vermicularis / Pinworm / Threadworm

Epidemiology:

  • The most common age group being school children.
  • Infections can persist for years due to auto-infective cycles.
  • Factors contributing to infection include:
    • Overcrowding
    • Impaired hygiene
    • Poor personal care practices (such as nail-biting and inadequate handwashing).

Morphology

Adult worm

 
  • The adults are short, white, and fusiform, resembling bits of white thread.
  • The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like structures called cervical alae, which are transversely striated.

Female worm

 
  • Females are long.
  • The posterior third tapers into a thin, pointed, pin-like tail.
  • Females are oviparous.

Male worm
  • The posterior end is tightly curved ventrally, sharply truncated, and has a prominent copulatory spicule.

Eggs

 
  • The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained
  • They float in saturated salt solution and have an elongated ovoid shape.
  • Each egg contains a tadpole-shaped, coiled embryo that becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited.

Scotch-tape test:

  • A piece of clear tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, typically overnight. The tape is then examined under a microscope for pinworm eggs.

Life cycle:

  • Enterobius vermicularis spends the entire lifecycle in humans.
  • It has no intermediate hosts and does not undergo systemic migration.
  • The eggs hatch in the intestine, and the larvae enter the caecum and mature into adults.
  • The male worm does not migrate and most often dies after mating and is passed in the feces.
  • The female worm migrates to the rectum from the colon and travels to the perianal skin at night to lay its sticky eggs and dies after laying all eggs or gets crushed due to scratching.

 

Pathogenicity:

  • The embryonated egg is the infective form.
  • The disease thus caused is called enterobiasis, which is more common in children than in adults.
  • It affects females > males.
  • The infection occurs in two ways:
    • Exogenous autoinfection is where the eggs are transferred from the perianal region to the mouth by nails after scratching the region.
    • Endogenous autoinfection/retro-infection is where the larva migrates retrograde and travels back into the colon after hatching in the perianal skin.

Incorrect Options:

Trichuris trichiura (Option B) (whipworm): While whipworms can infect the intestines, they are not typically associated with perianal itching or the nocturnal symptoms described. Their main symptoms involve abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally rectal prolapse.

Trichinella spiralis (Option C): This parasite causes trichinosis, which is typically associated with consuming undercooked pork or wild game. The primary symptoms are muscle pain and swelling, not perianal itching.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option D): This parasite causes strongyloidiasis, which typically presents with symptoms like abdominal pain, diarrhea, and skin rashes, but not specifically with perianal itching.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses are associated with the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - EBV

Explanation:

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is strongly linked to the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). It is a member of the herpesvirus family and is found to be associated with the endemic form of NPC, particularly in Southeast Asia. EBV infection can cause genetic changes in the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx, contributing to the development of cancer.

Malignancies associated with EBV:

Types of malignancy

Examples

Carcinoma

  • Gastric carcinoma (most common)
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Lymphoma

 
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma (most common lymphocyte depletion and mixed cellularity)
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
    • Burkitt’s lymphoma
    • DLBCL (diffuse large B cell lymphoma)
    • Post-transplant lymphoma
    • T or NK cell lymphoma

Sarcoma

  • Leiomyosarcoma

Incorrect Options:

Adenovirus (Option A): While adenoviruses can cause respiratory and other infections, they are not strongly associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Herpes virus (Option C): This is a broad family of viruses, but EBV is the herpesvirus specifically associated with NPC. Not all herpesviruses are linked to this cancer.

Papillomavirus (Option D): HPV (Human papillomavirus) is more closely linked to cancers like cervical cancer, oral cancer, and head and neck cancers, but not to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the time interval between points A and B in the flowchart depicting the natural progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Screening time

Explanation:

  • Screening time: Time from the earliest possible diagnosis point (A) to the critical diagnosis point (B).

 

Lead time:

  • Time gained by early detection of disease or time difference between the earliest possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis. (Option A ruled out)

Generation time (Option C): It refers to the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host. This option is incorrect.

Lag Time (Option D): Not shown in the image; refers to symptom development to diagnosis. Hence, this is incorrect option.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen was non motile and did not ferment lactose or mannitol. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Shigella dysenteriae

Explanation:

Shigella dysenteriae is a key pathogen that can cause bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps, typical of shigellosis. This organism is non-motile, does not ferment lactose or mannitol, and typically produces bloody diarrhea due to the invasion of the intestinal mucosa and resulting ulceration.

Clinical Presentation of Shigella:

Diarrhea:

  • Typically acute and often bloody (dysentery).
  • Incubation Period: 1-3 days after exposure.
  • Prodromal Period: 1-2 days after the incubation period.

Abdominal Pain:

  • Severe cramping.

Fever:

  • Often high-grade.

Tenesmus:

  • Painful straining with defecation.

Systemic Symptoms:

  • Malaise, headache, and sometimes vomiting.

Complications

  • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): Particularly associated with Shigella dysenteriae type 1.
  • Reactive Arthritis: More commonly seen after infection with Shigella flexneri.
  • Neurological Complications: Including seizures, especially in young children.

Diagnosis

Clinical Evaluation:

  • Based on symptoms such as bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever, along with a recent history of exposure (e.g., travel to endemic areas).

Laboratory Tests:

  • Stool Culture: Gold standard for diagnosis; Shigella species identified on selective media like MacConkey agar or XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar.
  • Biochemical Tests: Confirmatory tests include lactose non-fermentation and indole production, among other specific biochemical characteristics.
  • Serotyping: Identification of specific Shigella species and serotypes using agglutination tests with specific antisera.
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Rapid detection of Shigella-specific genes and virulence factors.
  • Stool Microscopy: Presence of leukocytes and erythrocytes in stool samples indicative of invasive diarrhea.

Treatment

Fluid Replacement:

  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT): Recommended for mild to moderate dehydration.
  • Intravenous Fluids: Necessary for severe dehydration or if the patient cannot tolerate oral fluids.

Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Recommended for severe cases, young children, the elderly, and immunocompromised patients.
  • First-line Antibiotics: Include fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone), or azithromycin based on susceptibility testing.
  • Increasing antibiotic resistance necessitates periodic updates on local resistance patterns.

Symptomatic Treatment:

  • Antipyretics for managing fever.
  • Avoidance of antimotility agents like loperamide, which can worsen the infection.

Incorrect Options:

E. coli (Option B): While E. coli (especially E. coli O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea, it is lactose fermenting and typically motile. Furthermore, E. coli infections are associated with hemorrhagic colitis and may present with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in severe cases. The stool culture results indicating non-motility and no lactose or mannitol fermentation are not typical of E. coli.

Salmonella (Option C): Salmonella species can cause gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. However, Salmonella is typically motile and lactose non-fermenting, so it could appear similar to Shigella, but it typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea in many cases and a longer incubation period.

Shigella sonnei (Option D): Like Shigella dysenteriae, Shigella sonnei can cause bloody diarrhea but is often less virulent and typically produces a milder infection. While it is non-motile and lactose non-fermenting, the severity of symptoms with Shigella sonnei usually doesn't match that of Shigella dysenteriae, which is often associated with more severe disease like dysentery.

questions.text: Mandatory exploration is required in the injuries. Which zones of retroperitoneum are required?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1

Explanation:

  • Mandatory exploration is generally required for injuries in Zone 1 of the retroperitoneum.

Zones of retroperitoneum

Zones

1

2

3

Location

Central

Lateral

Pelvic

(retroperitoneal zone of the pelvis)

Structures involve
  • The aorta & its proximal branches
  • Inferior vena cava & its proximal tributaries

Distal renal vessels

Iliac vessels

Management

(Other options ruled out)

Exploration with proximal & distal vascular control
  • Lateral hematoma (renal in origin) - managed nonoperatively (angioembolization)
  • Pulsatile hematoma or penetrating injury present - exploration.
  • Pelvic hematoma is exceptionally difficult to control.
  • Usually, it should not be opened. It is managed by packing/angioembolisation.
  • Explored only if there is expanding or pulsatile or penetrating injury present.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Ayushman Bharat?

choices.text: Aim is to achieve universal health coverage in India
Covers only tertiary health care centres
Cashless, paperless service by only government hospitals

questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Aim is to achieve universal health coverage in India

Explanation:

  • The Ayushman Bharat scheme, also known as Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana, aims to achieve universal health coverage in India.

 

Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY):

  • An initiative launched in 2018 (Option A ruled out) by Govt. of India to achieve UHC (Option B)
  • Provides all the elements, including NCDS, in primary care.
  • Benefits:
    • Coverage: up to INR 5 lakh per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. (Option C ruled out)
    • There is no restriction on the number of family members.
    • Cashless access across the country (Option D ruled out)
    • All pre-existing conditions covered
    • Covers the cost of treatment, up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization follow-up care.
  • Beneficiaries: Vulnerable and poor populations based on the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database.

questions.text:
What structures are contained within the anterior pararenal space?


	Head, neck, and body of the pancreas
	Adrenal gland, kidney, ureters
	Aorta, inferior vena cava
	Ascending and descending colon
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,4

Explanation:

  • Anterior pararenal space lies between the posterior parietal peritoneum & the perirenal fat, and it contains the head, neck, and body of the pancreas (the tail of the pancreas is within the splenorenal ligament), ascending and descending colon, and the duodenum (except for the proximal first segment).
  • The retroperitoneum divides into three main anatomical spaces:

Retroperitoneal spaces

Anterior pararenal space

It contains the head, neck, and body of the pancreas (the tail of the pancreas is within the splenorenal ligament), the ascending and descending colon, and the duodenum (except for the proximal first segment).

Perirenal space

This includes the adrenal gland, kidney, ureters, and renal vessels. (Statement 2 ruled out)

Posterior pararenal space

It is surrounded by the posterior leaf of the renal fascia and muscles of the posterior abdominal wall, contains no major organs and is composed primarily of fat, blood vessels, and lymphatics.

There is also a fourth, less well-defined space known as the great vessel space. It lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and psoas muscles and contains the aorta, inferior vena cava, and surrounding fat. (Statement 3 ruled out)

questions.text: A 27-year-old man came to the clinic with a headache, palpitations, and sweating. As there is a history of renal problems in his brother and father, he requested an abdominal ultrasound, which revealed the presence of multiple renal and pancreatic cysts. 24-hour urinary metanephrine was sent, which was elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?Multiple endocrine neoplasia type I
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Von Hippel-Lindau disease

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, a hereditary condition characterised by the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, pancreas, and other organs.
  • VHL is an autosomal dominant disorder due to VHL gene mutation on chromosome 3.
  • Patients often have an increased risk of developing pheochromocytomas, which can cause symptoms like headaches, palpitations, and sweating.
  • The elevated urinary metanephrines further support this diagnosis, as they are markers for pheochromocytomas.
  • It is also associated with the development of various tumours like
    • Hemangioblastomas in the CNS (cerebellum and retina)
    • Cysts of the pancreas, liver, and kidneys
    • Renal cell carcinomas

 

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type I (Option A) is a genetic condition characterised by the development of tumours in multiple endocrine glands, and it typically features hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic tumours, rather than the renal and pancreatic cysts as seen in VHL.

Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome (Option C) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder clinically manifested by fibrofolliculomas, renal cell carcinoma, lung cysts, and spontaneous pneumothorax. It is caused by mutations in the FLCN gene. Though they develop renal tumours, they do not commonly cause pancreatic cysts, pheochromocytomas, or elevated metanephrines.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option D), also called Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC), is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in either the TSC1 or TSC2 gene. It causes benign tumours in various organs, including the brain, kidneys, heart, and skin. It also leads to skin lesions like ash-leaf spots, shagreen patches, and facial angiofibroma. However, pancreatic cysts and pheochromocytomas are not typically associated with tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: Number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a year refers to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) General fertility rate

Explanation:

 

General Fertility rate

Definition

The total number of live births in an area in a year per 1000 women in the

reproductive age group (15- 44 or 49 years).

Disadvantages and advantages

Disadvantage:

Not everyone in the reproductive age group is exposed to the risk of childbirth

Gross Reproduction Rate (Option A): Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of daughters a woman would have if she were to experience the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her reproductive life (15-49 years).

Total Fertility Rate (Option B): Total fertility rate (TFR) estimates average children per woman over her lifetime with age-specific fertility rates.

Net Reproduction Rate (Option C): NRR is the number of daughters or girls a newborn will bear or have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates.

questions.text: What electrolyte imbalance is commonly observed in patients with this postoperative condition, as depicted in the provided x-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypokalemia

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a typical appearance of a paralytic ileus.
  • It is a common postoperative condition where the normal peristalsis of the intestines is temporarily reduced or absent, leading to a buildup of gas and fluid in the intestines, often seen on X-ray, which is frequently associated with hypokalemia.

Paralytic ileus

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g. hypokalemia) (Option B)
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Clinical Features
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Abdominal discomfort.
  • Non-colicky pain.
  • Vomiting.
  • Non-passage of feces and flatus.
  • Absence of bowel sounds.

Investigations

 

IOC: Abdominal X-ray.

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

Management

 

Decompression: Nasogastric aspiration.

 

Diet: Restrict oral intake until bowel sounds return or the patient starts passing faeces and flatus.

 

Treatment of Underlying Cause:

  • Correct dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia).
  • Discontinue medications affecting motility (e.g., opiates).

Hypocalcemia (Option A) can cause muscle cramps and other symptoms, but it is not typically associated with paralytic ileus.

Hyperkalemia (Option C) does not commonly result in paralytic ileus.

Hypercalcemia (Option D) is not associated with paralytic ileus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a past history of peptic ulcer disease. Physical examination reveals rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Urgent surgical exploration

Explanation:

  • The presence of air under the diaphragm on an X-ray (pneumoperitoneum) is a classic sign of perforated viscus, most commonly due to a perforated peptic ulcer which is a surgical emergency.
  • Physical examination findings of rigidity and past history of peptic ulcer disease also support this diagnosis.
  • Hence, the most appropriate next step in management is urgent surgical exploration to repair the perforation and address any potential complications, such as peritonitis.
  • Delaying the surgery can lead to potential complications.

 

Antibiotics and NPO (nothing by mouth) (Option A) are part of the supportive treatment; they are not sufficient alone in this case. The presence of free air under the diaphragm indicates a perforation that requires immediate surgical intervention.

Upper GI endoscopy (Option B) is useful for identifying ulcers in the non-perforated stage, but this patient already shows signs of perforation, including rigidity and free air; hence, surgery is the immediate priority.

CT abdomen (Option D) of the abdomen can provide valuable information in many cases of abdominal pain, including suspected perforation, but it is not the next best step when there are signs of peritonitis, such as rigidity during physical examination.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a low backache and weight loss. He has progressive difficulty in urination and had an episode of urinary retention two days back, which was relieved by catheterisation. PSA was done, which was 5.2 ng/ml, and an x-ray of the LS spine showed osteoblastic changes. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prostate cancer

Explanation:

  • The combination of urinary symptoms, elevated PSA, and osteoblastic changes on the x-ray strongly points to prostate cancer.
  • Osteoblastic changes in the lumbar spine are a characteristic feature that suggests bone metastasis, which is common in prostate cancer, as it frequently metastasises to bone.

Investigations for Prostate Cancer

DRE

Physical examination detects nodules but is limited in early-stage

PSA Test

Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer

TRUS

Imaging with the rectal probe detects abnormalities

mpMRI

Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread

Prostate Biopsy

The gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells

 

Benign prostatic hypertrophy (Option A) can also cause urinary symptoms like difficulty urinating and urinary retention, but it does not cause weight loss or osteoblastic bone changes on an x-ray. Additionally, the PSA in BPH is usually mildly elevated but not to the degree seen in prostate cancer.

Carcinoma bladder (Option B) can cause urinary symptoms like hematuria, dysuria, or obstructive voiding symptoms, but it is less likely to cause osteoblastic changes in the bones, and the PSA elevation is also not characteristic of bladder cancer.

Renal cell cancer (Option D) presents with symptoms such as hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable abdominal mass. The symptoms described by the patient, along with the elevated PSA level and osteoblastic changes on the X-ray, are not characteristic of renal cell cancer.

questions.text: NITI Aayog has replaced the?

choices.text: National institute of health & family welfare (NIHFW)

questions.solution:
Correct Option C) National planning commission (NPC)

Explanation:

The full form of NITI Aayog is National Institution for Transforming India. It replaced the planning commission on January 1, 2015.

  • NITI Aayog is the organization responsible for developing the Health Index in India. The Health Index is a composite measure that tracks the performance of Indian states and Union Territories on various health indicators. Eg. Neonatal Mortality Rate, Under-5 Mortality Rate, etc.
  • NITI Aayog replaced Planning Commission of India in 2015, acts as a think tank to the central and state governments on policy matters, including health.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare collaborates with NITI Aayog and provides data but is not the primary organization for evaluating and releasing the Health Index.
  • The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) focuses on biomedical research and is not involved in creating the Health Index. The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international body that provides health-related guidelines and support but does not develop the Health Index for India.

 

Medical Council of India (MCI) (Option A): The MCI was a statutory body that regulates medical education. The MCI has been replaced by by the National Medical Commission (NMC) to enhance transparency and improve medical education standards.

National Institute of Health & Family Welfare (NIHFW) (Option B): The NIHFW is an autonomous organization under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in India, the NIHFW has not been replaced by NITI Aayog.

National Board of Examinations (NBE) (Option D): The NBE is an autonomous body responsible for conducting postgraduate medical examinations in India. The NBE has not been replaced by NITI Aayog.

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Ohio presents to a physician with a chronic cough. A chest x-ray demonstrates a cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the lymph node and staining with lactophenol cotton blue demonstrates the following characteristics as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Histoplasmosis:

Explanation:

  • Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It is commonly found in regions with soil that is enriched with bird or bat droppings, such as the Ohio River Valley. This makes the farmer from Ohio particularly at risk, as he may have been exposed to the fungus while working in environments with high concentrations of bird or bat feces.
  • The key features of histoplasmosis on the chest x-ray (cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy) are consistent with this diagnosis, as the infection often affects the lungs and can lead to chronic pulmonary disease in immunocompetent individuals. In some cases, it may cause granulomatous lymphadenopathy.
  • The appearance of Histoplasma on lactophenol cotton blue staining typically shows small, round, or oval yeast cells inside macrophages, which is characteristic of this fungal pathogen.
  • Based on the patient’s history, histopathology showing intramacrophagic yeast form and (LPCB) mount showing numerous hyaline hyphae with few tuberculate macroconidia (arrows) and many smooth-walled oval microconidia are pointing towards a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum, are helpful for immunocompromised individuals

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole

Incorrect Options:

Coccidioidomycosis (Option B): Caused by Coccidioides species, this fungal infection is more common in the southwestern United States (California, Arizona, New Mexico) and is characterized by arthroconidia (spores) in sputum or biopsy, not the intracellular yeast forms typical of histoplasmosis.

Cryptococcus (Option C): Cryptococcus neoformans is another fungal pathogen, but it typically presents with meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients. It does not usually cause cavitary lung lesions with hilar lymphadenopathy in the manner seen in histoplasmosis.

Blastomycosis (Option D): Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, blastomycosis can also cause pulmonary infection with cavitary lesions, but it typically presents with a larger yeast form in tissue, and is more common in areas around the Great Lakes, Mississippi River, and St. Lawrence River regions, rather than Ohio.

questions.text: Which of the following options is considered a high-level disinfectant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Glutaraldehyde

Explanation:

Glutaraldehyde is considered a high-level disinfectant, meaning it is capable of killing most microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi, as well as spores (although it may require longer exposure times for spores). It is commonly used to disinfect medical equipment and instruments that cannot withstand the high temperatures required for autoclaving. Glutaraldehyde is effective at sterilizing items when used properly, although it can be toxic, so precautions are necessary during its use.

Risk category

Recommended method

Medical device/Equipment

1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site.

Sterilisation

  • If heat resistant: Hot air oven or autoclave
  • If heat-sensitive: Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation.

Surgical instruments, implants/prostheses, rigid endoscopes, syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter

2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk): Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids.
  • High-level disinfection (HLD):
  • Such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.

Respiratory equipment, non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans, urine bottles

 

3. Non-critical (low-risk)

Items in contact with intact skin.
  • Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD):
  • Such as phenols (Option D ruled out), chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol (Option A ruled out), povidone-iodine, iodophores (Option C ruled out), etc
  • Patient items include blood pressure cuffs, ECG electrodes, thermometer and stethoscopes.
  • Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails, food utensils, bedside tables, patient furniture and floor.

questions.text: A barber aged 42 years presented with a healed ulcer as below, over the lower medial aspect of the right leg. On examination, he has varicose veins on both his legs. What is the most likely type of ulcer he had?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Venous ulcer

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is venous ulcer, given the ulcer's location on the medial aspect of the leg and the presence of varicose veins, which are indicative of venous insufficiency.
  • These ulcers commonly occur in areas of chronic venous insufficiency, often associated with varicose veins.

 

Venous ulcer

(Option C)

Arterial ulcer

(Option B)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option A)

Pressure ulcer

 

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, and distal pulses are not palpable, and associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

It is also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

Tuberculous ulcer (Option D) occurs when tuberculosis affecting the lungs spreads to the skin. This type of ulcer is relatively uncommon but can develop in individuals with advanced or untreated TB. These ulcers typically have distinct characteristics like an undermined edge and necrotic base and may show signs like scarring or lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: What is the underlying cause of the symptoms exhibited by a 55-year-old male, including fever, fatigue, and abnormal vital signs, along with the identification of the causative agent based on the microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Plasmodium falciparum:

Explanation:

  • Plasmodium falciparum is the causative agent of severe malaria, which can present with symptoms like fever, fatigue, abnormal vital signs (such as hypotension or tachycardia), and in some cases, organ failure or cerebral malaria. It is the most dangerous of the Plasmodium species and can cause life-threatening complications, especially if not treated promptly.
  • The microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Vivax

Falciparum

Malariae

Ovale

RBC size

Enlarged

Normal

Normal

Enlarged with frayed margins

Pigments

Yellowish brown

Dark brown

Schizont

Large (9-10 μm)

Fills the RBC

Contains 12-24 merozoite

Not seen in the periphery

Small (6 μm), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites

Gametocytes

Spherical

Crescentic

Larger than RBC

Spherical

Ring form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

1.5 μm

Occupies ⅙ of RBC size

It may be

  • Multiple forms
  • Accole (attached to RBC membrane)
  • Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus

Band form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

Incorrect Options:

Plasmodium vivax (Option A): This species can cause milder malaria compared to P. falciparum. The blood smear for P. vivax often shows larger trophozoites with a larger, irregular-shaped ring and sometimes a "schuffner's dots" characteristic, which isn't described in the scenario.

Plasmodium ovale (Option C): This species is similar to P. vivax in causing mild malaria. It tends to have oval-shaped red blood cells in the smear and may also show schuffner's dots. It is less likely to cause the severe symptoms described.

Plasmodium malariae (Option D): This species generally causes milder malaria and may present with quotidian fever (fever occurring every 24 hours). The blood smear shows band forms or Ziemann’s dots, which are not typically associated with the severe symptoms seen in this patient.

questions.text: What should be the initial course of action for a patient who has presented with a pelvic fracture and a rupture in the membranous urethra?

choices.text: A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible.

Explanation:

  • The initial course of action for a patient with a pelvic fracture and ruptured membranous urethra is to insert a suprapubic catheter for urinary diversion.
  • By placing a suprapubic catheter, urine can be diverted from the injured urethra, ensuring proper bladder drainage.
  • This helps prevent urinary retention, minimises the risk of urinary extravasation, and reduces further damage to the urethra.
  • Suprapubic catheterisation is considered a temporary solution to manage urine drainage until definitive treatment, such as urethral repair, can be performed.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is a type of Posterior Urethral Injury.
  • The posterior urethra consists of the prostatic urethra and membranous urethra, and injuries in this region are often caused by pelvic fractures, particularly from high-energy trauma like motor vehicle accidents.

Investigations, Management & Complications of Posterior Urethral Injuries

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

Management
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterisation for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided (Option B ruled out)
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications
  • Urethral stricture (most common long-term complication)
  • Urinary incontinence (due to sphincter damage)
  • Erectile dysfunction (common due to injury near neurovascular structures)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

IVP (Option B) can be useful for evaluating the urinary tract, but it is not the initial step in the management of a ruptured urethra. The patient should be stabilised first, with urinary diversion (via suprapubic catheter), before any imaging studies are done.

MCU should be done (Option D): Micturating Cystourethrogram is an imaging study that evaluates the urethra and bladder during voiding. While it may be helpful in assessing the extent of a urethral injury, it is not the first step in management. The priority is to manage the patient's urinary diversion and stabilise them before any imaging studies are performed.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea. The stool examination finding is shown below. Which of the following is most likely causative organism?

 

 


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Entamoeba histolytica

Explanation:

The given image is of E. histolytica trophozoites.

Entamoeba histolytica is the causative organism of amoebic dysentery, which can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and sometimes bloody stools. In the case of a child presenting with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea, Entamoeba histolytica should be strongly considered, especially when stool examination reveals characteristic trophozoites or cysts under the microscope. These trophozoites often have a distinctive central nucleus and can cause tissue destruction in the colon, leading to ulcerations and diarrhea.

Entamoeba histolytica

Trophozoite

Cyst
  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • Single nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus
  • Erythrophagocytosis (engulfed RBCs)

 
  • 1 to 4 nucleus – Quadrinucleate
  • Thick Chromatoid body/ bar:
    • Composition: Ribonucleoprotein (RNP)
    • Stain: Iron hematoxylin

 

 

Entamoeba histolytica

Entamoeba coli

Trophozoite

  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus
  • Erythrophagocytosis

Trophozoite

  • Blunt pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Eccentric karyosome
  • No cartwheel nucleus
  • No erythrophagocytosis

Cyst

  • 1 to 4 nuclei- Quadrinucleate
  • Thick chromatoid body/bar

Cyst

  • 1 to 8 nuclei- Octanucleate
  • Thin filamentous chromatoid body/bar

 

Incorrect Options:

Giardia lamblia (Option A): While Giardia can cause diarrhea (typically watery diarrhea), it doesn't typically cause bloody diarrhea or the same type of abdominal pain associated with Entamoeba histolytica. Giardia trophozoites would also look different under the microscope, with a characteristic "pear-shaped" appearance and two nuclei.

Shigella dysenteriae (Option B): Shigella causes bacillary dysentery, which typically presents with bloody diarrhea and severe abdominal cramping. However, the stool exam would usually show bacilli or a lack of cysts or amoeboid cells, which would be different from what is seen with Entamoeba histolytica.

Campylobacter jejuni (Option D): Campylobacter infection is another cause of diarrhea, and it is commonly associated with watery or bloody diarrhea and fever. However, it typically presents with curved rods on a stool culture, and the stool examination findings in this case would not show the characteristic cysts or trophozoites seen with Entamoeba histolytica.

questions.text: What is the cause of the following appearance in IVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ureterocoele

Explanation:

  • The cobra head appearance in IVP is most characteristic of ureterocoele, where there is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter at its insertion into the bladder.
  • Ureterocele is the congenital dilation of the distal ureter within the bladder wall. It can obstruct urine flow, leading to recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis. Treatment often involves surgical correction to relieve the obstruction.

Ureterocoele

Types
  • Simple Ureterocele (Intravesical - 20%): Found entirely within the bladder and associated with a single ureter. It is less complex and easier to manage.
  • Ectopic Ureterocele (80%): Extends beyond the bladder and often involves a duplicated ureter. This is more complicated due to its location, which may involve the bladder, neck, or urethra.

Etiology

Congenital anomaly is caused by an obstruction in the development of the distal ureter during fetal growth, leading to cystic dilation at the ureteral orifice.

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)/ Urosepsis.
  • Unilateral Hydroureteronephrosis.
  • Palpable Abdominal Mass: Particularly in children, where a distended bladder or large ureterocele might be felt as a mass.

Investigations
  • Ultrasound (USG): The first-line imaging modality revealing hydroureteronephrosis and a cystic structure in the bladder.
  • Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU): Demonstrates a filling defect in the bladder caused by the ureterocele.
  • Cystoscopy: Allows direct visualisation of the ureterocele as a cystic structure that enlarges and collapses with urine flow in the bladder.
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP): The investigation of choice (IOC) for diagnosing ureterocele, showing the characteristic "adder head" or "cobra head" appearance due to the dilated ureter within the bladder.

 

Cobra head or adder head appearance

Treatment

The treatment approach depends on the type of ureterocele:

  • Intravesical Ureterocele: Typically managed with an incision over the cyst wall to allow free flow of urine into the bladder, relieving the obstruction.
  • Ectopic Ureterocele: More complex, often requiring surgical excision of the ureterocele and reimplantation of the ureter into the bladder to correct the abnormal anatomy.

Associated Congenital Abnormalities
  • The most common congenital abnormality of the upper urinary tract is ureteral duplication, which can be associated with ureterocele.
  • Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), another common congenital abnormality, may occur in conjunction with ureterocele, particularly in cases involving ureteral duplication.

Horseshoe kidney (Option A) refers to a congenital fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys, forming a U-shape. IVP here shows characteristic findings, which include medial orientation of calyces (Hand Joining Sign) and high insertion of ureters with anterior transposition ("Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters).

 

 

Bladder tumour (Option C) may cause various structural changes in the bladder, but it normally does not result in the distinct cobra head appearance seen in the ureterocoele. Bladder tumours are more likely to show mass-like lesions or irregularities in the bladder contour.

Posterior urethral valve (Option D) Posterior urethral valves are a congenital abnormality in males where there is a flap-like obstruction in the posterior urethra. This condition is typically diagnosed in infancy or childhood. While an IVP may show associated findings, such as bladder distention or bilateral hydronephrosis, it does not typically cause the cobra head appearance seen in the ureterocoele.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. You notice the following in his CECT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Horseshoe kidney

Explanation:

  • The most likely condition, based on the provided options and typical CT findings, is Horseshoe kidney.
  • It is a congenital anomaly where the two kidneys are fused at their lower poles, forming a “U” or "horseshoe" shape.

Horseshoe kidney

Causes
  • During fetal development, the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure.
  • This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen.

Clinical features
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • Hydronephrosis.
  • Hematuria
  • Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.

Investigations
  • CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualisation of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications.
  • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include:
    • Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign."

High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters.

 

 

Treatment

Treatment depends on the presence and severity of symptoms:

  • Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment but should be monitored periodically.
  • Symptomatic Patients:
    • UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty
    • Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal
    • UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent.
    • Isthmus Management: The isthmus of the horseshoe kidney should not be divided surgically as it contains functional renal tissue.
    • Pregnancy Considerations: A horseshoe kidney can lead to dystocia (difficult labour) due to the kidney's abnormal position.

Appendicitis (Option A) often presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, and in CT, it typically shows a dilated, inflamed appendix. It wouldn't have a horseshoe-shaped mass as seen in the CT scan, making this option unlikely in the given context.

Wilms tumour (Option C) is a pediatric malignancy of the kidney, and it would present as a mass in the kidney, often seen as well-defined & lobulated. While it can be seen in adults, it’s far more common in children. The tumour's presentation wouldn't usually show a horseshoe shape, and it would commonly be isolated in one kidney.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (Option D) appears as a focal dilation of the abdominal aorta, often seen in the midline of the abdomen. It can cause abdominal pain, but it would not present as a kidney-shaped mass or with the characteristic "horseshoe" shape.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for the lesion developed by a patient after 6 months of undergoing heart surgery, as depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Keloid scar

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis based on the image and the lesion that developed 6 months after heart surgery is a keloid scar.
  • It is characterized by abnormal and excessive growth of scar tissue that grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress.
  • It typically appears firm, raised, and extends beyond the margins of the initial injury.
  • Keloid formation seems to be an individual predisposition, and it is more common in African Americans.
  • Sternum is the most common site for Keloid formation.
  • Treatment can be done by intralesional injection of steroids like Triamcinolone.

Hypertrophic scars (Option A) are also raised, they typically remain within the boundaries of the original injury. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after treatment compared to keloids.

Atrophic scars (Option B) are pale, flat, and depressed scars that appear sunken or as indentations in the skin due to loss of tissue or collagen.

Contracture (Option D) occurs when scar tissue forms and tightens, leading to restricted movement of nearby joints or tissues. They typically occur in case of burns or deep wounds. Contractures may result in deformity and functional impairment.

questions.text: Receptor used for the entry of HIV virus into the host cell is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - CCR5

Explanation:

CCR5 (C-C chemokine receptor type 5) is one of the primary receptors used by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) to enter host cells. Specifically, CCR5 is found on the surface of CD4+ T cells and other immune cells, and HIV binds to it along with CD4 (another receptor) in order to gain entry into the host cell.

Modes of Transmission of HIV

  • Sexual Transmission:
    • Most common (75% of cases).
    • Heterosexual Route: Male to female via vaginal intercourse is typical; risk per encounter is low (0.1–1%). Higher risk with anal intercourse.
  • Blood Transfusion: Least common (5% of cases) but has a high transmission risk (90–95%).
  • Percutaneous/Mucosal Transmission: Includes needle stick injuries and sharing razors; less effective compared to sexual transmission.
  • Perinatal Transmission: 20–40% risk of mother-to-fetus transmission without intervention; highest risk during delivery.
  • Casual Contact: No evidence of transmission through casual contact, kissing, or insect bites.
  • Viral Load: Highest in blood, genital secretions, and cerebrospinal fluid; minimal in saliva and other body fluids.
  • Saliva: Contains substances that may inhibit HIV transmission.

Pathogenesis:

  • Receptor Attachment
    • Main Receptor:
      • HIV binds its gp120 to the CD4 receptor on host cells, primarily expressed on helper T cells and other cells like monocytes and macrophages.
    • Co-Receptors: Fusion requires a second receptor:
      • CXCR4: Found on T lymphocytes.
      • CCR5: Present on macrophage lineage cells. (Option B)
    • DC-SIGN:
      • A dendritic cell-specific receptor that binds HIV-1 but does not mediate entry; facilitates transport to lymphoid organs.
    • CCR5 Delta 32 Mutation:
      • Mutation can block HIV entry:
        • Homozygous individuals are resistant to HIV (1% of Northern Europeans).
        • Heterozygous individuals may have delayed progression to AIDS (10–15% of Europeans).
  • Replication

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are not used as a receptor for the entry of HIV into the host cells.

questions.text: What is the vector responsible for transmitting the Zika virus among the options listed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Aedes albopictus

Explanation:

  • Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is one of the primary vectors responsible for transmitting the Zika virus. This mosquito species, along with Aedes aegypti, plays a major role in the spread of Zika, as well as other viral infections like dengue and chikungunya.

Zika virus:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA.

Transmission:

  • ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito.
  • Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.
  • Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.
  • Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.
  • Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.
  • IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.
  • Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins.

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who visited the outpatient department (OPD) experiencing intense pain during erection and a deviated penis for the past half-year?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Peyronie’s disease

Explanation:

  • The patient described in the scenario, experiencing intense pain during erection and a deviated penis for the past six months, is most likely suffering from Peyronie’s disease.

Peyronie’s disease

Definition

It is characterised by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea of the penis, causing abnormal curvature during erections.

Characteristics

Plaque Location: Typically on the dorsolateral aspect of the penis.

Curvature: Resulting from plaque contraction.

 

Causes
  • Trauma/Injury: Repeated minor trauma to the penis.
  • Genetic Factors: Possible genetic predisposition.
  • Connective Tissue Disorders: Associated with conditions like Dupuytren’s contracture.

Associated Conditions

Galezia’s Triad:

  • Dupuytren’s Contracture: Thickening and shortening of connective tissue in fingers.
  • Retroperitoneal Fibrosis: Fibrosis in the retroperitoneal space.
  • Peyronie’s Disease

Clinical Features
  • Painful Erection
  • Erectile Dysfunction
  • Penile Curvature
  • Palpable Plaques
  • Impotence & Infertility (in severe cases)

Treatment

Observation:

  • Spontaneous Resolution: Often improves without treatment.

Medical Management:

  • Oral Medications: Pentoxifylline, colchicine, vitamin E (efficacy varies).

Surgical Intervention (If Spontaneous Resolution Does Not Occur):

  • Nesbit Operation: Placement of a non-absorbable suture opposite the plaque to correct the curvature.
  • Plication Surgery: Shortens the longer side of the penis.
  • Plaque Excision and Grafting: Removes plaque and replaces it with graft material.
  • Penile Prosthesis: For severe cases.

 

Priapism (Option B) is a condition where a prolonged and often painful erection occurs unrelated to sexual stimulation. It is typically unrelated to penile curvature and is caused by abnormal blood flow in the penis, leading to stagnant blood in the erectile tissues. It is considered a urological emergency and requires immediate medical attention.

Marion’s disease (Option C) is also known as bladder neck stenosis or primary bladder neck obstruction (PBNO). Marion described diseases affecting the bladder and neck as causing urinary disturbances resembling those caused by prostate enlargement. However, these disturbances result from changes in the bladder neck itself, without any visible abnormalities.

Erectile dysfunction (Option D) is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual intercourse. It is not associated with pain or penile curvature. In some cases, pain or discomfort may accompany an erection, but it is not the primary symptom of ED.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy who has weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in his jaw area? CBC results indicate anaemia and lymphocytosis. The image below shows biopsy findings from the swelling.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Burkitt lymphoma

Explanation:

  • The histopathological picture is of a Classical Burkitt Lymphoma involving a lymph node.
  • The most characteristic finding is a “starry sky” pattern.
  • At high-power magnification, the neoplastic cells are of intermediate size, similar to the size of benign histiocyte nuclei.
  • The neoplastic cells have round nuclear contours, multiple nucleoli, frequent mitoses, and basophilic cytoplasm. Macrophages with engulfed pyknotic nuclei and nuclear debris are also present.

 

Burkitt's lymphoma

Aspects

Description

Definition

An aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterised by the proliferation of mature B-cells.

Epidemiology
  • Endemic (African) form: Common in children, associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.
  • Sporadic form: Worldwide distribution, more common in children and young adults.
  • Immunodeficiency-related: Often seen in HIV/AIDS patients.

Etiology
  • Strong association with EBV (especially in the endemic form).
  • Translocations involving the MYC gene (chromosome 8).

Genetic Abnormality
  • t(8;14): MYC gene translocated next to the IgH locus (most common).
  • t(2;8) or t(8;22): Less common, involving MYC and Ig light chain loci.

Clinical Features
  • Endemic form: Presents with jaw or facial bone tumours.
  • Sporadic form: Often involves the abdomen (e.g., ileum, cecum) and may cause bowel obstruction.
  • Systemic symptoms: Fever, night sweats, weight loss.

Pathology
  • Histology: "Starry-sky" appearance due to numerous apoptotic cells and macrophages.
  • Tumor cells are medium-sized with round nuclei, coarse chromatin, and high mitotic activity.

Immunophenotype
  • Positive for CD19, CD20 (B-cell markers), and CD10.
  • Expresses surface IgM.
  • High proliferation index (Ki-67 > 95%).

Diagnosis
  • Biopsy: Histological examination showing "starry-sky" appearance.
  • Cytogenetics: Detection of MYC translocations.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Positive for B-cell markers (CD19, CD20).

Prognosis
  • Highly aggressive but potentially curable with prompt treatment.
  • Favorable response to chemotherapy in many cases.

Treatment
  • Chemotherapy: Intensive regimens like cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and methotrexate (CODOX-M).
  • CNS prophylaxis: Methotrexate or cytarabine.
  • Supportive care for tumour lysis syndrome.

Complications
  • Risk of tumour lysis syndrome due to rapid tumour breakdown.
  • It may progress to involve bone marrow or CNS if untreated.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
  • Other high-grade B-cell lymphomas.
  • Lymphoblastic lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma (rarely resembles).

Kikuchi disease (Option A) is a subacute necrotising lymphadenopathy affecting young adults, predominantly women, especially in Japan and neighbouring Asian countries. It presents with painless lymphadenopathy, moderate fever, chills, myalgia, sore throat, and skin rashes. Histopathology reveals necrotising lymphadenitis with histiocyte proliferation and reactive germinal centres.

Infectious mononucleosis (Option B) presents with a triad of fever, pharyngitis, and cervical or generalised lymphadenopathy. Histopathology reveals Paracortical hyperplasia with a mottled ("moth-eaten") lymph node architecture.

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) (Option C) is characterised by a heterogeneous cellularity comprising a minority of specific neoplastic cells—the Hodgkin cells, the Reed-Sternberg cells, and a majority of reactive non-neoplastic cells.

questions.text: Graft from an identical twin is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Isograft

Explanation:

Type of Graft

Description

Autograft

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself

(Option B ruled out)

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

(Option C)

Allograft

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals. (Option A ruled out)

Xenograft

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment). (Option D ruled out)

Synthetic Graft

Artificial materials or bioengineered constructs replace or support damaged tissue (e.g., artificial skin substitutes, bone graft substitutes).

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bochdalek hernia

Explanation:

  • The neonate's presentation of mild intermittent upper abdominal pain, scaphoid abdomen, and decreased breath sounds on both sides, along with X-ray findings showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, strongly points toward a Bochdalek hernia.
  • It is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) due to the failure of the development of the pleuroperitoneal canal.

Bochdalek hernia

Aspect

Description

It is due to the failure of the fusion of the pleuroperitoneal canal, which leads to direct communication between the pleura and peritoneum on the left side.

Contents

Colon, occasionally small bowel or stomach

Associated Conditions
  • Hypoplasia (potentially bilateral)
  • Decreased bronchial branch generation
  • Extension of tunica media beyond respiratory bronchioles
  • Decreased total lung mass

Diagnostic Features
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory embarrassment
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Bowel sounds on the left side of the chest
  • Mediastinal shift towards the right side
  • Intestinal obstruction

Pneumonia (Option B), while being a common cause of respiratory distress, would not typically present with bowel loops in the thoracic cavity on X-ray. It usually shows lung consolidation, infiltrates, or pleural effusion on imaging, not abdominal organs in the chest.

Gastric volvulus (Option C) involves twisting of the stomach, which can lead to obstruction, pain, and vomiting, but it does not cause bowel loops in the thoracic cavity.

Eventration of the diaphragm (Option D) is a condition where there is diaphragmatic weakness or paralysis, leading to the upward displacement of abdominal contents into the chest. While it may cause respiratory distress, it does not lead to bowel loops in the chest on X-ray.

questions.text: What is the term for a stone obstructing the cystic duct, causing dilation of the common hepatic duct, resulting in CBD obstruction and jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mirizzi’s syndrome

Explanation:

  • The condition described in the question is known as Mirizzi’s syndrome.
  • Mirizzi's syndrome is seen in 1% of all cholecystectomies, where a gallstone impacts the gallbladder wall, leading to compression and pressure necrosis.
  • This often results in adherence to the common hepatic duct (CHD) or common bile duct (CBD) wall and can occasionally lead to a cholecystocholedochal fistula.
  • It leads to biliary obstruction, which can result in jaundice and dilation of the bile ducts (CHD and CBD).

Mirizzi’s syndrome

Pathophysiology
  • The gallstone usually impacts from the Hartmann's pouch, leading to compression of the CHD/CBD.
  • Can also occur from the fundus of the gallbladder into the CBD.

Clinical features
  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Upper abdominal tenderness on the right side
  • Possible palpable soft, enlarged liver

Csendes Classification

Type I - Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch;

  • IA- the presence of cystic duct
  • IB- is obliterated cystic duct

Type II - The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd of the circumference of the CBD/CHD, forming a fistula

Type III - Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHD
