Type IV - Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD

Type V - Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with

gallstone ileus (VB)

Investigations
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial imaging to assess gallbladder and ducts.
  • CT Scan: Provides detailed imaging of the biliary system.
  • ERCP/ MRCP: Essential for delineating duct anatomy and identifying the site of obstruction.
  • HIDA Scan: Useful for functional assessment of the biliary system.
  • Findings: Dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary system with a block at the common hepatic duct (CHD).

 

Acute cholecystitis (Option A) is inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct. While this condition can cause pain and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, it does not commonly cause dilation of the common hepatic duct or jaundice unless there is a secondary obstruction of the CBD or cystic duct.

Porcelain gallbladder (Option B) refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall, usually due to chronic cholecystitis. This condition is associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer but does not cause biliary obstruction or jaundice due to stone impaction in the cystic duct.

Cholesterolosis (Option C), also called strawberry gallbladder, involves lipid deposits in the gallbladder mucosa, leading to a characteristic appearance on imaging. It is often asymptomatic and does not typically cause biliary obstruction or jaundice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9x10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Phyllodes tumour

Explanation:

  • The clinical features and HPE show increased stromal cellularity and overgrowth, giving rise to the typical leaf-like architecture, suggesting phyllodes tumour.
  • Phyllodes tumours, also called cystosarcoma phyllodes, are stromal tumours developing from the breast's connective tissue.
  • It occurs in middle-aged women (40 - 50 years).
  • Most phyllodes tumours are benign (noncancerous), but a small number (about 10% to 15%) can be borderline or malignant (cancerous).
  • They present as a lump in the breast, which may be firm, smooth, and well-defined. It may also grow quickly from a few centimetres to massive lesions involving the entire breast.
  • Phyllodes tumour is differentiated from fibroadenoma based on its overgrowth of stroma, increased mitotic activity and cellularity, and nuclear pleomorphism. (Option B ruled out)

 

Inflammatory carcinoma (Option C) presents with redness, swelling, warmth, and often skin changes (such as peau d’orange). It also presents with more aggressive symptoms like axillary lymphadenopathy and is often accompanied by pain.

Ductal carcinoma (Option D) usually presents with irregular masses, skin changes, and often axillary lymphadenopathy. Histologically, it is characterised by the proliferation of malignant epithelial cells in the ducts, not the stromal cellularity and leaflike pattern seen in phyllodes tumours.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distention. On investigations, hepatosplenomegaly and malar eminence are seen, and his peripheral blood smear is shown below. He has a low Hb; the Mentzer index is less than 13. What diagnosis would this signify for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thalassemia

Explanation:

Thalassemia Major (β-Thalassemia Major)

Features

Description

Definition

A severe form of β-thalassemia caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the β-globin gene (HBB) on chromosome 11, leading to absent or markedly reduced β-globin chain production.

Genetics

Autosomal recessive disorder, caused by mutations in the β-globin gene leading to defective hemoglobin synthesis.

Pathophysiology

Reduced or absent β-globin chains lead to excess α-globin chains, which form unstable precipitates, causing ineffective erythropoiesis, hemolysis, and severe anaemia.

Clinical Features

Symptoms appear around 6 months of age (as fetal haemoglobin declines); severe anaemia, growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal deformities (crew-cut appearance on skull X-ray, frontal bossing), jaundice, and delayed puberty.

Hematological Findings
  • Peripheral smear: Microcytic hypochromic anaemia, target cells, anisopoikilocytosis, nucleated RBCs.
  • Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with expansion of marrow cavities.

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis

Absent or very low HbA, markedly increased HbF (>90%), variable HbA2.

Complications
  • Iron overload (due to repeated transfusions leading to secondary hemochromatosis)
  • Cardiac failure (due to iron deposition)
  • Endocrinopathies (diabetes, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism)
  • Osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Increased infection risk (especially from Yersinia and viral infections).

Diagnosis

Blood tests (CBC, peripheral smear), Hb electrophoresis/HPLC, Serum ferritin (for iron overload), Genetic testing (HBB gene mutations), Prenatal diagnosis (chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis).

Treatment

Regular blood transfusions, iron chelation therapy (deferoxamine, deferasirox, deferiprone), splenectomy (in refractory cases), and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) (only curative option).

Prevention

Carrier screening, genetic counselling, prenatal diagnosis, preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) in high-risk couples.

 

  • The Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count) helps distinguish IDA from beta-thalassemia minor, with a value <13 suggesting beta-thalassemia minor. An elevated RDW favours IDA in microcytic, hypochromic anaemia.
  • Confirmatory test: Hemoglobin electrophoresis showing HbA₂ >3.5% confirms beta-thalassemia minor.

Feature

 

Iron Deficiency Anemia

Beta Thalassemia Minor

 

Type

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

RBC

Less

More

MCV

Normal to low

Low

RDW(size variance)

More

Normal

Mentzer index: MCV/RBC

>13

<13

Reticulocyte count

Low

Normal to slightly increased

HbA2 - confirmatory test

<3.5%

>3.5%

 

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option A) The main causes are folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Peripheral blood shows hypersegmented neutrophils and macroovalocytes as early changes. Bone marrow is hypercellular, with numerous megaloblasts and giant metamyelocytes.

Iron deficiency anemia (Option B) is the most common nutritional deficiency in the world. Diagnostic criteria include anaemia, hypochromic and microcytic red cell indices, low serum ferritin and iron levels, low transferrin saturation, and increased total iron-binding capacity.

Pernicious anaemia (Option D): The most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency, resulting from autoimmune destruction of gastric mucosa, leading to intrinsic factor deficiency.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a neonate who is brought to the hospital with complaints of forceful vomiting that is not accompanied by bile after feeding? The child appears lethargic and dehydrated, and abdominal examination shows visible movements of the stomach. A barium meal was conducted, and the image provided is shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Explanation:

  • The neonate presenting with the mentioned complaints and the barium swallow showing a “string sign” suggests Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS).

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

Definition

It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 and 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age.
    • Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus.
  • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
    • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
    • Pyloric length > 14 mm
    • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic ¸ with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

 

 

Hirschsprung’s disease (Option A) is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal intestine, which can present as delayed passing of meconium or constipation. Barium enema shows the dilated proximal segment and the transition zone. Forceful vomiting without bile and visible stomach movements are not typical of Hirschsprung's disease.

Jejunal atresia (Option C) is a condition where there is a congenital obstruction in the jejunum, often presenting with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. It is characterised by multiple dilated loops of the small bowel and a "triple bubble sign" on X-ray. In this case, the vomiting is non-bilious, which rules out this diagnosis.

Duodenal atresia (Option D) is another congenital condition where there is a complete or partial obstruction of the duodenum, which results in bilious vomiting. It often presents with a "double bubble" sign on the X-ray.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with anaemia and hepatosplenomegaly. A peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. A biopsy showed marrow fibrosis and a few characteristics, as given below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Primary myelofibrosis

Explanation:

  • Primary myelofibrosis (PMF) is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm characterised by the development of extensive marrow fibrosis, which impairs normal hematopoiesis.
  • This fibrosis is driven by the inappropriate release of fibrogenic factors, such as platelet-derived growth factor and TGF-β, from neoplastic megakaryocytes.
  • Clinically, PMF presents with progressive anaemia, splenomegaly, and symptoms like fatigue and weight loss.

 

 

WHO diagnostic criteria:

Major criteria:

  • Megakaryocyte proliferation and atypia, usually with reticulin or collagen fibrosis.
  • Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 + CML, PV, ET, MDS, or other myeloid neoplasm.
  • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation or in the absence of these mutations, presence of other clonal markers, or absence of minor reactive BM reticulin fibrosis.

Minor criteria:

  • Leukocytosis ≥ 11 × 109/L.
  • Increased Serum Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH).
  • Anaemia is not attributed to another condition.
  • Palpable Splenomegaly.

 

Polycythemia vera (Option A): Given that the patient presents with anaemia, the diagnosis is unlikely to be polycythemia vera.

Essential thrombocythemia (Option B): In Essential thrombocythemia, patients usually present erythromelalgia and elevated platelet count, and there is an absence of marrow fibrosis.

Chronic myeloid leukaemia (Option D): Though CML presents with anaemia and splenomegaly, bone marrow aspirate in CML is likely to show dwarf megakaryocyte and characteristic garden party appearance.

questions.text: A teenager developed swelling of the face, lips, and tongue and also found it difficult to breathe within a few minutes of consuming prawns. What type of hypersensitivity is seen here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type 1

Explanation

  • The above clinical case is suggestive of an anaphylactic reaction to prawns, which is a type-1 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type I hypersensitivity is also known as an immediate reaction and involves the IgE-mediated release of antibodies against the soluble antigen.
  • This results in mast cell degranulation and the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

 

Type

Mechanism

Immune Components

Features

Examples

Type I: Immediate

(Option A)

IgE-mediated degranulation of mast cells and basophils after allergen binding.
  • IgE antibodies
  • Mast cells
  • Histamine
  • Rapid onset (minutes)
  • Localised or systemic reactions
  • Mediated by histamine.
  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Asthma
  • Urticaria (hives)
  • Food allergies

Type II: Cytotoxic

(Option B ruled out)

Antibody-mediated destruction or dysfunction of target cells.
  • IgG, IgM antibodies
  • Complement
  • Phagocytes
  • Targets specific cells or tissues.
  • Cell lysis or dysfunction.
  • Involves complement activation.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Graves' disease

Type III: Immune Complex

(Option C ruled out)

Deposition of immune complexes in tissues, leading to inflammation and damage.
  • IgG, IgM Antibodies
  • Complement
  • Neutrophils
  • Immune complex deposition in vessels.
  • Tissue inflammation and damage (vasculitis).
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Serum sickness

Type IV: Delayed

(Option D ruled out)

T-cell-mediated immune response, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.
  • T cells (CD4+, CD8+)
  • Macrophages
  • Delayed onset (48–72 hours).
  • Involves cytokine release and macrophage recruitment.
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Tuberculin skin test (PPD)
  • Granulomatous inflammation (e.g., tuberculosis)

questions.text: Tau protein inclusions are involved in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alzheimer’s Disease

Explanation:

  • The fundamental abnormality in Alzheimer’s disease is the accumulation of two proteins (Aβ and tau) in specific brain regions in the form of plaques and tangles.

 

Morphology of Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Gross: Cortical atrophy (narrowed gyri and widened sulci) is predominant in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes.
  • Histology:

Plaques
  • Deposits of Aβ peptides in the neuropil.
  • They are of two types: Diffuse and neuritic (senile).
  • Neuritic plaques contain both Aβ 40 and Aβ 42.
  • Diffuse plaques are predominantly made up of Aβ 42 and seen in trisomy 21 patients.

Tangles
  • Aggregates of the microtubule-binding protein tau.
  • Demonstrated by silver (Bielschowsky) staining.
  • Commonly found in cortical neurons, especially in the entorhinal cortex, and in other sites such as pyramidal cells of the hippocampus, amygdala, basal forebrain, and raphe nuclei.

Hirano bodies
  • Intracellular eosinophilic inclusions are typically found in conditions like Alzheimer's disease and Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease.

Granulovacuolar degeneration
  • Formation of small, clear vacuoles within the neurons.

 

Plaques

Neurofibrillary tangles

Hirano bodies

Granulovacuolar degeneration

Huntington's Disease (Option B) is characterised by toxic gain-of-function of mutant huntingtin protein and neuronal loss in the striatum.

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) (Option C) involves the degeneration of motor neurons, often linked to superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) mutations or TDP-43 protein inclusions.

CNS Lymphoma (Option D) is a type of brain tumour originating from lymphocytes (B cells) and is unrelated to tau protein.

questions.text: The body of an 82-year-old man has been seen for a post-mortem to determine the cause of death. You are examining a histopathological slide containing a section of his cardiac tissue where you notice some pigmentation. Which is the substance that is seen in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lipofuscin

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image shows lipofuscin in the section of cardiac tissue.
  • Lipofuscin is a yellow to red-brown pigment found in cardiac muscle cells, particularly around the nucleus in the hearts of elderly, debilitated people.

Melanin (Option A) is a black or brown pigment found in skin, hair, and certain brain areas, not typically seen in cardiac tissue.

Hemosiderin (Option C) is an iron-storage complex resulting from the breakdown of haemoglobin, typically associated with conditions like haemorrhage or hemochromatosis.

Iron (Option D): Elemental iron deposition in tissues is pathological and associated with diseases like hemochromatosis or chronic blood transfusions. Staining with Prussian blue would help confirm iron presence.

questions.text:
What is the diagnosis based on the X-ray given below?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bladder calculi

Explanation:

  • The X-ray image shows radio-opaque shadows within the pelvis, which are consistent with bladder calculi.
  • Bladder stones can be classified into primary and secondary types based on their underlying causes.

Type

Primary Bladder Stones

Secondary Bladder Stones

Causes

Nutritional deficiency (Vitamins A, B6, magnesium, protein-carbohydrate imbalance)

Bladder outlet obstruction, infection, foreign body presence

Common Composition

Ammonium urate, calcium oxalate

Uric acid, struvite (infection-related)

Common Population

Children in developing countries

Adults with urinary tract dysfunction or infection

Clinical Presentation

May be asymptomatic or present with dysuria, hematuria

Hematuria, dysuria, frequency and urgency,

Investigations

A simple X-ray, renal tract ultrasound or CT scan

Renal calculi (Option A) are typically found in the renal pelvis or kidney. Though they can cause similar symptoms, they are located in the upper urinary tract so that they would be seen above the bladder, not within it.

Schistosomiasis (Option C) is a parasitic infection caused by Schistosoma species, which can affect the bladder and cause hematuria, bladder fibrosis, and calcification. The infection can result in bladder wall calcifications, and the radiograph shows the classic appearance of the calcified bladder, which resembles a fetal head in the pelvis, but these would not appear as radio-opaque stones in the bladder.

Ureteric calculi (Option D) are stones located in the ureters, which are the tubes that carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder. These stones can cause intense flank pain, hematuria, and urinary obstruction. However, they are usually not seen within the bladder, and the X-ray shows radio-opaque shadows specifically in the bladder, not along the ureter.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show:

Haemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000 platelets/mm3

Total leucocyte count: 52,000 cells/mm3 with 83% blasts, as seen below.

The blasts are CD33 +ve. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute Myeloid Leukemia

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses with anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with 83% blast, which is CD33+ve, and peripheral smear showing myeloblasts is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia.
  • AML arises due to genetic mutations in hematopoietic stem cells, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloblasts in the bone marrow, resulting in marrow failure.
  • Patients often present with pancytopenia-related symptoms, including easy bruising (due to thrombocytopenia), fatigue (due to anaemia), and infections (due to leukopenia with dysfunctional blasts).

 

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (Option B): In ALL, the lymphoblasts are CD33-ve and myeloperoxidase-ve.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (Option C): Smudge cells characteristic of CLL are CD33-ve, CD20+ve, and CD5+ve.

Myelodysplastic Syndrome (Option D) is a heterogeneous group of hematologic neoplasms classically described as a clonal disorder of hematopoietic stem cells leading to dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in the bone marrow. Some patients with MDS may have a transformation into acute myeloid leukemia.

questions.text: A boy fell down while playing and presented with deviated nose. The septum however was found to be normal. Following is the CT finding of the patient. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Closed reduction after edema subsides in 20 days
Closed reduction and swelling will decrease automatically

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Closed reduction and swelling will decrease automatically

Explanation:

  • In the case of a nasal fracture with no involvement of the septum, the most appropriate approach is to wait for the swelling to subside before proceeding with closed reduction.
  • This period typically lasts around 10-14 days after the trauma, which allows for the edema (swelling) to decrease.
  • After the swelling is reduced, closed reduction can be performed to realign the nasal bones without the risk of additional trauma or incorrect positioning.
  • The reason for this approach is that if the closed reduction is performed too early, the swelling can obstruct proper visualization and alignment of the fractured nasal bones, potentially leading to complications or an incomplete reduction.

Nasal Fracture Management:

  • Closed reduction is the preferred management for nasal fractures that involve only the nasal bones, not the septum.
  • Waiting for swelling to decrease naturally allows for better visualization during the procedure, reducing the chances of complications or inadequate realignment.
  • Septo-rhinoplasty is typically only necessary for more complex fractures or when there is significant septal involvement that cannot be corrected with closed reduction.
  • Open reduction is used for more complicated fractures where closed reduction isn't feasible.

Incorrect Options:

Septo-rhinoplasty (Option A): is incorrect because it's a more invasive procedure used when there are issues with both the nasal bones and septum.

Open reduction (Option B): is incorrect because open reduction is generally only indicated in cases where closed reduction is not successful or in more complicated fractures.

Closed reduction after edema subsides in 20 days (Option C): is also incorrect because waiting for 20 days is unnecessary. The typical waiting period for swelling to subside is about 10-14 days, not 20 days.

questions.text: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows a displaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- 5-7 days following injury

Explanation:

  • In the case of a nasal fracture, the ideal time for closed reduction is typically within 5-7 days following the injury.
  • This time frame allows for the initial swelling to subside, providing better visibility and ensuring that the fractured bones can be accurately realigned.
  • Reducing the fracture within this window also minimizes the risk of complications and ensures better cosmetic and functional outcomes.

Timing of Nasal Fracture Reduction:

  • Early reduction (within the first 12 hours) may sometimes be appropriate for fractures with significant deformity or in cases where swelling is minimal.
  • However, it's generally not advisable to reduce the fracture within the first few hours because the swelling can obscure proper alignment and make it harder to achieve a precise reduction.
  • After 5-7 days, when swelling decreases, a closed reduction can be safely performed, and the nasal bones can be realigned without much obstruction from edema.
  • If the reduction is done too late (e.g., after 2 weeks or more), bony consolidation begins, making the bones harder to manipulate, and the chances of achieving an optimal result decrease.

Incorrect Options:

Within 12 hours following the injury (Option A): is incorrect because early reduction is often difficult due to swelling that can hinder the realignment of the nasal bones.

After 2 weeks of injury (Option C): is incorrect because waiting too long increases the risk of bony consolidation, making it harder to reduce the fracture and improving the chances of a less satisfactory result.

After 4 weeks of injury (Option D): is incorrect for the same reason. At this point, the bones may have healed or begun to heal, which would reduce the success rate of reduction.

questions.text: Hallpike maneuver aids in the assessment of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Vestibular function

 

Explanation:

  • The Hallpike maneuver, also known as the Dix-Hallpike test, is primarily used to assess vestibular function. It helps in diagnosing benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) by provoking vertigo symptoms related to the inner ear.
  • The test involves rapidly positioning the patient’s head in specific ways to observe for symptoms like nystagmus, which are indicative of vestibular disorders.

Hallpike Maneuver:

  • The Hallpike maneuver is designed to provoke vertigo and nystagmus in patients suspected of having BPPV. It tests the function of the posterior semicircular canal of the inner ear, which is involved in balance.
  • The test is positive if a burst of vertigo and nystagmus occur when the patient is moved into the position, and this supports the diagnosis of BPPV.
  • The maneuver is specifically used for evaluating vestibular disorders, not for assessing hearing or corneal reflexes.

Incorrect Options:

Audiometry (Option B): is incorrect because audiometry assesses hearing, not balance or vestibular function.

Cochlear function (Option C): is incorrect because cochlear function pertains to hearing, and the Hallpike maneuver is not used to assess hearing but rather balance.

Corneal test (Option D): is incorrect because the corneal reflex test assesses the sensory and motor pathways for blinking, unrelated to vestibular or hearing functions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient undergoes TURP, and after 3 days, the patient develops altered sensitiveness and drowsiness. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • The patient is experiencing altered sensitivity and drowsiness 3 days after undergoing TURP (Transurethral Resection of the Prostate), raising suspicion for hyponatremia as the most likely diagnosis.
  • TURP Syndrome is a complication that can occur after a TURP procedure, which results from excessive absorption of irrigating fluids during the surgery, leading to hyponatremia, fluid overload, and a variety of systemic symptoms.

TURP Syndrome

Pathophysiology

It is because fluid is absorbed intravascularly due to high volumes of hypotonic irrigation fluid used during the resection, causing dilutional hyponatremia and various neurologic symptoms.

Risk factors
  • Size of prostate > 75g
  • Duration of surgery > 90 minutes
  • Pre-existing hyponatremia
  • Renal failure

Clinical presentation
  • Confusion,
  • Agitation,
  • Nervousness,
  • Nausea,
  • Hemolysis,
  • Visual disturbances,
  • Coma and shock.

Treatment
  • Drug of choice: IV furosemide.
  • Mild to moderate cases: IV furosemide and normal saline
  • Severe or symptomatic patients: IV 3% Saline
  • Fluid restriction: Useful after initial stabilisation and correction of severe hyponatremia to prevent further fluid overload.

Hypernatremia (Option A) symptoms include thirst, muscle twitching, muscle weakness, seizures and confusion. It is less likely in this case since the patient is experiencing drowsiness, which is more characteristic of hyponatremia.

Stroke (Option C) can present with altered consciousness or neurological deficits such as hemiparesis or aphasia. However, stroke symptoms typically present suddenly and are not typically related to a postoperative time frame of 3 days. The timing of the symptoms makes a stroke less likely unless there is a specific underlying vascular issue. Hyponatremia is a more common cause of these symptoms after TURP.

Meningitis due to spinal anaesthesia (Option D) is a rare complication, with symptoms including fever, headache, neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting and photophobia. The timing of the symptoms (3 days after surgery) is not typical for spinal meningitis. Also, the given symptoms align more with hyponatremia.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 5-year-old child with abdominal swelling, mild discomfort, no pain or vomiting, and a fluctuant soft swelling that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the mesentery attachment, as seen in the outpatient department?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chylolymphatic cyst

Explanation:

  • The description of the abdominal swelling, which is fluctuant, soft, and moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the mesentery attachment, strongly points toward a Chylolymphatic cyst.
  • It is a type of mesenteric cyst, which is a rare, benign cystic lesion that typically contains chyle (lymph fluid mixed with fat). These cysts are often seen in children and are related to lymphatic malformations. (Congenitally misplaced lymphatics)
  • Pathophysiology: absence of efferent lymphatics → collection of chyle→ progressive increase in the size of the cyst.
  • The cyst is usually soft, fluctuant, and non-tender, aligning with the clinical presentation.
  • The cyst moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the mesentery attachment, which is characteristic of cysts within the mesentery or mesenteric root.

Peritoneal cysts (Option A) are also fluid-filled sacs within the peritoneal cavity, but they tend to be less common in children and often do not exhibit the same characteristic free movement seen in chylolymphatic cysts.

Lipoma (Option B) is a benign fatty tumour, typically firm and mobile but not fluctuating in consistency. They are solid masses and do not show the fluctuating and soft characteristics described here. They also typically don't show distinct movement in relation to mesenteric attachment.

Pseudocysts (Option D) are more commonly associated with acute or chronic pancreatitis and would typically present with symptoms such as abdominal pain or other signs of pancreatic pathology.

questions.text: Rhinolalia clausa occurs in all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Cleft palate

Explanation:

  • Rhinolalia clausa refers to a nasal voice or nasal speech caused by obstruction of the nasal passage.
  • It occurs when there is impaired airflow through the nasal cavity during speech, resulting in a distinctive "blocked" or muffled sound.
  • This condition is typically caused by nasal obstruction or nasopharyngeal pathology.

Rhinolalia Clausa:

  • Nasopharyngeal polyp, nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option B), and nasopharyngeal angiofibroma are all conditions that can obstruct the nasopharyngeal region, leading to nasal speech (rhinolalia clausa).
  • A cleft palate, however, leads to a different type of speech disorder. It causes velopharyngeal insufficiency, which results in hypernasality (excessive nasal resonance) rather than the nasal blockage seen in rhinolalia clausa.

Incorrect Options:

Nasopharyngeal polyp (Option A): is incorrect because it can cause obstruction in the nasal passage, leading to rhinolalia clausa.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option B): is incorrect because it can obstruct the nasopharynx, leading to nasal voice or rhinolalia clausa.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option D): is incorrect because it can obstruct the nasopharynx, leading to nasal speech or rhinolalia clausa.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman had her routine follow-up, and her USG of the liver is shown below. She is asymptomatic at present but has a history of mild right hypochondriac pain, which is relieved by taking analgesics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gallstones

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Gallstones, based on the USG findings of a thickened gallbladder wall with biliary sludge, acoustic shadowing and the patient's history of mild right hypochondriac pain that responds to analgesics.
  • Gallstones can sometimes be asymptomatic or present with mild right upper quadrant pain, which is relieved by analgesics. This suggests biliary colic rather than an acute infection.
  • Biliary sludge, often seen on imaging, is a precursor to gallstones and can occur due to stagnation of bile in the gallbladder, often in the presence of gallstones.

Amoebic liver abscess (Option B) presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and liver enlargement. It is often seen in patients with a history of amoebic dysentery (entamoeba histolytica infection). The USG would show a hypoechoic mass in the liver, which is not consistent with the findings in this case.

Hydatid cyst (Option C) is caused by Echinococcus tapeworm infection and is usually found in the liver. The USG appearance of a hydatid cyst typically shows water-lily signs multilocular cysts, or honeycomb patterns, which is not seen here. Symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice.

Acute cholecystitis (Option D) presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and Murphy's sign (pain on palpation of the right upper quadrant). It generally presents more acutely and is associated with inflammation and infection, leading to more severe symptoms.

questions.text: What is the preferred management of the condition in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision

Explanation:

  • The given image suggests an Angular dermoid cyst ,and the preferred management for this is surgical excision, as it completely removes the cyst and prevents recurrence.

Angular Dermoid

Presentation

It commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture.

Location

They are most often located near the lateral canthus, which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet. They may also occur near suture lines of the skull.

Symptoms

They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected.

Diagnosis

Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected.

Management

(Option A)

Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice, especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms.

  • Careful dissection is required to ensure the cyst is fully removed and avoid recurrence.
  • If left untreated, angular dermoids sometimes undergo resorption or indentation of the underlying base. CT is done to rule out dural attachments.

Radiotherapy (Option B) is not a standard treatment for dermoid cysts. It is typically used for malignant tumours or conditions such as cancer and is not indicated for benign lesions like dermoid cysts.

Antibiotics (Option C) are used for bacterial infections. They are not the treatment of choice for an uncomplicated dermoid cyst as it is non-infectious. They are only needed if the cyst becomes infected.

Intralesional steroids (Option D) are typically used for conditions like keloids or hypertrophic scars and are not effective in treating dermoid cysts. The goal for dermoid cysts is to remove the cyst hence, surgical excision is the appropriate approach.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the with a three-day history of severe headache, fever, and nausea. He also reports experiencing pain and swelling behind his left ear and blood-tinged ear discharge. On examination tenderness and bluish discoloration over the mastoid process of the left temporal bone is observed. His CT showed an empty delta sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Lateral sinus thrombosis

Explanation:

  • The empty delta sign on CT imaging refers to a sign of lateral sinus thrombosis. It is characterized by the absence of contrast in the lateral sinus, which is usually filled with a clot, causing a "delta" shape around the thrombus.
  • This condition is typically a complication of otitis media or mastoiditis, leading to infection spreading to the lateral sinus, which can cause severe headache, fever, nausea, and pain and swelling behind the ear.

Lateral Sinus Thrombosis:
Lateral sinus thrombosis is a rare but serious condition that can result from the spread of infection from the middle ear or mastoid to the lateral sinus. It is characterized by:

  • Headache, fever, nausea, and pain/swelling behind the ear (mastoid process).
  • Bluish discoloration over the mastoid, which is called "mastoid ecchymosis" or "Battle's sign".
  • The empty delta sign on CT, which is highly suggestive of lateral sinus thrombosis.

Incorrect Options:

Meningitis (Option A): is incorrect because while meningitis can cause headache, fever, and nausea, it would not present with the empty delta sign or swelling behind the ear associated with lateral sinus thrombosis.

Brain Abscess (Option C): is incorrect because a brain abscess would present with neurological symptoms, such as focal deficits or altered consciousness, and would not typically show the empty delta sign on CT.

Extradural Abscess (Option D): is incorrect because although an extradural abscess can cause swelling and localized pain, it does not typically show the empty delta sign or the same pattern of infection spread as lateral sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: The image below shows an image of the anus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and it occurs when one of your anus glands becomes clogged and infected? Pus and fluid accumulate in the anal gland, resulting in an excruciatingly painful abscess around your anus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Perianal abscess

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this scenario, based on the symptoms described and the given clinical image, is a perianal abscess.
  • It is an infection of one of the small glands near the anus, known as anal glands or crypts. These glands can become blocked or infected, leading to pus accumulation, resulting in an abscess.
  • It is a type of anorectal abscess that occurs in the perianal region.
  • It can also develop as a complication of Crohn's disease.
  • Treatment of perianal abscess:
    • Surgical Drainage: It is the primary treatment, often performed under anaesthesia. The abscesses are drained via perineal skin using a cruciate incision, avoiding excessive excision of healthy tissue.
    • Antibiotics: Indicated in cases with extensive cellulitis, diabetes, or immunosuppression.

Hemorrhoids (Option A) are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus. While they can cause pain, discomfort, and sometimes bleeding, haemorrhoids do not result in pus accumulation or an infected abscess.

Pelvirectal abscess (Option B) develops when the intersphincteric abscess extends cranially past the levator muscles. The infection progresses semicircularly and primarily posteriorly, resulting in the creation of a horseshoe abscess or fistula. Such a condition does not represent the case here.

Pilonidal sinus (Option D) are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair. However, this condition is not located around the anus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old male patient who visited the surgery OPD with a history of occasional discharge of pus with a slight presence of blood from an external opening in the perianal region, despite multiple attempts at drainage? The examination of the perianal region is depicted below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fistula-in-ano

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this patient, with an occasional discharge of pus with slight blood from an external opening in the perianal region, despite multiple drainage attempts, along with the findings of the clinical image given, is Fistula-in-Ano.
  • It is a chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Fistula-in-ano

Causes
  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Parks classification

Type 1 - Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2 - Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3 - Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4 - Extra- sphincteric (1%)

 

Pilonidal sinus (Option A) is found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair. It occurs higher up near the coccyx, not in the perianal region.

Perianal abscess (Option B) is an infection of one of the small glands near the anus, known as anal glands or crypts. These glands can become blocked or infected, leading to pus accumulation and abscess. This patient has had multiple drainage attempts and ongoing discharge, suggesting a chronic issue. Hence, he likely has a chronic fistula rather than an acute abscess.

Hemorrhoids (Option C) are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus. While they can cause pain, discomfort, and sometimes bleeding, pus discharge is not characteristic of hemorrhoids.

questions.text: At what age frontal sinuses appear on X ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- 4 years

Explanation:

  • The frontal sinuses are usually not visible on X-ray until around 4 years of age.

  • While their development begins earlier, they do not appear clearly on radiographs until this age, as the sinuses are still small and continue to grow throughout childhood.

Development of Paranasal Sinuses:

  1. Maxillary Sinus:

    • The maxillary sinus is the first to develop and is present at birth as a small cavity. It grows rapidly during the early years of life and reaches full size by 4 years of age.

  2. Ethmoid Sinus:

    • The ethmoid sinus is present as a small cluster of cells at birth and becomes more prominent in childhood. Development continues up to 6-8 years, with further changes through adolescence.

  3. Sphenoid Sinus:

    • The sphenoid sinus begins to develop around 2 years of age. It is typically visible on imaging after 3-5 years and reaches its adult size by 12 years.

  4. Frontal Sinus:

    • The frontal sinuses are not visible on imaging until about 4 years of age, with full development occurring much later, generally by the age of 16-18 years. Their growth continues until late adolescence.

Incorrect Options:

1 year (Option A): is incorrect because frontal sinuses are not present or visible on X-ray at this age.

2 years (Option B): is incorrect because while they start developing around this time, they aren't visible on X-ray yet.

3 years (Option C): is incorrect because although they begin developing around 2 years, frontal sinuses generally appear on X-ray by the age of 4 years, not 3 years.

questions.text: The authority who investigates the death of a 14-year-old girl who was abducted by a man and subsequently died while in police custody will be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Judicial magistrate

Explanation:As per Section 176 CrPC (Code of Criminal Procedure, India), when a person dies in police custody or under suspicious circumstances, the investigation must be conducted by a Judicial Magistrate.

Key Reasons:

  • Judicial Magistrate ensures an impartial and independent inquiry.

Mandatory for cases involving:

  • Death in police custody.
  • Death of minors under suspicious circumstances.
  • Death due to abduction or unnatural causes.

Coroner (Option A): Outdated in India, previously investigated unnatural deaths.

Police (Option B): Cannot investigate deaths occurring in their custody independently due to conflict of interest.

Medical Examiner (Option C): Conducts autopsies but does not have legal authority for formal investigation.

questions.text: An infant of 12 weeks presented with the following defect in the umbilical area. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Umbilical hernia

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this 12-week-old infant with a defect in the umbilical area is Umbilical Hernia.
  • It is a protrusion of abdominal contents (usually fat or intestines) through a weakness in the abdominal wall at the umbilical ring. This condition is more common in infants and obese adults.
  • In infants, it is a benign condition, often noticed shortly after birth, and the hernia usually appears as a soft swelling in the umbilical area that may disappear when the infant is lying down or when pressure is applied.
  • It mostly resolves spontaneously in infants before 2 years, without needing any intervention.
  • If they have not resolved by 2 years of age, surgical repair is considered.

Omphalocele (Option A) is a condition where, instead of the abdominal wall completely closing, some of the internal organs protrude out of the body through the umbilical area. These organs are not just exposed to the environment but are enclosed in a protective membrane (peritoneum, Wharton’s jelly & amnion). They are usually much larger than hernia, and the given clinical condition aligns more with an umbilical hernia.

Gastroschisis (Option B) is the evisceration of bowel contents through a defect in the anterior abdominal wall just lateral to the umbilicus. It is characterised by a defect beside the umbilicus and does not present in the same way as an umbilical hernia.

Paraumbilical hernia (Option D) is a protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall, but it occurs slightly above or below the umbilicus rather than directly at the umbilical ring. The swelling is located directly at the umbilicus in the infant, which is more characteristic of an umbilical hernia rather than a paraumbilical hernia.

questions.text: Which of the given options is most likely to cause sensory neural hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Labyrinthitis:

Explanation:

  • Labyrinthitis refers to an inflammation of the inner ear, specifically the labyrinth, which contains both the cochlear (hearing) and vestibular (balance) systems.

  • When the cochlear part is affected, it can lead to sensorineural hearing loss due to damage to the cochlear structures or the auditory nerve.

  • It is often caused by a viral or bacterial infection, resulting in hearing impairment and balance issues.

Labyrinthitis:

  • Labyrinthitis typically results from viral or bacterial infections, leading to inflammation of the inner ear.

  • It can cause sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, nausea, and tinnitus.

  • The hearing loss is sensorineural because it involves damage to the cochlea or the auditory nerve.

  • Treatment typically involves managing the infection (if bacterial) and symptomatic relief for the hearing and balance disturbances.

Incorrect Options:

Otosclerosis (Option B): is incorrect because otosclerosis is a condition that affects the ossicles (middle ear bones), leading to conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

Ear wax (Option C): is incorrect because ear wax can cause conductive hearing loss by blocking the ear canal, but it does not affect the inner ear, so it does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) (Option D): is incorrect because CSOM primarily causes conductive hearing loss due to the damage to the middle ear structures, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A dead body was found with a wound on the neck, with clean-cut edges, crushed tissues along with the disruption of the vertebral bones.Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chop wound

Explanation:

A chop wound is characterized by:

  • Clean-cut edges (sharp weapon component).
  • Crushed tissues (blunt force component).
  • Disruption of vertebral bones (high-impact force).

Mechanism:

  • Caused by heavy, sharp-edged weapons like an axe, machete, or cleaver.
  • Combines both incised (clean edges) and lacerated (crushing) features due to the weight and force involved.

Incised wound (Option A): Clean-cut edges without tissue crushing or bone injury.

Lacerated wound (Option C): Irregular edges with tissue bridging, caused by blunt trauma.

Avulsion (Option D): Tearing away of tissue, often from high-velocity trauma or accidents.

questions.text: The image below shows a procedure that was done on the patient. What is the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Tracheostomy

Explanation:

  • A tracheostomy is a surgical procedure where an opening is created in the neck, directly into the trachea (windpipe), to provide an airway and to allow for breathing when the upper airway is blocked or compromised.
  • This is usually performed in cases of long-term mechanical ventilation needs, upper airway obstruction, or trauma to the neck.

Tracheostomy:

Aspect

Details

Indications

Upper airway obstruction (tumors, foreign body)

Prolonged mechanical ventilation

Neurological conditions (e.g., spinal cord injury)

Procedure

Incision made below vocal cords, tube inserted into trachea.

Tube Types

Cuffed: for ventilation support.

Uncuffed: for stable airway or weaning.

Complications

Infection, bleeding, tracheal stenosis, accidental dislodgement, swallowing difficulty.

Care

Regular cleaning, monitoring for infection, and tube changes.

Advantages

Comfortable for long-term ventilation, lower risk of airway damage compared to intubation.

Incorrect Options:

Endotracheal intubation (Option A): is incorrect because it involves the insertion of a tube into the trachea via the mouth or nose, not through a neck incision.

Needle cricothyroidotomy (Option B): is incorrect because this emergency procedure involves inserting a needle through the cricothyroid membrane in the neck to secure an airway in life-threatening situations, but does not involve creating a permanent opening as in a tracheostomy.

Oropharyngeal airway (Option D): is incorrect because this is a device inserted into the mouth to maintain an open airway, typically in unconscious patients, and does not involve a surgical incision or permanent airway opening.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given abdominal x-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rectal foreign body

Explanation:

  • The correct diagnosis based on the abdominal x-ray given is a rectal foreign body.
  • It refers to an object that has been accidentally or intentionally inserted into the rectum and is typically visible on abdominal X-rays.
  • These are serious injuries and generally require surgical intervention.
  • Temporary colostomy may be necessary for recovery.
  • There’s a risk of developing necrotising fasciitis, so broad-spectrum antibiotics are crucial.
  • Bladder or urethral damage can also be associated with these injuries.

Ureterocoele (Option A) is a congenital dilation of the distal ureter that occurs at the ureterovesical junction. It is usually identified on IVU with a "cobra head" appearance, which is a hallmark of a ureterocele, but it would not be visible as a foreign object in the rectal area on an abdominal x-ray.

Pelvic bone fracture (Option B) would be visible on an x-ray, but it would involve fractures of the pelvic bones but not a foreign body in the rectum.

Bladder stone (Option D) would be visible on an abdominal x-ray as a radio-opaque mass in the bladder, but the given image is suggestive of a rectal foreign body.

questions.text: A cricket player was initially hit on the head with a cricket ball, appearing fine but later collapsing, regaining consciousness to play well, and then found unconscious in the dressing room. What is the probable diagnosis based on the result of the CT scan provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Extradural hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis here, given the sequence of events and CT scan showing the biconvex lens-shaped collection of blood, is Extradural Hemorrhage.
  • It is also called epidural haemorrhage & occurs when there is bleeding between the skull and the dura mater (the outermost layer covering the brain). It is typically caused by trauma, like being hit on the head, which is consistent with the patient's history of being struck by a cricket ball.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Initial Loss of Consciousness
    • Neurological Deterioration
    • Variable Consciousness Levels
    • Posterior Fossa EDH (Rare)
    • Signs of Elevated ICP
  • They are neurosurgical emergencies when symptomatic. Their management includes:
    • Emergency - Burr hole surgery.
    • Definitive - Craniotomy with hematoma evacuation.

Artifact (Option B) on a CT scan refers to image distortion or interference that does not represent actual pathology. Given the clear clinical scenario of trauma and the CT finding of a hematoma, an artefact is unlikely to be the cause of the findings.

Subdural haemorrhage (Option C) occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane. They tend to be crescent-shaped on CT, unlike the biconvex lens-shaped appearance of an extradural haemorrhage.

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (Option D) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater. CT appearance of subarachnoid haemorrhage is usually diffuse, with blood visible in the subarachnoid space, whereas extradural haemorrhage appears as a localised biconvex mass.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 70-year-old man who has neck nodes and exhibits a dull tympanic membrane, along with symptoms of deafness and tinnitus in the left ear, and a type B graph on tympanometry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) commonly presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, which can explain the neck nodes observed in this patient.

  • The patient also exhibits a dull tympanic membrane, which can be associated with eustachian tube dysfunction, a common manifestation in NPC due to obstruction or invasion of the nasopharynx. This dysfunction leads to middle ear effusion and the type B tympanogram seen in this case.

  • The presence of deafness and tinnitus further suggests that the nasopharyngeal carcinoma may be affecting the middle ear or the auditory pathway.

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma (NPC):

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor arising from the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx. It is more common in certain geographic regions and in older individuals. The disease often presents with:

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (neck nodes), as seen in this patient.

  • Deafness or tinnitus, due to eustachian tube obstruction, which leads to middle ear effusion, presenting with a dull tympanic membrane.

  • Type B tympanogram, which indicates middle ear effusion or obstruction.

Incorrect Options:

Chronic suppurative otitis media (Option A): is incorrect because this condition typically causes a purulent discharge and would not lead to the characteristic lymphadenopathy or dull tympanic membrane associated with NPC.

Glomus tumor (Option B): is incorrect because although it can cause tinnitus and middle ear effusion, it would not typically present with cervical lymphadenopathy or the eustachian tube dysfunction leading to type B tympanogram.

Sensorineural hearing loss (Option D): is incorrect because while it can cause hearing loss, the additional findings of cervical lymphadenopathy, a dull tympanic membrane, and type B tympanogram point toward a more localized pathology, such as NPC.

questions.text: False regarding deep second-degree burns:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Painless

Explanation:

  • Deep second-degree burns are typically painful. This type of burn damages the epidermis (top layer of skin) and the dermis (tissue below the skin) & It's also known as a deep partial-thickness burn.

Deep Partial-Thickness Burns

Affected Area

Epidermis and reticular dermis (bottom layer of dermis) (Option C ruled out).

Clinical Features
  • Painful
  • Loss of epidermis
  • Less moist dermis
  • Fixed capillary staining
  • Reduced sensation
  • No blanching with pressure (Option B ruled out)

Healing

Takes 3+ weeks: often leads to scarring (Option A ruled out)

Treatment

May require surgical intervention (e.g., skin grafting)

questions.text: Identify the fingerprint pattern shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Arch

Explanation: An arch fingerprint pattern is characterized by:

  • Wave-like pattern with ridges flowing from one side to the other.
  • No core or delta (triangular ridge formations).
  • Simplest pattern among fingerprint types.

Types of Arches:

  • Plain Arch: Smooth wave-like ridges.
  • Tented Arch: Steeper rise in the center, resembling a tent.

Whorl (Option A): Circular or spiral pattern with at least 2 deltas.

Composite (Option B): Combination of multiple patterns (whorl + loop).

Loop (Option C): Ridges enter from one side, curve back, and exit the same side, with one delta.

questions.text: Cause of Opisthotonus is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strychnine

Explanation: Alkaloid from seeds of strychnos nux-vomica causes opisthotonus.

  • Opisthotonus is a severe form of muscle spasm where the body is arched backward due to involuntary contractions of the back muscles, especially the paraspinal muscles.

Cause:

  • Strychnine poisoning is the classic cause.

It acts as a glycine antagonist in the spinal cord, leading to:

  • Loss of inhibitory control in motor neurons.
  • Uncontrolled muscle contractions and spasms.

Cocaine (Option A): Causes CNS stimulation, tremors, seizures, not opisthotonus.

Codeine (Option B): Opioid, causes CNS depression, respiratory depression, not muscle spasms.

Curare (Option D): A muscle relaxant causing flaccid paralysis, not spasms.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with complaints of a facial deformity, as shown in the image below. His medical records show a history of acne rosacea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Rhinophyma

Explanation:

  • Rhinophyma is a severe form of acne rosacea and is characterized by the thickening and enlargement of the nasal skin, often with a bulbous appearance. It is more common in men and typically develops in individuals with a long history of rosacea.

  • The condition causes facial deformity due to the increased sebaceous gland activity and inflammation. The nose becomes enlarged and may appear red and nodular, which is consistent with the image shown.

Rhinophyma:

Rhinophyma is a subtype of acne rosacea, often associated with long-term rosacea that leads to the hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands on the nose. This condition manifests as:

  • Thickening of the skin, leading to a bulbous or enlarged nose.

  • Redness or telangiectasias (visible blood vessels) on the nose.

  • It typically affects middle-aged to older men and is often triggered or worsened by chronic inflammation from acne rosacea.

  • Treatment may involve laser therapy, surgical excision, or topical treatments to reduce the size and appearance of the nose.

Incorrect Options:

Rhinoscleroma (Option B): is incorrect because rhinoscleroma is a chronic bacterial infection (caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae) that leads to granulomatous inflammation and fibrosis, affecting the nasal and upper respiratory tract. It does not present with the same cosmetic deformity seen in rhinophyma.

Rhinosporidiosis (Option C): is incorrect because rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the Rhinosporidium seeberi, which leads to the development of polyps, not the thickening and deformity of the nose characteristic of rhinophyma.

Scleroderma (Option D): is incorrect because scleroderma primarily causes skin tightening and fibrosis but does not lead to the characteristic redness and bulbous deformity of the nose seen in rhinophyma. Scleroderma can affect the face, but it does not cause the same localized changes in the nose as rhinophyma.

questions.text: What is the substance identified by Barberio's test, which was conducted on the stains from a sexual assault incident involving an 18-year-old female and a 20-year-old male?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Spermine

Explanation:

Barberio's Test is used to detect spermine crystals, using picric acid.

  • Spermine is an important component of prostatic secretion and is found in semen.
  • On adding picric acid to the sample, yellow needle shaped (rhombic) crystals are seen (also called spermine picrate crystals).

Other tests used in semen analysis in cases of sexual offenses:

  • Fluorescence test: Seminal stain + UV light → Bluish white color
  • CPK (Creatinine Phospho Kinase): Detects old seminal stains (6 months old as well). Normal range: 660 IU/ml.
  • LDH isoenzyme detection of sperm: Most specific test of semen.Absolute proof = One unbroken sperm.
  • Phadebas test: In case of oral sex, saliva can be detected by L-amylase.

questions.text: Best way to localise extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nucleotide scan

Explanation:

  • The best method to localise extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas is through a Nucleotide scan (such as MIBG or PET scan), which allows for accurate identification of the tumour's location.
  • MIBG is a radiopharmaceutical that is selectively absorbed by neuroendocrine tumours, such as pheochromocytomas. When radioactive iodine-labelled MIBG is administered intravenously, the tumour cells take it up due to their affinity for norepinephrine.
  • Once the MIBG is taken up by the tumour, a whole-body scan is performed using a gamma camera, allowing for the precise localization of pheochromocytomas, including extra-adrenal tumours.

X-ray (Option A) is not suitable for visualising soft tissue tumours like pheochromocytomas or detecting abnormal growths. It is better suited for visualising bones or detecting larger, more obvious structural abnormalities.

VMA excretion (Option C) is a metabolite of catecholamines and can be measured in urine to help diagnose pheochromocytoma. However, while increased VMA (Vanillyl mandelic acid) excretion is suggestive of pheochromocytoma, it does not help localise the tumor.

Clinical examination (Option D) can reveal signs and symptoms of pheochromocytoma, but it is not reliable for localising an extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. Symptoms like hypertension, sweating, and tachycardia suggest the presence of pheochromocytoma, but further imaging studies (like the nucleotide scan) are required for accurate localisation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought by his parents with concerns about being increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. As further workup reveals a tumour, the eye is enucleated, and the microscopic appearance is as shown in the image. Molecular analysis of the tumour indicates a loss of cell cycle control in the tumour cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

  • The child presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and progressive clumsiness, raising suspicion for an intraocular malignancy. The absence of a red reflex suggests an opaque mass within the eye, which is highly indicative of retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.
  • Age of Presentation: Usually before 3 years, with non-familial cases diagnosed by 1 year.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Leukocoria (most common presenting sign)
    • Strabismus (misaligned eyes) due to loss of vision
    • Proptosis in advanced cases
    • Orbital invasion and metastasis in late stages.
  • Histopathology:
    • Small round blue cells are characteristic of primitive neuroectodermal tumours.
    • Anastomosing areas of necrosis
    • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (well-differentiated tumours)
  • Molecular Pathogenesis:
    • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14, leading to loss of cell cycle control.
    • Loss of both alleles of RB1 leads to uncontrolled retinal cell proliferation.

 

Wilms tumour (Option A), a nephroblastoma, typically presents with an abdominal mass, hematuria, and hypertension and histologically shows a triphasic pattern with blastemal, stromal, and epithelial components.

Ependymoma (Option C) arises in the fourth ventricle or spinal cord, leading to obstructive hydrocephalus, and shows perivascular pseudorosettes and true rosettes on histology.

PA

 

Neuroblastoma (Option D), a neural crest tumour usually originating in the adrenal gland or sympathetic chain, presents with an abdominal mass, periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes"), and opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome, with histology showing Homer-Wright rosettes and immunohistochemical positivity for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and neuron-specific enolase (NSE).

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the sign depicted in the contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head shown below in a 14-year-old football player who presented to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football, along with a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding, unilateral nasal obstruction, and denasal speech, without any history of trauma or falls?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Holman Miller Sign.

Explanation:

  • Holman Miller Sign is associated with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), a highly vascular benign tumor commonly seen in young males.

  • It appears on imaging, typically on a contrast-enhanced CT scan, as a vascular mass in the nasopharynx or nasal cavity, and is indicative of JNA, which is associated with recurrent epistaxis, unilateral nasal obstruction, and denasal speech.

Holman Miller Sign:

  • Holman Miller Sign refers to the contrast-enhanced CT finding that highlights the vascular nature of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It is seen as a highly vascular mass in the nasopharyngeal region, often extending into the nasal cavity.

  • JNA presents with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, denasal speech, and is often diagnosed in adolescent males.

  • JNA is a benign tumor but can cause significant morbidity due to its location and vascularity. Treatment typically involves surgical resection and sometimes preoperative embolization to reduce vascularity.

Incorrect Options:

Aquino Sign (Option A): is incorrect because it is not associated with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma but rather describes a different vascular finding.

Teardrop Sign (Option C): is incorrect because it refers to a specific radiographic appearance in the case of subdural hematoma, not nasopharyngeal tumors.

Hanging Drop Sign (Option D): is incorrect because it is associated with posterior fossa lesions such as cerebellar or brainstem tumors, not nasal or paranasal sinus conditions.

questions.text: Grey-Turner's sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • Grey-Turner's sign refers to bluish discolouration or bruising of the flanks (the sides of the abdomen), which can be seen in severe acute pancreatitis.
  • It is a sign of retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which occurs when pancreatic inflammation spreads from the anterior pararenal space to the lateral edge of the quadratus lumborum muscle, causing bruising on the flanks.

Acute appendicitis (Option A) generally presents with right lower abdominal pain, fever, and nausea. It does not usually cause retroperitoneal haemorrhage or bruising, so Grey-Turner's sign is not associated with it.

Acute cholecystitis (Option C) involves inflammation of the gallbladder, usually causing right upper quadrant pain. While it may cause jaundice or tenderness, Grey-Turner's sign is not typically seen.

Acute hepatitis (Option D) involves liver inflammation, often caused by viral infections or drug-induced liver injury, which can cause jaundice, but Grey-Turner's sign is not characteristic of hepatitis.

questions.text: Identify the active toxin extracted from the poisonous plant in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-Hyoscyamine

Explanation: The above image shows Atropa Belladonna, also called the deadly nightshade.

  • It produces an active poisonous component called hyoscyamine.
  • The toxin may also be found in datura Stramonium (Jimson weed)
  • Hyoscyamine is an isomer of Atropine and has Anticholinergic and Antimuscarinic activity.
  • It is used as an antiemetic, anti-secretory and antispasmodic agent in the treatment of naused, motion sickness, allergic rhinitis etc.
  • Side effects include dryness of the mouth and eyes, tachycardia, palpitations, decreased sweating, and can also produce anxiety and restlessness.

Calotropis Gigantea (Option A): It is a purple colored flower which has an active poisonous principle called Calotropin, Calotoxin.

Digitalis (Option B): Also called purple foxglove where the poison acts by inhibiting Na-K ATPase channel.

Ricin (Option C): Produced by castor plant where it inhibits RNA polymerase and protein synthesis.

questions.text: What is the type of cell from which the cell displayed below originates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) B cells

Explanation:

  • B cells express CD19, CD20, and CD21 markers.
  • When activated, they differentiate into plasma cells, which have an eccentric nucleus, basophilic cytoplasm, and a perinuclear halo (indicative of the Golgi apparatus involved in antibody production).
  • Plasma cells secrete immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, etc.), essential for humoral immunity.

 

NK (Natural Killer) (Option A) cells are innate immune cells. NK cells are lymphocytes that arise from the same common lymphoid progenitor that gives rise to T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes.

CD4 (Option B) and CD8 (Option D) are expressed on distinct T-cell subsets and act as coreceptors during T-cell activation.CD4 is expressed in 50% to 60% of T cells, whereas CD8 is expressed in about 40% of T cells. The CD4- and CD8-expressing T cells—called CD4+ and CD8+ cells, respectively

questions.text: A person was found dead in the bushes with his hands tied. On examination of the body, there was cyanosis petechial hemorrhages, abrasions, and bruises around the mouth and lips.There was associated facial congestion and edema. What is the least likely cause of death here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Suicide

Explanation: Suicide is least likely because hands tied (self-restraining difficult) and facial trauma unusual in suicidal deaths.

Key Findings:

  • Hands tied → Suggests restraint, highly indicative of homicide.
  • Cyanosis and petechial hemorrhages: Signs of asphyxia.
  • Abrasions and bruises around the mouth and lips: Consistent with smothering (external airway obstruction).
  • Facial congestion and edema: Due to venous obstruction from asphyxia.

Differentiation of Causes:

  • Asphyxia (general term): Present, evidenced by petechiae, cyanosis, and facial congestion.
  • Smothering (a form of asphyxia): Hands tied, mouth injuries indicate external airway obstruction.
  • Homicide: Most consistent due to the tied hands and physical trauma.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carbuncle

Explanation:

  • The carbuncle is the most likely diagnosis in this case due to the pus-filled masses with necrotic tissue and a yellow centre seen in the image, which is characteristic of this type of deep skin infection.
  • These are composed of two or more furuncles. They classically have multiple pustules, or "heads," originating from the underlying abscess.

Carbuncle

Definition

Infection of hair follicles extending into surrounding and subcutaneous tissue.

Cause

Staphylococcus aureus.

Common Sites

Nape of neck, back.

Symptoms

Red, painful nodule; tender, fluctuant lesion; multiple draining sinuses; fever, lymphadenopathy.

Complications

Septicemia, abscess, necrosis, requiring possible excision or skin graft.

Treatment

Control of diabetes; antibiotics; drainage, debridement, possible excision.

Botryomycosis (Option A) is a chronic bacterial infection, commonly affecting the skin and rarely the soft tissues, often mistaken for an abscess. It is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, or other bacteria, but it presents more as granulomatous lesions rather than the typical pus-filled carbuncle.

Erysipelas (Option B) is a localised cutaneous sharply demarcated infection to the upper layers of the dermis, usually associated with broken skin. It is caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococcus pyogenes. It appears to be a red, swollen, and shiny rash, not a deep abscess with pus or necrotic tissue.

Ecthyma (Option C) is a deeper form of impetigo caused by bacteria (usually Streptococcus), which presents as ulcerative lesions with a crusted appearance, not as a deep abscess with dead tissue and a yellow centre.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of berry aneurysm?

choices.text: Endothelial injury of the vessel due to hypertension
Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

Explanation:

  • Berry aneurysms, also known as saccular aneurysms or intracranial aneurysms, most commonly occur due to a defect in the muscle intimal elastic lamina layer of the blood vessel wall.
  • This defect weakens the vessel wall, leading to the formation of a small outpouching or sac-like dilation.
  • These aneurysms are frequently found in the arteries at the base of the brain, particularly at the branching points of the major cerebral arteries.

 

Endothelial injury of vessels due to hypertension (Option A): While hypertension can contribute to the development and progression of aneurysms, it is not the most common cause of berry aneurysms.

Muscle and adventitial layer defect (Option C) and Adventitia defect (Option D): Berry aneurysms primarily involve the defect in the muscle intimal elastic lamina layer.

questions.text: Which clinical test is being shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Cottle’s test.

Explanation:

  • Cottle’s Test is a diagnostic maneuver used to evaluate nasal obstruction, particularly to assess the patency of the nasal passages and nasal valve function.

  • During this test, the examiner applies external pressure to the lateral nasal walls (just below the cheekbone) to temporarily relieve nasal obstruction.

  • If this improves the patient’s airflow, it suggests nasal valve collapse or dysfunction, which is often seen in patients with deviated septum or nasal valve stenosis.

Cottle’s Test:

  • Cottle's test involves applying pressure to the lateral nasal wall while the patient is instructed to breathe in.

  • If improvement in nasal airflow is noted when external pressure is applied, it indicates that nasal valve collapse is the cause of the obstruction.

  • This test is frequently used before performing surgical interventions, such as septoplasty or rhinoplasty, to confirm the diagnosis of nasal valve insufficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Epley’s maneuver (Option A): is incorrect because it is used for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), not for nasal or facial assessments.

Heimlich maneuver (Option B): is incorrect because it is used for airway obstruction due to choking, not for assessing nasal function.

Trotter’s method (Option D): is incorrect because it is a clinical sign of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, characterized by trismus and nasal obstruction but not a diagnostic maneuver like Cottle's test.

questions.text: A patient, after heavy drinking of alcohol presents with multiple episodes of vomiting and hematemesis. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mallory-Weiss syndrome

Explanation:

  • Given the patient's history of heavy drinking, multiple episodes of vomiting, and hematemesis, the most likely diagnosis is Mallory-Weiss syndrome, where the vomiting-induced tear leads to bleeding from the oesophagus.

Mallory-Weiss syndrome

Definition

It is defined as mucosal lacerations in the gastric mucosa at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction that are caused by forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining.

Epidemiology
  • It accounts for 10-15% of acute upper gastrointestinal haemorrhages.
  • The greatest risk for massive haemorrhage is alcoholic patients with preexisting portal hypertension.

Risk Factors
  • Alcoholic patients with intense vomiting after binge drinking.
  • Forceful abdominal contractions against a closed cardia.
  • Any patient with repeated episodes of emesis.
  • Portal hypertension in alcoholic patients.

Diagnosis
  • The patient's history is crucial.
  • It can be confirmed with endoscopy.
  • Retroflexion manoeuvre during endoscopy is used to view the area below the gastroesophageal junction.

Symptoms

Vomiting, hematemesis, upper abdominal pain, hypotension, tachycardia

Complications

Rarely massive bleeding associated with portal hypertension

Treatment

Endoscopic methods (multipolar electrocoagulation, epinephrine injection, band ligation), angiographic transarterial embolisation, rarely surgery

Prognosis

Generally good with appropriate endoscopic treatment

Esophageal carcinoma (Option B) can present with dysphagia, weight loss, and anorexia. It may cause hematemesis in advanced stages, but it is less likely to be associated with acute episodes of vomiting or retching, as seen in this patient.

Achalasia cardia (Option C) is a disorder of the lower esophageal sphincter, causing difficulty in swallowing and regurgitation of food, but it doesn't usually present with hematemesis or the tears caused by vomiting.

Boerhaave's syndrome (Option D) involves a rupture of the oesophagus due to severe vomiting or retching. It presents with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, pleural effusions, tachypnea, fever, and hypotension. It is a life-threatening condition often associated with violent vomiting, much more severe than Mallory-Weiss syndrome.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for inguinal hernia in infants is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Herniotomy

Explanation:

  • The treatment of choice for inguinal hernia in infants is herniotomy, which involves the removal of the hernial sac.
  • This procedure is preferred in infants as it effectively addresses the condition by removing the sac and preventing further complications, such as incarceration or strangulation, without the need for complex repair techniques used in older patients.

Herniorrhaphy (Option B) is a more complex procedure involving suturing the defect in the abdominal wall, which is more commonly used in older children and adults but not typically in infants due to the smaller size and risks associated with suturing in such delicate tissues.
