One of the methods for cervical ripening involves the use of hygroscopic dilators, which work by absorbing moisture from surrounding tissues to gradually expand and dilate the cervix.

Intracervical laminaria tent is a hygroscopic dilator. Laminaria tents are derived from the dried stems of seaweed. When placed in the cervix, they absorb moisture and expand, gradually dilating the cervix. This method is slow and controlled, often preferred for gentle and gradual ripening.

 

Intracervical dinoprostone gel (Option A): Dinoprostone gel (prostaglandin E2) promotes cervical ripening by softening and thinning the cervix, but it does not work through hygroscopic properties. It is a pharmacological agent used for cervical ripening.

Foley catheter at internal of cervix (Option C): A Foley catheter is a mechanical method for cervical ripening. It involves the insertion of a balloon-tipped catheter into the cervix, which is inflated with sterile water or saline to apply pressure. This method does not involve hygroscopic properties but instead works through mechanical dilation

Misoprostol in posterior fornix (Option D): Misoprostol is a medication used for cervical ripening, but it does not work through hygroscopic mechanisms. It is typically administered orally or vaginally to induce ripening, and its mode of action is through pharmacological pathways rather than absorption of moisture.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a patient who has chronic small bowel diarrhea, claims to have a wheat allergy, and exhibits villous atrophy on duodenal biopsy with tests positive for anti-endomysial antibodies and tissue transglutaminase (TTG) IgA antibodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Celiac sprue

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Celiac sprue or Gluten-sensitive enteropathy based on the classic presentation of chronic small bowel diarrhea, wheat allergy, villous atrophy, and positive serologic markers (anti-endomysial and TTG IgA antibodies), which is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion.

 

Celiac sprue / Celiac disease / Gluten-sensitive enteropathy

Clinical manifestations
  • Diarrhoea, growth failure, and anaemia.
  • Temporal association with the introduction of wheat products at weaning.
  • Abdominal distension, vomiting, anorexia, aphthous stomatitis, and bloating.
  • Rickets, osteoporosis, short stature, muscular atrophy, peripheral neuropathy, and irritability might be seen in some cases.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis can be seen.

Diagnosis:

ESPGHAN (European Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology & Nutrition) guidelines 2020 suggest that in all suspected cases (symptomatic, asymptomatic, and at-risk group), the first test should be total serum IgA and IgAtTG.

 

Serology:

  • Anti-TTG (Tissue Transglutaminase)
  • Anti EMA (Endomysial antibody)
  • Anti-DGP (Deamidated gliadin peptide)

 

Upper GI endoscopy:

  • The endoscopy may be normal or show the absence of folds or scalloped duodenal folds.

 

Histopathology:

  • Villous atrophy/Flat villi
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Intraepithelial lymphocyte infiltration.

Treatment:
  • Treatment involves a gluten-free diet (avoid wheat, rye, barley and oats).
  • High-risk groups include type 1 diabetes mellitus, Down syndrome, selective IgA deficiency, autoimmune thyroid disease, Turner syndrome, Williams syndrome, Addison’s disease, autoimmune liver disease and first-degree relatives of patients with celiac disease.
  • A temporal association may be present with the introduction of wheat products at weaning.

 

While cystic fibrosis (Option A) can cause chronic diarrhea, it is typically associated with respiratory symptoms, pancreatic insufficiency, and positive sweat chloride tests. The specific findings of villous atrophy and positive antibodies are not typical of cystic fibrosis.

Whipple's disease (Option B) causes malabsorption and diarrhea but is characterized by PAS-positive macrophages in biopsy. It has no association with wheat allergy and lacks the specific antibodies mentioned in the case. The condition is attributed to Tropheryma whipplei infection.

Tropical sprue (Option C) can cause villous atrophy but occurs specifically in tropical regions. It has no association with wheat allergy and does not produce the specific antibodies seen in celiac disease. The condition typically responds to antibiotics and folate supplementation.

questions.text: Under which benefit in the ESI act do beneficiaries receive 70% of their wages for a duration of 3 months?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Sickness benefit

Explanation:In the ESI act, the beneficiaries are offered 70% wages for 91 days continuously. An extended sickness benefit is provided for 34 diseases including TB, leprosy, HIV, and mental illness for 2 years at 80% of daily wages.

Benefits of ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act

Medical Benefit (Option B ruled out)
  • Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit (Option A)
  • Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit
  • Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.
  • Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilization procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit (Option C ruled out)

 
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit

 
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit (Option D ruled out)
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, and they are eligible until age 18.
  • If the daughter marries before 18, the benefit is withdrawn.

Funeral Expenses
  • It offers a cash payment of up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation

 
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month for this benefit.
  • A rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance
  • For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

questions.text: 10-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a back deformity. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Idiopathic

Explanation:

  • Idiopathic scoliosis is the most common type of scoliosis, accounting for the majority of cases.
  • It refers to scoliosis of unknown cause and typically develops during adolescence.
  • The age of the patient in this scenario aligns with the typical onset of idiopathic scoliosis, making it the most likely cause.

Scoliosis:

Scoliosis is defined as a lateral curvature of the spine with a Cobb angle of >10°, as measured on a standing radiograph. It commonly develops during adolescence.

Causes:

  1. Idiopathic Scoliosis: Most common, with no known cause. Typically develops in adolescence.
  2. Congenital Scoliosis: Results from abnormal fetal spinal development.
  3. Neuromuscular Scoliosis: Associated with neurological or muscular disorders like cerebral palsy or muscular dystrophy.
  4. Degenerative Scoliosis: Caused by age-related degeneration, often seen in older adults.

Types:

  1. Structural Scoliosis: Permanent curvature of the spine.
  2. Nonstructural Scoliosis: Functional or temporary, often corrects when lying down.

Clinical Features:

  1. Uneven shoulders or hips.
  2. Leaning to one side due to spinal curvature.
  3. Prominent ribs or shoulder blade on one side.
  4. Asymmetrical back appearance, especially when bending forward.
  5. Muscle imbalances causing fatigue and discomfort.
  6. Back pain, especially during prolonged sitting or standing.

Incorrect Options:

Congenital (Option A): Congenital scoliosis occurs due to malformation of the vertebrae during fetal development and is usually detected much earlier (infancy or early childhood).

NF1 (Option B): Neurofibromatosis type 1 can cause scoliosis, but it’s associated with other features like café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, or a family history.

Neuromuscular (Option D): Neuromuscular scoliosis is seen in children with neurological or muscular disorders like cerebral palsy or muscular dystrophy, which would have associated clinical findings.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Aedes aegypti

Explanation: Zika virus disease should be considered in patients with acute onset of fever, maculopapular rash, and arthralgia, particularly if they have travelled to areas with ongoing transmission in the two weeks before symptom onset. Zica virus is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.

Zika virus disease:

Agent: Zika virus is a Flavivirus transmitted via mosquito bite; hence, it is called an arbovirus.

Mode of Transmission:

  • Transmitted by the bite of an infected Aedes aegypti mosquito, which tends to bite during the morning and late afternoon.
  • It is also increasingly recognized that an infected pregnant woman can pass the virus to her baby during pregnancy or near the time of birth.

Clinical Symptoms: Fever, skin rash, conjunctivitis, joint pain, headache. Symptoms are usually mild and last 2-7 days.

Prevention: Prevention and control depend on reducing mosquitoes through the removal and modification of breeding sites.

Culex mosquito (Option B): Primarily known for transmitting West Nile virus and other arboviruses.

Anopheles mosquito (Option C): Primarily known for transmitting malaria.

Phlebotomus (Option D): It is a sandfly known for transmitting Kala-azar.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect concerning medical termination of pregnancy?

choices.text: Baby with serious mental or physical abnormality

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) When the family is large

Explanation:

  • When the family is large The size of the family alone is not a valid medical or legal indication for the termination of pregnancy. The decision for termination must be based on health risks, fetal abnormalities, or other more pressing medical or social factors, rather than family size
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) is generally allowed for specific medical, social, or legal reasons. The criteria for MTP vary by jurisdiction.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act:

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome. (Option C)
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape. (Option A)
    • Contraceptive Failure. (Option D)
  • Qualifications:
    • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
    • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
    • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
    • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.
  • Additions of 2021 amendment:
    • Abortions allowed up to 20-24 weeks.
    • <20 weeks - Single doctor’s decision; 20-24 weeks - 2 doctors.
    • Extension of abortion rights to single, unmarried females.
    • Inclusion of marital rape under the MTP Act.
    • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit, are to be decided by a state medical board (gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist).

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion. (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

 

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy

questions.text: What is the required thickness of a lead apron used for radiation protection?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) 0.5mm

Explanation:

  • The ideal thickness of lead aprons to prevent the technicians from radiation hazards is 0.5 mm.
  • Radiation exposure is hazardous (dose-dependent), ranging from acute radiation sickness up to genetic mutations, fetal anomalies and carcinogenesis.

RADIATION DOSE

BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS

<5 rad
  • No adverse effects

 

5-150 rad
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Mild haematological changes

 

150-1100 rad
  • Bone marrow failure (anaemia, infections, bleeding tendency - might require bone marrow transplantation)

 

1100-2000 rad
  • Gastrointestinal destruction in addition (death almost always occurs in a few weeks)

>2000 rad
  • Muscle and brain damage (death occurs in days)
  • Employees who are exposed to radiation should
    • Wear a lead apron 0.5 mm thick. (Option C)
    • Wear a dosimeter to be checked from time to time.
  • Radiation hygiene: Preventive measures, continued watchfulness and safe disposal of radioactive waste materials.
  • Creating awareness through seminars.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with a productive cough. He is a chronic smoker and alcoholic. CXR is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Consolidation
 

Explanation:

  • Consolidation refers to a condition in which the air spaces in the lungs fill with fluid, inflammatory exudates, or cellular infiltrates, leading to the loss of normal air-filled lung tissue.
  • On chest X-ray (CXR), consolidation appears as an area of increased opacity due to the filling of alveoli with fluid, pus, or other substances.
  • In this case, the patient's chronic smoking and alcoholism increase the risk of developing respiratory infections.

 

 

CXR Radiological Findings

Associated Diseases

Consolidation

Pneumonia, Lung abscess

Infiltrates

Pulmonary edema, ARDS

Atelectasis

Obstructive lung disease, Pneumothorax

Blunting of the Costophrenic Angle

Pleural effusion, Empyema

Cavity

Tuberculosis, Lung abscess

Nodule/mass

Lung cancer, Pulmonary metastasis

Ground-glass opacities

Interstitial lung diseases (e.g., Pulmonary fibrosis, Pneumoconiosis)

Honeycombing

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, End-stage interstitial lung disease

Air bronchograms

Consolidation, Alveolar processes

Mediastinal shift

Pneumothorax, Large pleural effusion, Mediastinal mass

 

 

Abscess (Option A): They would typically appear as a cavity with an air-fluid level, which is not mentioned here.

Cavity filled with air & fluid

Cavity (Option C): Cavities have distinct air-fluid levels and thin or thick walls, seen in tuberculosis.

Pleural effusion (Option D): This would present with obliteration of the costophrenic angle and/or meniscus sign, not described in this case.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G3 P1L1 A1 at 37 weeks of gestation with a previous history of emergency caesarean section and dilatation and curettage presents to the ER with labor pains. During abdominal examination, it was difficult to palpate fetal parts. Per vaginal examination revealed a 5 cm dilated cervix, and her vitals were: BP-80/60 mmHg, RR – 20/min, HR – 106/min, SpO2 – 97% on room air. CTG showed a non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Placental abruption

Explanation:

  • Placental abruption involves partial or complete detachment of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. This leads to severe abdominal pain, difficult palpation of fetal parts, hypotension, tachycardia, and non-reassuring fetal heart patterns, as seen in this patient.
  • Abruptio placenta is a form of antepartum haemorrhage, where the bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

Pathogenesis:

  • Bleeding occurs due to rupture of blood vessels in the decidua basalis.
  • There is an accumulation of blood in the decidua.
  • This causes the separation of the placenta, leading to
    • Further bleeding.
    • Thrombin generation from haemorrhage triggers the action of matrix metalloproteinases, inflammatory cytokines, and coagulation cascade (high risk of DIC).
    • Fetal distress.

Clinical features:

  • Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding
  • Abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Back pain
  • Fetal distress
  • Hypovolemic shock
  • Frequent contractions

Types of abruptio placenta:

Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed

  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

 

 

Page Classification of abruptio placentae:

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

 

Comparison of findings in placenta previa and abruptio placentae:

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

 

Amniotic fluid embolism (Option A) typically presents with respiratory distress and cardiovascular collapse, not consistent with the described findings.

Uterine rupture (Option C) causes severe pain and maternal shock but is less likely here, given the clinical presentation.

Placenta previa (Option D) usually presents with painless bleeding rather than severe abdominal pain and abnormal fetal heart rate patterns.

questions.text: In a boarding school where students share the same canteen, one student experienced abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. Subsequently, other students began showing similar symptoms. Which investigations should the local medical officer consider in order to arrive at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) IgM for hepatitis A

Explanation: Hepatitis A is transmitted by the faecal-oral route. Hence the students can be suspected of acquiring Hepatitis A from the contaminated food. The diagnostic tests for Hepatitis A are a Stool sample, and an Anti HAV IgM antibody performed after 2 weeks of increase in the liver enzyme.

Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

  • Most Common Cause of viral hepatitis in Children
  • Most Common Cause of Acute Relapsing viral hepatitis

Virus characteristics:

  • HAV is a 27-nm, nonenveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus, resistant to heat, acid, and ether.

Mode of Transmission: Fecal-oral route.

Incubation period: ~3–4 weeks.

Pathogenesis:

  • Replication is limited to the liver but found in the liver, bile, stools, and blood during the late incubation and pre-icteric phases.
  • Faecal shedding, viremia, and infectivity decrease rapidly once jaundice appears.

Clinical presentation:

  • Asymptomatic cases
  • Jaundice
  • Cholestatic hepatitis
  • Fulminant hepatitis - Acute liver failure especially in older adults or those with preexisting liver conditions.
  • Does not lead to chronic liver disease.

Diagnosis:

  • Acute illness - anti-HAV IgM antibodies. (Option B)
  • HAV RNA can persist in stools, liver, and serum for months after acute illness but is not correlated with persistent infectivity.
  • Previous infection: IgG anti-HAV
  • LFT: Elevated bilirubin, serum aminotransferases, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

Treatment:

  • Most cases are self-limiting
  • No specific antiviral treatment
  • Symptomatic management (10 % Dextrose)

Prevention:

  • Inactivated vaccination: Single antigen or in combination with hepatitis B
  • Good sanitary conditions and measures

IgA for hepatitis A (Option A): IgA is not specific to Hepatitis A and does not give accurate results.

IgM for hepatitis B (Option C) and IgG for hepatitis B (Option D): Hepatitis A is transmitted by the faecal-oral route. Whereas hepatitis B is transmitted through blood or body fluids.

questions.text: A nurse got an accidental prick from a needle used for an HIV+ patient. Which single test would lead to a confirmatory diagnosis in her?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Western blot assay

Explanation:

LABORATORY DIAGNOSIS OF HIV INFECTION

Screening tests

ELISA screens for HIV antibodies (most sensitive) (Option C ruled out)

Confirmatory tests
  • Western blot - A confirmatory test confirms specific antibodies against p24 and gp41 proteins. (highly specific) (Option D)
  • Confirmatory test for adults - qPCR for HIV1 (Option B ruled out)
  • Confirmatory tests of infants < 1 year - HIV DNA RT-PCR

Virus Isolation

Direct virus testing is not standard; HIV isolation from cultured lymphocytes is costly and resource-intensive.

CD4 Lymphocyte Count

Most reliable predictor of HIV progression; absolute count indicates immune system health, with <200 cells/µL signalling a high risk of AIDS-related infections.

CD4 Lymphocyte Percentage

Independent indicator of disease progression; <14% suggests a heightened risk of AIDS-related complications.

HIV Viral Load Tests

Measure actively replicating HIV in blood; correlate with disease progression and assess antiretroviral therapy effectiveness.

Other Markers
  • Beta-2 microglobulin (B2M) levels and p24 antigen presence indicate immune activation and viral replication, aiding disease assessment.
  • P24 antigen tests positive in the window period (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding UTI in pregnancy?

choices.text: It is lower in people with sickle cell trait
The preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin
If ASB is not treated, 75% of them will develop symptomatic infection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) If ASB is not treated, 75% of them will develop symptomatic infection

Explanation:

  • Untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) in pregnancy can progress to symptomatic urinary tract infections (UTIs), significantly increasing the risk of complications such as pyelonephritis, preterm labor, and low birth weight. Therefore, routine screening and prompt treatment of ASB during pregnancy are essential to ensure maternal and fetal well-being.

Asymptomatic Bacteriuria (ASB)

  • ≥10^5 CFU/mL of a single bacterium in urine without UTI symptoms.

Causative organisms: E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterococcus, Proteus.

Risk factors: Female sex, age, diabetes, pregnancy, urinary tract abnormalities, catheters, immunosuppressive conditions.

Diagnosis: Urine culture: ≥10^5 CFU/mL without symptoms.

Management:

  • Pregnant women: Requires treatment (e.g., nitrofurantoin, amoxicillin).
  • Non-pregnant women: Generally, no treatment unless symptomatic.
  • Elderly and catheterized patients: Treatment is usually not recommended unless symptomatic.

Complications:

  • Pyelonephritis
  • Preterm delivery
  • Low birth weight
  • Antibiotic resistance

Prevention: Pregnancy screening at 12–16 weeks.

 

The prevalence of ASB is 50% (Option A): The prevalence of ASB during pregnancy is not as high as 50%. It is typically estimated to be around 5-10%.

It is lower in people with sickle cell trait (Option B): Sickle cell trait does not reduce the risk of UTIs in pregnancy. In fact, individuals with sickle cell trait may have a higher risk of developing infections due to compromised renal function.

The preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin (Option C): While amoxicillin is safe in pregnancy and commonly used, the choice of antibiotics is guided by culture sensitivity results and local resistance patterns. Nitrofurantoin and cephalexin are also frequently used.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and cough with expectoration. The chest X-ray has been shown below. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Pneumococcus

Explanation:

  • The chest X-ray showed features of round pneumonia and the patient presented with fever and cough with expectoration, the likely causative organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Round pneumonia is a term used to describe a specific radiographic appearance of pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumonia.

Disease

Radiological Findings

Staphylococcal Pneumonia (Option D)

Air Bronchogram

Mycoplasma Pneumonia

Reticulonodular Markings

Klebsiella Pneumonia

Bulging Fissure Sign

Legionella Pneumonia

Bilateral Multifocal Consolidation

Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia

Reticular Shadows and multiple cysts more often in the upper part of the lungs.

Lung Abscess

Air-Fluid Level

Aspergilloma

Fungal ball/ Monad sign

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis

Gloved-Finger Sign

Invasive Aspergillosis

Air-Crescent Sign/ Halo sign

Adenoid Hypertrophy

Adenoid Enlargement

Acute Epiglottitis

Thumb Sign

Croup (Parainfluenza) (Option B)

Steeple Sign

Mucormycosis

Reverse halo sign/Bird nest sign/Atoll sign

Haemophilus influenzae (Option A)

Patchy or segmental consolidation, may have pleural effusion

questions.text: The blood pressure of 200 hypertensive patients is being compared after 3 months. One group of 100 patients received medical advice, while the other group of 100 patients were advised to make lifestyle changes. Which test of significance is used to compare the blood pressure in these two groups?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Un-paired T test

Explanation:As this is a qualitative test, we need to use a non-parametric test such as the Unpaired T-Test to compare the blood pressures after 3 months. Since we are comparing two groups we use an unpaired t test and not the paired t test.

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's t-test (Option B)

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option A ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

Chi-Square Test (Option C): It is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables.

McNemar's test (Option D): Non-parametric test is used only when there is one group.

questions.text: What is the rare and hazardous complication associated with Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measles

Explanation:

  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is a rare fatal, severe, long-standing complication of measles. It is a progressive neurological disorder that affects the central nervous system. It typically develops 7-13 years after primary measles infection.
     

Complications of Measles:

  • Otitis media (m/c complication), Pneumonia (m/c cause of death), other respiratory complications - bronchitis, laryngitis, etc.
  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE): Rare, fatal and long term complication.
  • Acute encephalitis

 

Prevention

  • Measles is a preventable and potentially eradicable disease.
  • Maternal antibodies protect infants until 6-9 months of age, so administering the vaccine at 9 months in endemic countries ensures early protection and seroconversion.
  • The measles vaccine, derived from the Edmonston-Zagreb strain, is available as a monovalent preparation or in combination with rubella (MR), mumps (MMR), and varicella (MMR-V).
  • The vaccine schedule is as follows:

Vaccine

MR (Measles-Rubella)

Type

Live attenuated

Dose

0.5 ml

Site

Anterolateral thigh or right upper arm (at the insertion of deltoid)

Schedule

1st dose - 9 months; 2nd dose - 16-24 months

questions.text: What kit would you recommend for a 30-year-old woman who has been experiencing creamy discharge with a fishy odor for the past month, AMSEL's score of 3 out of 4 on the Whiff test, and positive amines in the secretion when tested with 10% KОН?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) Green kit

Explanation: It is indicative of Bacterial vaginosis. The colour-coded kit for vaginitis in the Syndromic management of STI kits is green.

Suraksha Clinics: Integrating STI/RTI Treatment and HIV/AIDS Control
  • Government STI/RTI clinics, branded as "Suraksha Clinics," offer free standardized integrated STD and RTI treatment services at district-level and above healthcare facilities.
  • Under National AIDS Control Program (NACP)

Referral Centers
  • STD Clinics at district, block, and First Referral Unit (FRU) levels act as referral centers for specialized treatment.

Counselling and Condom Distribution
  • Counselling services and high-quality condoms are provided to promote safer sexual practices.
  • Utilizes the expertise of NGOs in providing counselling services at STD clinics.

Training and strengthening existing centers
  • Existing STD clinics in hospitals and medical colleges are strengthened with technical support, equipment,
  • Training for medical staff to manage STDs/RTIs using a syndromic approach.

Pre-packed STI/RTI Color-Coded Kits
  • Free pre-packed kits provided to clinics, centrally procured and distributed through State AIDS Control Societies.

Kit Colors and Conditions

Kit 1 (Grey) (Option D ruled out)

Urethral discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis (Option A)

Kit 2 (Green) (Option C)

Vaginitis

Kit 3 (White) (Non-herpetic)

Genital ulcers

Kit 4 (Blue) (non-herpetic) in patient allergic to penicillin (Option B ruled out)

Genital ulcers

Kit 5 (Red) (herpetic) (Option A ruled out)

Genital ulcers

Kit 6 (Yellow)

Lower abdominal pain (PID)

Kit 7 (Black)

Inguinal bubo

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding should be continued for a minimum of how many months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 6 months

Explanation:

  • Breastfeeding is exclusively recommended for the first 6 months of life. It ensures child health and higher survival rates. While exclusive breastfeeding is highly beneficial during the first six months, continuing it alone can lead to nutritional deficiencies. By 9 months, the baby needs additional nutrients, such as iron, so complementary feeding should begin around 6 months to meet the baby's nutritional needs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes with chronic vulval itching and pain. On examination, there is a vulval lesion suspicious of vulval cancer. Which of the following lymph node/s should be considered for sentinel node biopsy to look for the metastatic spread?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

Explanation:

Superficial inguinal lymph nodes:

  • Vulval cancer primarily drains lymph to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, which are the first-echelon nodes.
  • Sentinel node biopsy in vulval cancer targets these nodes to detect regional metastatic spread early, minimizing the need for extensive lymphadenectomy.

 

Vulval cancer

Age Group

Most common in elderly women, especially in the 6th and 7th decades, (50-70 years age group)

Risk Factors

HPV infections, HSV infections, smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., lichen sclerosis).

Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type.

Common Sites
  • Labia majora: Most common site (60%).
  • Clitoris: Second most common site (15%).

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) growth.
  • Ulcerative lesions.

Symptoms
  • Pruritus (most common), often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Swelling, lump, or ulcer.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain (late symptom).

Spread
  • Primarily through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Commonly involved lymph nodes: Inguinofemoral.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly impacts prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy: Preferred for lesions < 1 cm, for histological assessment of invasion depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm.
  • Wedge biopsy, Keyes punch biopsy, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (to assess inguinofemoral node involvement).

Treatment
  • Vulvectomy: Partial or total, depending on disease stage.
  • Inguinal lymph node dissection: To evaluate disease spread.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (Superficial inguinal lymph nodes): Determines stage and prognosis.

 

Pelvic lymph nodes (Option A) are involved in later stages of vulval cancer. They are not first-line nodes for sentinel biopsy.

Cloquet node (Rosenmüller node) (Option B) is a deep inguinal node, located near the femoral canal, may be involved in advanced disease but is not routinely targeted in sentinel node biopsy.

Deep inguinal lymph nodes (Option D) are Though involved in advanced vulval cancer, these nodes are downstream of the superficial inguinal nodes and are not sentinel nodes.

questions.text: During her routine antenatal check-up, a 25-year-old woman's arterial blood gas analysis revealed an abnormality characterized by elevated pH and reduced carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the blood. What type of arterial gas abnormality would likely be observed in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chronic respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

  • Respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is a decrease in CO2 levels in the blood due to hyperventilation, leading to an elevated pH. Chronic respiratory alkalosis indicates that this process has been ongoing for some time, allowing for partial renal compensation (reduction in bicarbonate).

ABG features in pregnancy:

  • pH: Slightly elevated (due to reduced CO2).
  • CO2: Decreased (due to hyperventilation from progesterone).
  • Bicarbonate: Slightly reduced (compensatory renal response).
  • ABG Pattern: Mild respiratory alkalosis with partial compensation (reduced bicarbonate).

 

During pregnancy, women often experience mild hyperventilation due to increased progesterone levels, leading to reduced CO2 and a slightly elevated pH. The body partially compensates over time, but the primary abnormality remains respiratory in nature.

Acute metabolic acidosis (Option A) is characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to an accumulation of acids (like lactic acid) or a loss of bicarbonate.

Acute metabolic alkalosis (Option B) is characterized by an increase in blood pH due to an excess of bicarbonate or a loss of hydrogen ions (e.g., from vomiting).

questions.text: A mother of a 5-day-old baby presents with the complaint that her baby is “unable to latch on” for breastfeeding. She also says there is some leakage of milk at times, and on examination, there is bilateral tenderness and swelling. What is the most likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Breast engorgement

Explanation:

  • Based on the given information, the most likely cause of the mother's symptoms is breast engorgement.
  • Breast engorgement is a common condition that occurs in the early postpartum period when there is excessive swelling and fullness of the breasts. This often results in difficulty with the baby latching properly. The leakage of milk, as well as the bilateral tenderness and swelling, align with the symptoms of breast engorgement.
  • This condition typically arises in the first few days after childbirth due to hormonal changes that increase blood flow, milk production, and fluid accumulation in the breasts. If the baby is not effectively breastfeeding or emptying the breasts, engorgement can occur.

 

Bacterial mastitis (Option A) usually presents with localized redness, warmth, pain, and swelling of the breast, often accompanied by flu-like symptoms such as fever and body aches. While tenderness and swelling are present in the case, the information provided does not suggest the presence of systemic symptoms commonly associated with bacterial mastitis.

A breast abscess (Option B) is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue. It typically occurs as a complication of untreated mastitis. The presence of bilateral tenderness and swelling is not consistent with a breast abscess, as it usually involves a specific area of the breast and may present with a visible fluctuant mass or localized pain.

Lactational mastitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of the breast tissue, often caused by milk stasis or blocked milk ducts. It can lead to redness, pain, and swelling in the affected area. While lactational mastitis is a possibility, the bilateral tenderness and swelling described in the case suggest a more generalized breast engorgement rather than a localized inflammation.

questions.text: A female patient, who is in the 8th week of her pregnancy, came for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). What would be the correct dosage of Misoprostol given through the mucosal route?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 800 mcg

Explanation:

  • In pregnancy greater than 7 weeks, a higher dose of 800 mcg may be used as a single dose or in divided doses to further facilitate the completion of the abortion process.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act:

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
    • Contraceptive Failure.
  • Qualifications:
    • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
    • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
    • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
    • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.
  • Additions of 2021 amendment:
    • Abortions allowed up to 20-24 weeks.
    • <20 weeks - Single doctor’s decision; 20-24 weeks - 2 doctors.
    • Extension of abortion rights to single, unmarried females.
    • Inclusion of marital rape under the MTP Act.
    • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit, are to be decided by a state medical board (gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist).

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks
  • Medical Abortion. (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks
  • Hysterotomy

 

Stepwise Approach for MTP:

  • Mifepristone (200mg): Administered orally on day 1. Mifepristone is a progesterone antagonist, which leads to the detachment of the pregnancy from the uterine lining, causing fetal death.
  • Misoprostol (800 mcg): Administered 24-48 hours later through vaginal, sublingual, or buccal routes. Misoprostol induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy.

Confirmation: Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 after the procedure to ensure the termination is complete.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is presented by her mother due to concerns that the child has not experienced her first menstrual period. Upon examination, the presence of secondary sexual characteristics is observed, and ultrasound imaging reveals a normal uterus and ovaries. What would be the subsequent course of action in managing this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reassure mother and patient

Explanation:

  • Delayed onset of menstruation is considered normal in some cases, particularly when secondary sexual characteristics are present.
  • Menstruation can be absent until the age of 15 years, which is within the normal range of puberty development.
  • Reassurance and educating the family about normal variations in the onset of menstruation are appropriate steps. If menstruation has not started by the age of 16 or if other concerns arise, further evaluation can be pursued.

Delayed Puberty refers to:

  • No periods till 13 years if secondary sexual characters are absent.
  • No periods till 15 years if secondary sexual characters are present.

Causes of Delayed Puberty

Category

Causes

Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
  • Constitutional delay
  • Chronic illness, malnutrition
  • Primary hypothyroidism
  • Isolated gonadotropin deficiency (Kallman’s Syndrome)
  • Intracranial lesions- Tumors (craniopharyngioma, pituitary adenomas)

Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (Turner’s Syndrome)
  • Pure gonadal dysgenesis
  • Ovarian failure

Eugonadism
  • Anatomic causes (Mullerian agenesis, Imperforate hymen)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome

 

Combined oral contraceptives (Option A): Not indicated in this case. Contraceptives are used to regulate menstrual cycles or for contraception, which is not necessary for a 14-year-old girl who has not yet started menstruating.

Karyotyping (Option B): The presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal uterus and ovaries on ultrasound suggest normal physiological development, so karyotyping is not necessary at this point.

LH, FSH level and TSH testing (Option D): Since secondary sexual characteristics are normal and the ultrasound findings are unremarkable, hormonal testing is unnecessary unless other symptoms are present or the delay persists beyond typical developmental timelines.

questions.text: What type of learning is demonstrated when a doctor instructs an intern on proper technique for performing the knee reflex, emphasizing its significance in clinical practice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Psychomotor learning

Explanation:

  • Psychomotor learning refers to the acquisition of motor skills or physical movements through practice and repetition. In this scenario, the doctor is teaching the intern how to perform the knee reflex test, which involves a physical examination technique. The intern is expected to learn and develop the necessary motor skills to perform the knee reflex accurately.

 

Cognitive learning (Option A): Cognitive learning refers to the acquisition of knowledge, understanding, or mental skills.

Affective learning (Option C): Affective learning pertains to the acquisition of attitudes, values, or emotional responses.

Repeated learning (Option D): Repeated learning is a generic term that doesn't specify the type of learning involved.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings will be observed in a 19-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, amenorrhea, fatigue, and a history of being constantly worried about weight gain, accompanied by poor appetite and a BMI of 15.8?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperthyroidism

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, including weakness, amenorrhea, fatigue, poor appetite, and a low BMI (indicative of possible weight loss), suggest hyperthyroidism.
  • This condition occurs due to excessive thyroid hormone production, leading to increased metabolic rates and symptoms such as weight loss, fatigue, and amenorrhea.
  • The constant worry about weight gain may also indicate an underlying thyroid imbalance, as hyperthyroidism can cause disturbances in mood and appetite.

 

Hypocholesterolaemia (Option A) is not typically associated with hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is more likely to cause a reduction in cholesterol levels due to increased metabolism, but it is not a prominent laboratory finding in this case.

Hypersecretion of corticotropin-releasing hormone (Option C) is more related to conditions like Cushing's syndrome, which involves excess cortisol production. The symptoms described in this case do not align with those of Cushing's syndrome.

Hyperglycaemia (Option D) is not a typical characteristic of hyperthyroidism. In fact, the increased metabolism in hyperthyroidism may lead to more glucose utilization, which could potentially result in hypoglycemia rather than hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which organization is involved in intersectoral coordination in the integrated child development services (ICDS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) NHM

Explanation:

  • NHM is the National Health Mission. There is inter-sectorial coordination between the ICDS and the NHM. Their coordination is focused on the nutrition of the child and the child's health care.

The components of NHM:

 

Goals of NHM:

Reduce Infant Mortality Rate to 25/1000 live births

Reduce Maternal Mortality Rate to 1/1000 live births

Reduce Total Fertility Rate to 2.1

Reduce annual incidence and mortality from TB by half.

Reduce prevalence of Leprosy to <1/10000 population and incidence to zero in all districts

Annual malaria incidence to < 1/1000.

<1% microfilaria prevalence in all districts.

Eliminate kala-azar by 2015

 

Components of RMNCAH+N:

 

 

NACO (Option B): NACO is the National AIDS Control organization and it does not work in coordination with ICDS.

NLEP (Option C): NLEP is the National Leprosy Eradication Program and it does not work in coordination with ICDS.

UNDP (Option D): UNDP is the United Nations development program and it does not work in coordination with ICDS.

questions.text: What are the potential long-term consequences of this condition in a 25-year-old female with a previous history of chlamydia infection who currently presents with mild fever, non-specific lower abdominal pain, mild diffuse tenderness upon deep palpation in the lower abdomen, cervical motion tenderness, and mucopurulent discharge from the vagina?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infertility

Explanation:

  • The patient likely has pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to a previous chlamydia infection, and untreated or recurrent PID can cause scarring and damage to the reproductive organs, particularly the fallopian tubes.
  • This scarring can lead to infertility or an increased risk of ectopic pregnancy. PID is a major cause of infertility in women, especially if left untreated.

 

Pelvic inflammatory disease

Pathogenesis

Infection ascends from the cervix and endometrium to the fallopian tubes and ovaries, causing inflammation and scarring. Can lead to infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain.

Aetiology

Acute:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, E. coli, Mycoplasma genitalium, Anaerobes (Bacteroides species), Gardnerella vaginalis, Trichomonas vaginalis, Streptococci, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Actinomyces israelii.

 

Chronic: Same as acute, with possible additional mixed infections.

Clinical Features

Signs:

Fever, Purulent cervical discharge, Cervical motion tenderness, Adnexal tenderness, Abdominal tenderness.

 

Symptoms:

Lower abdominal pain, Abnormal vaginal discharge, Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse), Dysuria (pain during urination), Menstrual irregularities, Nausea and vomiting.

Complications
  • Infertility: Due to scarring and damage to fallopian tubes.
  • Ectopic Pregnancy
  • Chronic Pelvic Pain
  • Peritonitis
  • Sepsis

Laboratory Findings

Elevated WBC, Elevated CRP, Elevated ESR.

Ultrasound: Thickened, fluid-filled fallopian tubes and free pelvic fluid.

Next Step in Diagnosis

Endocervical Swab: Detects key pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae to guide treatment and prevent complications.

Treatment

First-line Therapy:

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose, or

Cefoxitin 2g IM single dose + Probenecid 1g PO single dose, or

Cefotaxime IV.

Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 14 days, with or without Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD for 14 days.

Male Partner Treatment

Treat with Cefixime + Azithromycin (Grey kit in India) to prevent reinfection.

Out-patient Therapy (India)

Yellow kit: Ceftriaxone, Doxycycline, Metronidazole for syndromic management.

 

Uterine cancer (Option B): It arises from the lining of the uterus and is influenced by factors like hormonal imbalances and genetics. Chlamydia infection or PID is not a known cause of uterine cancer.

Pelvic organ prolapse (Option C): Although chronic infections can contribute to pelvic floor weakness, pelvic organ prolapse is not a direct long-term consequence of chlamydia or PID.

Cervical cancer (Option D): While chlamydia infection can increase the risk of acquiring other sexually transmitted infections (such as HPV), which is a known risk factor for cervical cancer, chlamydia itself is not a direct cause of cervical cancer.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action for a 26-year-old woman who is not married and experiencing irregular menstrual cycles despite having a history of regular periods, with a normal pelvic examination?

choices.text: Reassure her that it’s normal to have delayed periods

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Beta hCG estimation

Explanation:

  • The first step in a woman with irregular menstrual cycles, especially with a history of regular periods, is to rule out pregnancy.
  • A beta hCG test is used to detect pregnancy, and it is essential to ensure that the irregular cycles are not caused by pregnancy before further investigation or management.

Condition

Serial beta-hCG Measurement

Normal Intrauterine Pregnancy

Rising beta-hCG (doubling every 1.4–2 days)

Ectopic Pregnancy

Plateauing or declining beta-hCG

Threatened Abortion

Variable beta-hCG changes

Early Pregnancy Loss

Declining beta-hCG

hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin)

  • hCG is a glycoprotein hormone secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.
  • It can be detected in the maternal blood and urine as early as 8–9 days post-fertilization using techniques like radioimmunoassay. During early pregnancy, hCG levels double every 1.4–2 days.

Functions of hCG:

  • Rescue of the Corpus Luteum: The primary role of hCG is to stimulate the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum during the first 6 weeks of pregnancy, maintaining the uterine environment.
  • Leydig Cell Stimulation: It stimulates Leydig cells in the male fetus to produce testosterone, crucial for male sexual differentiation.
  • Steroidogenesis: hCG supports steroid hormone production by the adrenal glands and placenta.
  • Thyrotropic Activity: It stimulates the maternal thyroid gland due to its structural similarity to TSH, leading to mild thyroid activation during pregnancy.
  • Relaxin Secretion: hCG promotes the secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum, which helps in softening the cervix and ligaments in late pregnancy.

Clinical Implications of hCG Levels:

  • High hCG levels: Associated with multiple pregnancies, hydatidiform mole, choriocarcinoma, and Down syndrome (trisomy 21).
  • Low hCG levels: Seen in ectopic pregnancies and impending miscarriages.

 

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option A): While useful for evaluating pelvic organs and identifying conditions like ovarian cysts or fibroids, a transvaginal ultrasound is not the first step when pregnancy is a possibility.

Reassure her that it’s normal to have delayed periods (Option B): While occasional menstrual irregularities can occur due to factors like stress or hormonal changes, given the patient’s history of regular cycles, further evaluation is needed to rule out other causes, particularly pregnancy.

Serum FSH and LH (Option D): Serum FSH and LH are useful for evaluating the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, especially when conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) are suspected. However, ruling out pregnancy should be the first step in this case.

questions.text: A patient is seen in the OPD after her delivery, which was 5 days ago. She presents with smelly greenish vaginal discharge. What is the initial investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Per vagina examination

Explanation:

  • The first step in investigating smelly greenish vaginal discharge postpartum is a per vagina examination. This helps assess the discharge, identify signs of infection or inflammation, and collect samples for analysis, such as a vaginal swab, to determine the cause and guide management

Trichomonas Vaginitis

  • Trichomonas vaginitis, caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age, typically transmitted sexually.

Symptoms:

  • Yellowish-Green, Frothy Discharge: Foul-smelling.
  • Vulvar Irritation & Itching: Around the vaginal opening.
  • Painful Urination (Dysuria).
  • Dyspareunia: Pain during intercourse.
  • "Strawberry Cervix": Punctate hemorrhages on the cervix.
  • Recurrent Infections.

Organism:

  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan.
  • It thrives in the vaginal and cervical mucosa, causing inflammation.
  • Infective & Diagnostic Stage: Trophozoite

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination:
    • Profuse, frothy yellow-green discharge.
    • Strawberry cervix.
  • Microscopy (Wet Mount): Motile Trichomonas vaginalis seen under the microscope.
  • Vaginal pH: Elevated (>4.5).
  • Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT): Gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Culture: Less common, but highly accurate.
  • Rapid Antigen Test: Point-of-care, less sensitive than NAAT.

Treatment:

  • Metronidazole or Tinidazole: Single or multi-dose regimen.
  • Treat both sexual partners to prevent reinfection.

Feature

Bacterial Vaginosis

Candidiasis

Trichomoniasis

Causative agent

Overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and others

Candida albicans or other Candida species

Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan)

Discharge appearance

Thin, gray-white, homogeneous

Thick, white, "cottage cheese-like"

Yellow-green, frothy

Odor

Fishy (especially post-coital or with KOH)

None or mild

Foul-smelling

Vaginal pH

> 4.5

≤ 4.5

> 4.5

Whiff Test

Positive (fishy odor with KOH)

Negative

May be positive

Microscopy

Clue cells, few lactobacilli

Hyphae or pseudohyphae, spores

Motile trichomonads, many WBCs

Associated symptoms

Often asymptomatic, may have itching or irritation

Intense itching, burning, dyspareunia

Itching, burning, erythema

Treatment

Metronidazole or clindamycin

Fluconazole or topical antifungals

Metronidazole or tinidazole

 

Complete blood count (CBC) (Option A) CBC can help detect signs of infection, such as an elevated white blood cell count. However, it is not the first step in investigating postpartum vaginal discharge, though it may be ordered later if an infection is suspected or confirmed to evaluate the severity.

USG (Option B) may be used if the per vagina examination suggests complications like retained placental tissue or uterine infection, but it is not the initial investigation for vaginal discharge.

Urine analysis (Option C) is not relevant in this case, as the symptoms are focused on vaginal discharge. A urine test would be more appropriate if urinary tract infection (UTI) symptoms were present.

questions.text: As a senior resident in the OBG department, which of the following cases would you not consider uterine artery embolization as a treatment option?

choices.text: Prior to the removal of placenta accreta in a multiparous woman
Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

Explanation:

  • Calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids are fibroids that have hardened and developed a stalk, projecting into the uterine cavity. These fibroids are better managed by surgical removal, such as hysteroscopic resection, rather than uterine artery embolization (UAE).
  • UAE is generally indicated for larger, intramural fibroids or multiple fibroids causing symptoms like heavy menstrual bleeding or pain.

Fibroid (Uterine Leiomyoma)

  • Benign smooth muscle tumor of the uterus.
  • Estrogen-dependent growth; typically regresses after menopause.
  • Commonly occurs in reproductive-age women.

Types (Based on Location):

  • These fibroids are classified as Type 0 under the FIGO classification of fibroids.

FIGO Classification of Fibroids.

 

Type

Name

Submucosal

0

Pedunculated, Intracavity

1

<50% Intramural and rest in cavity

2

≥ 50% Intramural and a part in cavity

3

100% intramural but contacts endometrium

Intramural

4

Intramural

Subserosal

5

≥ 50% Intramural and partly in serosa

6

<50% Intramural and rest in serosa

7

Subserosal Pedunculated

Others

8

Other - Cervical, Parasitic

2-5

Hybrid - Present both in the cavity (type 2) and in the serosa (type 5)

Symptoms:

  • Menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding).
  • Dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation).
  • Pelvic pain or pressure.
  • Dyspareunia (painful intercourse).
  • Urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, or retention).
  • Infertility or recurrent miscarriages.

Signs:

  • Enlarged, irregular, firm uterus on bimanual examination.
  • Mobility of the uterus may be reduced if fibroids are large.

Complications:

  • Severe anemia due to chronic menorrhagia.
  • Infertility and subfertility.
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Red degeneration (painful necrosis, often during pregnancy).
  • Torsion of pedunculated fibroids.
  • Malignant transformation (rare; <1% cases to leiomyosarcoma).

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: Primary imaging modality; identifies size, number, and location.
  • Hysteroscopy: For evaluation of submucosal fibroids.
  • MRI: Detailed imaging in complex or unclear cases.
  • Sonohysterography: Detects submucosal fibroids and cavity distortion.

Treatment Options:

  • Medical:
    • Hormonal therapy (GnRH agonists, progestins).
    • Non-hormonal options (NSAIDs, tranexamic acid).
  • Surgical:
    • Myomectomy: For preserving fertility.
    • Hysterectomy: Definitive treatment for symptomatic fibroids in women who have completed childbearing.
    • Uterine artery embolization (UAE): Minimally invasive, for reducing fibroid size and symptoms.
  • Other Interventions:
    • MRI-guided focused ultrasound (non-invasive ablation).
    • Laparoscopic or hysteroscopic resection.

Prognosis: Recurrence possible after myomectomy, especially in younger women.

 

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) (Option A): Uterine artery embolization is an effective treatment option for postpartum hemorrhage. By blocking the uterine blood supply, it can control bleeding and reduce the need for invasive surgical procedures, such as hysterectomy.

Placenta accreta (Option B): In cases of placenta accreta, where the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall, UAE can be performed pre-operatively to reduce uterine blood flow, thereby minimizing the risk of severe bleeding during placenta removal.

Menorrhagia in multiparous women (Option D): For multiparous women with menorrhagia due to fibroids, UAE can be considered. By decreasing blood flow to the fibroids, it alleviates symptoms like heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Which organization is responsible for gathering and regularly publishing extensive surveys on morbidity, family planning, and vital events?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) National sample survey

Explanation:

  • The National Sample Survey Office(NSSO) headed by a Director General conducts large scale sample surveys in diverse fields throughout India.

 

National Sample Survey Office(NSSO):

  • Primarily data are collected through nation-wide household surveys.
  • NSSO also collects data on rural and urban prices and plays a significant role in the improvement of crop statistics.
  • It also maintains a frame of urban area units for use in sample surveys in urban areas.
  • Four divisions of NSSO:
    • Survey Design and Research Division (SDRD)
    • Field Operations Division (FOD)
    • Data Processing Division (DPD)
    • Survey Coordination Division (SCD)

questions.text: The full form of the Urban HEART programme is:

choices.text: Urban health equity assessment and response tool
Urban health evaluation assessment and response tool
Urban health equity assessment and response technique
Urban health evaluation assessment and response technique

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Urban health equity assessment and response tool

Explanation:

  • Urban HEART is a tool developed by WHO that is designed to address health inequities in urban areas.
  • It helps policymakers identify disparities, assess their causes, and implement strategies to improve health outcomes for disadvantaged populations.
  • Health of individuals varies due to variation in genetic and constitutional variations. Older people tend to be sicker than younger people, because of the natural ageing process. These turn difference in health into an inequity in health.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 45-year-old woman who is a mother of three, experiencing discomfort and a mass in her lower abdomen? During examination, her uterus appears uniformly enlarged and the adnexa is unaffected. An MRI reveals the presence of a cyst within the uterine muscle.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adenomyosis

Explanation:

  • Adenomyosis is characterized by the invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium (muscle layer of the uterus).
  • This condition leads to a uniformly enlarged and tender uterus and can present with symptoms such as pelvic discomfort, heavy menstrual bleeding, and dysmenorrhea.
  • The presence of a myometrial cyst seen on MRI is a hallmark finding in adenomyosis, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Adenomyosis

Definition

Presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, leading to uterine enlargement.

Epidemiology

Common in parous women over 40 years of age.

Clinical Features
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).
  • Chronic pelvic pain.
  • Globally enlarged and globular uterus (if diffuse).

Investigations

Primary Investigation: TVS with Color Doppler.

Key Signs on USG:

  • Shutter/Venetian Blind sign (echogenic striations).
  • Central vascularity on Doppler.

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Asymmetrical uterine wall thickness (posterior > anterior).
  • Heterogeneous myometrial echotexture.
  • Hypoechoic myometrial cysts (honeycomb appearance).
  • Striated projections from endometrium to myometrium.
  • Poorly defined endometrial echo.
  • J-Zone thickening ≥12 mm.

Secondary Investigation: MRI (if USG is inconclusive).

 

  • Thickened junctional zone (>12 mm).
  • High-intensity myometrial foci on T2-weighted images.

Histopathology

Myometrial infiltration by endometrial glands and stroma.

 

Medical Management
  • Combined OCPs and progestin-only regimens (for dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia).
  • NSAIDs (for pain and menorrhagia).
  • LNG-IUS (for menorrhagia).
  • GnRH agonists (for subfertility or pre-surgical symptom relief).
  • Danazol (for menorrhagia and pain).

Surgical Management

Conservative:

  • Adenomyomectomy (risk of recurrence).
  • Uterine mass reduction (laparotomy/laparoscopy).
  • Uterine artery embolization (UAE).

Definitive: Total hysterectomy.

 

 

Endometriosis (Option A) refers to the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, often leading to symptoms like pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and infertility. While it can coexist with adenomyosis, the myometrial cyst described in this scenario is more characteristic of adenomyosis.

Leiomyoma (Option C), or fibroids, are benign tumors of the uterine smooth muscle. They typically present as localized masses within the uterus, leading to an irregularly enlarged uterus rather than a uniformly enlarged one. The presence of a myometrial cyst is not commonly associated with fibroids.

Endometrial hyperplasia (Option D) involves excessive thickening of the endometrial lining due to hormonal imbalance, often leading to abnormal uterine bleeding. It does not cause a uniformly enlarged uterus or myometrial cysts, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this scenario.

questions.text: Which among the following regions is free from rabies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C) Lakshadweep

Explanation:

  • Rabies is usually not found in areas bound on all sides with water. In India, rabies is not found in islands such as Andaman and Nicobar Islands and Lakshadweep.

 

Epidemiological Determinants of Rabies:

Agent factor
  • Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate
  • Lyssavirus type 1
    • Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family).
  • Two Types of Viruses:
    • Street virus:
      • Cause natural infection (Rabies)
      • Variable incubation period (7 days-months)
    • Fixed virus:
      • Fixed incubation period (5-7 days)
      • For vaccine production.
      • It does not demonstrate Negri bodies.

Host factors
  • Occupation
    • Dog handlers
    • Forest workers
    • Veterinarians.

Transmission
  • Incubation period: 2-8 weeks
  • Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey or Wild animal (all need vaccination)
  • Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission.
  • Rodent bites don't require vaccination.
  • Human bite is a very dangerous bite (no documented cases yet)
  • In India:
    • Urban Rabies is very common.
    • Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands) (Option C)

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1L1 presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum in labor, and loss of fetal movements. She occasionally smokes but does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, her pulse rate is 80 bpm, BP is 150/90 mmHg, and her abdomen is tense on palpation. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abruptio placenta

Explanation:

  • Abruptio placenta, or placental abruption, is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery.
  • Abruptio placenta is a form of antepartum haemorrhage, where the bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

Pathogenesis:

  • Bleeding occurs due to rupture of blood vessels in the decidua basalis.
  • There is an accumulation of blood in the decidua.
  • This causes the separation of the placenta, leading to
    • Further bleeding.
    • Thrombin generation from haemorrhage triggers the action of matrix metalloproteinases, inflammatory cytokines, and coagulation cascade (high risk of DIC).
    • Fetal distress.

Clinical features:

  • Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding
  • Abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Back pain
  • Fetal distress
  • Hypovolemic shock
  • Frequent contractions

Types of abruptio placenta:

Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed

  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

Page Classification of abruptio placentae:

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

 

Comparison of findings in placenta previa and abruptio placentae:

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

 

Placenta previa (Option B) occurs when the placenta covers the cervix partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the third trimester and no abdominal pain or tense uterus, making it unlikely in this scenario.

Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) (Option C) is an excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid. It may cause abdominal discomfort or uterine distension but does not present with vaginal bleeding, loss of fetal movements, or a tense abdomen.

Preterm labor (Option D) involves uterine contractions before 37 weeks of gestation. While it may cause abdominal pain, it is not associated with vaginal bleeding, tense abdomen, or loss of fetal movements in the absence of other complications.

questions.text: How should a patient be managed if a 30-year-old woman, using an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) for contraception, presents to the emergency department after experiencing two episodes of painless vaginal bleeding following 8 weeks of missed periods? She also complains of dizziness, and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, with a pulse rate of 138 beats per minute. A urine pregnancy test is positive.

choices.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate
Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy, which is a medical emergency. Key features in this case include:

  • Missed periods and positive pregnancy test indicating pregnancy.
  • Painless vaginal bleeding and dizziness, raising suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.
  • Hemodynamic instability (BP 80/50 mmHg, pulse 138 bpm), suggesting significant blood loss, possibly due to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Management

Stabilize the patient:

  • Immediate resuscitation with intravenous (IV) fluids to address hypovolemia and maintain blood pressure.
  • Stabilization is critical to ensure the patient is safe for the next steps.

Suction evacuation:

  • This minimally invasive procedure removes the ectopic tissue and is the preferred treatment for hemodynamically stable patients.
  • Further imaging or diagnostic laparoscopy may be used to confirm ectopic pregnancy location before intervention if the diagnosis is unclear.

 

IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate (Option A):

  • Methotrexate is suitable only for hemodynamically stable patients with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and no signs of imminent rupture.
  • This patient is unstable, requiring immediate surgical intervention, making methotrexate inappropriate.

Immediate laparotomy (Option B):

  • Laparotomy is indicated for life-threatening cases of ectopic pregnancy rupture with massive intra-abdominal bleeding or when other interventions fail.
  • In this case, suction evacuation after stabilization is sufficient if the diagnosis is confirmed and bleeding is manageable.

Dilatation and curettage (D&C) (Option D):

  • D&C is used to manage intrauterine pregnancies or miscarriages but is not suitable for treating ectopic pregnancies, as the pregnancy is outside the uterus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has never given birth and is undergoing hormone replacement therapy (HRT) presents with abdominal pain. On examination, a non-painful palpable mass is detected in the right adnexa. Following further investigation, she undergoes laparotomy, and her ovaries are observed as described. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ovarian carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Ovarian carcinoma is a common cause of adnexal masses in postmenopausal women.
  • The patient’s history of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and a non-tender right adnexal mass raise suspicion, as HRT may stimulate tumor growth and increase the risk of ovarian carcinoma in postmenopausal women.


“Nodular carcinoma of ovary” (Option A) is not a recognized medical term or specific diagnosis. It might be used to describe a solid tumor, but it is not a common or accurate term to describe ovarian malignancy. Ovarian carcinoma is the preferred and more precise diagnosis for malignant ovarian tumors in this context.

A chocolate cyst (endometrioma) (Option B) is an ovarian cyst filled with old blood, typically associated with endometriosis. This condition is more common in premenopausal women. In postmenopausal women, especially those on HRT, ovarian carcinoma is more likely, as hormonal therapy can influence the growth of ovarian tumors.

Ovarian fibroids (Option C) are not a recognized medical entity. Fibroids, or leiomyomas, are smooth muscle tumors that occur in the uterus, not the ovaries. A mass in the adnexa that is associated with a postmenopausal woman, especially with HRT use, is more consistent with ovarian carcinoma.

questions.text: What could be the possible cause for the increased bleeding in a G2P1L1 woman who had a previous cesarean section due to fetal distress and now has an uneventful vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) but an incomplete removal of the placenta, with the cord snapping on traction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Placenta percreta

Explanation:

  • Placenta percreta is a severe form of placenta accreta in which the placenta penetrates through the entire thickness of the uterine wall and may extend beyond the uterus.
  • This condition can cause difficulty in removing the placenta, leading to retained placental tissue and excessive bleeding.
  • In this case, the incomplete removal of the placenta and the snapping of the umbilical cord on traction without placental expulsion are indicative of placenta percreta. The placenta is abnormally attached, making its removal challenging and contributing to the profuse bleeding observed.

Placental Invasion Anomalies: Placenta Accreta, Increta, and Percreta

Feature

Placenta Accreta

Placenta Increta

Placenta Percreta

Definition

Superficial attachment to myometrium.

Invades into the myometrium.

Invades through the uterine wall to adjacent organs.

Depth of Invasion

Limited to myometrium surface.

Partial invasion of myometrium.

Complete invasion through uterine wall.

Risk Factors

Previous cesarean delivery, placenta previa, uterine surgery.

Same as accreta.

Same as accreta, higher risk with multiple cesareans.

Clinical Features

Postpartum hemorrhage.

Severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Massive hemorrhage, adjacent organ involvement.

Diagnosis

Ultrasound, MRI if needed.

Ultrasound, MRI for depth assessment.

Ultrasound, MRI showing invasion into adjacent organs.

Management

Planned cesarean, hysterectomy if needed.

Cesarean, likely hysterectomy.

Cesarean hysterectomy to prevent complications.

Complications

Hemorrhage.

Severe hemorrhage.

Massive hemorrhage, organ injury.

Prognosis

Good with early diagnosis.

Requires surgical expertise.

High morbidity and mortality risk.

 

Abruptio placenta (Option A) refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, typically associated with abdominal pain and fetal distress. However, in this case, there is no mention of placental separation before delivery, making abruptio placenta unlikely as the cause of the bleeding.

Placenta previa (Option B) occurs when the placenta is located near or over the cervix, often resulting in painless bleeding during pregnancy. While it can lead to bleeding during delivery, it does not typically cause incomplete removal of the placenta or the snapping of the umbilical cord during traction.

Uterine rupture (Option C) is a rare but serious complication, particularly in women with a previous cesarean section. While uterine rupture can lead to severe bleeding and fetal distress, the scenario described here suggests a different cause, particularly related to placental issues, with the patient having had an uneventful VBAC.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female complains of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A Giemsa stained smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Curdy white discharge

Explanation:

  • Curdy white discharge is a hallmark of vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection), which is caused by an overgrowth of Candida species. The discharge appears thick and white, often resembling cottage cheese.
  • However, the condition described in this case is Trichomoniasis, which is caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. Trichomoniasis typically results in a frothy, yellow-green discharge that may be foul-smelling, not a curdy white discharge.

Trichomonas Vaginitis

  • Trichomonas vaginitis, caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age, typically transmitted sexually.

Symptoms:

  • Yellowish-Green, Frothy Discharge: Foul-smelling.
  • Vulvar Irritation & Itching: Around the vaginal opening. (Option D ruled out)
