  • Painful Urination (Dysuria): Burning sensation during micturition (Option C ruled out)
  • Dyspareunia: Pain during intercourse.
  • "Strawberry Cervix": Punctate hemorrhages on the cervix. (Option A ruled out)
  • Recurrent Infections.

Organism:

  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan.
  • It thrives in the vaginal and cervical mucosa, causing inflammation.
  • Infective & Diagnostic Stage: Trophozoite

Diagnosis:

Clinical Examination:

  • Profuse, frothy yellow-green discharge.
  • Strawberry cervix.

 

  • Microscopy (Wet Mount): Motile Trichomonas vaginalis seen under the microscope.
  • Vaginal pH: Elevated (>4.5).
  • Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT): Gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Culture: Less common, but highly accurate.
  • Rapid Antigen Test: Point-of-care, less sensitive than NAAT.

Treatment:

  • Metronidazole or Tinidazole: Single or multi-dose regimen.
  • Treat both sexual partners to prevent reinfection.

Feature

Bacterial Vaginosis

Candidiasis

Trichomoniasis

Causative agent

Overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and others

Candida albicans or other Candida species

Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan)

Discharge appearance

Thin, gray-white, homogeneous

Thick, white, "cottage cheese-like"

Yellow-green, frothy

Odor

Fishy (especially post-coital or with KOH)

None or mild

Foul-smelling

Vaginal pH

> 4.5

≤ 4.5

> 4.5

Whiff Test

Positive (fishy odor with KOH)

Negative

May be positive

Microscopy

Clue cells, few lactobacilli

Hyphae or pseudohyphae, spores

Motile trichomonads, many WBCs

Associated symptoms

Often asymptomatic, may have itching or irritation

Intense itching, burning, dyspareunia

Itching, burning, erythema

Treatment

Metronidazole or clindamycin

Fluconazole or topical antifungals

Metronidazole or tinidazole

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, married for the past 5 years, presents with complaints of inability to conceive despite regular intercourse. Physical examination is unremarkable. Semen analysis of the husband revealed no abnormalities. Hysterosalpingography reveals the following picture. The anomaly shown in the image below falls under which category of the American Fertility Society classification of Müllerian duct anomalies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Class II

Explanation:

  • As described in the image given above, the Hysterosalpingography (HSG) demonstrates a characteristic appearance of a unicornuate uterus, where one Müllerian duct has failed to develop completely.
  • This anomaly is classified as Class II under the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) classification of Müllerian anomalies.
     

Müllerian Duct Anomaly

Description

Clinical Features

Diagnosis

Management

Class I

 

Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome

 

(Option D)
  • Complete or partial absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina.
  • Ovaries are normal.
  • Primary amenorrhea.
  • Absence of menstruation.
  • Normal secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Pelvic ultrasound.
  • MRI.
  • Karyotyping.
  • Vaginal reconstruction.
  • Assisted reproduction for fertility (gestational surrogacy or oocyte donation).

Class II

Unicornuate Uterus
  • Uterus is smaller and only one side develops.
  • Can have a rudimentary horn.
  • Dysmenorrhea.
  • Infertility.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Ectopic pregnancy.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG).
  • MRI.
  • Surgical removal of rudimentary horn.
  • Fertility management.
  • Cesarean delivery in case of pregnancy.

Class III

Bicornuate Uterus

 

(Option B)
  • Uterus has two horns.
  • Often with a deep indentation in the upper part.
  • Single cervix.
  • Menstrual irregularities.
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Preterm labor.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical correction (metroplasty) in some cases.
  • Supportive care for pregnancy management.

Class IV

Septate Uterus

 

(Option A)
  • Normally shaped uterus but with a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the cavity.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Infertility.
  • Preterm labor.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Sonohysterogram.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical resection of the septum (hysteroscopic septoplasty).
  • Fertility treatments if needed.

Class V

Arcuate Uterus
  • Mild indentation of the uterine fundus with a normal external uterine contour.
  • Often asymptomatic.
  • May have recurrent miscarriage.
  • Preterm birth.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Typically no treatment required.
  • Management of complications like miscarriage may be necessary.

Class VI

Didelphys Uterus

 
  • Complete non-fusion of the Müllerian ducts.
  • Two separate uterine cavities and cervices.
  • Vaginal septum.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Preterm labor.
  • Infertility.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical correction if needed.
  • Assisted reproductive techniques (ART) for infertility.

questions.text: The following chart shows the hormonal variations in the menstrual cycle. Identify the true statement:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) White Line represents FSH hormone

Explanation:

  • The White Line in the chart represents FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone).
  • FSH is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and It stimulates the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles in the first half of the menstrual cycle. FSH levels typically rise during the follicular phase and then decline as ovulation approaches.

Hormones Involved in the Menstrual Cycle

Hormone

Origin

Triggering Factors

Peak Timing

Role

Luteinizing Hormone (LH)

(Option C)

Anterior pituitary

Surge in GnRH from hypothalamus, feedback from estrogen/progesterone

Just before ovulation

Triggers ovulation, supports corpus luteum formation, stimulates progesterone secretion.

Estrogen (Estradiol)

(Option A)

Granulosa cells of ovarian follicles

Stimulated by FSH and LH, increases with follicular growth

Just before ovulation (mid-cycle)

Stimulates follicle growth, thickens endometrial lining, regulates FSH and LH through feedback mechanisms.

Progesterone

(Option D)

Corpus luteum (post-ovulation)

LH surge, transformation of follicle to corpus luteum

Post-ovulation, during luteal phase

Maintains uterine lining for implantation, inhibits ovulation, supports pregnancy if fertilization occurs.

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Anterior pituitary

GnRH from hypothalamus, modulated by estrogen feedback

Just before ovulation, during follicular phase

Stimulates follicle growth and estrogen production to support follicular development and progression of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Lepromatous leprosy

Explanation:

  • The given image is Lepromatous Leprosy. It is one of the types of Leprosy and is characterized by widespread, poorly defined, shiny-surfaced, hypopigmented, and erythematous macules with normal sensation.
  • Typical leonine features include a thickened forehead, lost brow hairs, and eyelashes (madarosis), a distorted nose, and thickened earlobes.

Transmission of Mycobacterium leprae

  • Source of Infection:
    • Leprosy is solely a human disease.
    • Infected individuals are the only source.
  • Transmission Route:
    • The precise route is unclear.
    • Significant shedding of bacilli through nasal secretions.
    • Possible transmission through the respiratory tract or skin.

Classification of Leprosy

Madrid Classification:

Type

Characteristics

Lepromatous Leprosy

Low host resistance, abundant bacilli in lesions, widespread lesions, higher transmission likelihood (Option D).

Tuberculoid Leprosy

High resistance, limited well-defined skin lesions, minimal bacilli in the lesions (Option A ruled out).

Dimorphous (Borderline)

Characteristics of both lepromatous and tuberculoid forms, potential to shift between the two (Option C ruled out).

Indeterminate Leprosy

Early, unstable stage, may resolve spontaneously or progress to other forms.

 

Leishmaniasis (Option B): The clinical features seen in the image given is not indicative of leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Riya was found to have a height of more than the 95th percentile for her age and an arm-span to height ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers. An image of her showing characteristic signs is provided below. What is the most common ocular complication expected in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Subluxation of lens

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of tall stature flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers in suggestive of Marfan's syndrome.

Marfan syndrome is commonly associated with mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes the connective protein fibrillin.

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • Multisystem disorder with involvement of the connective tissues.

Clinical features:

Skeletal abnormalities:
  • Tall stature
  • Arachnodactyly
  • Chest wall abnormalities like pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum
  • Thumb sign( On folding thumb, it will protrude beyond the ulnar border of palm) or wrist sign is positive
  • Increased joint laxity

CVS abnormalities:
  • Aortic root dilation
  • Mitral insufficiencies
  • Arrhythmias

Eye abnormalities:
  • Ectopia lentis or subluxation of the lens of the eye (Option D)
  • Blindness

Pulmonary involvement:

  • Increased risk of pneumothorax

Diagnosis:

  • Marfan syndrome is clinically diagnosed using Ghent criteria

questions.text: What is considered the most reliable tonometer in the medical field?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Goldmann applanation tonometer

 

Explanation:

Types of Tonometry:

1. Indentation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP by how much a plunger indents the eye; softer eyes indent more than harder eyes.
  • Schiotz Tonometer (Option A):
    • Most widely used tonometer in the world.
    • Advantages: Inexpensive, simple, and reliable.
    • Disadvantages: Gives false readings in eyes with abnormal scleral rigidity (e.g., high myopes, post-surgery).

2. Applanation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP based on the force needed to flatten the cornea's surface (Imbert-Fick Law: P = W/A).
  • Goldmann Tonometer (Option B):
    • Most popular and accurate; uses a double prism on a slit lamp.
    • Technique:
      • Cornea is anesthetized and stained with fluorescein.
      • Cornea and biprisms are illuminated with cobalt blue light.
      • The prism touches the cornea, and the inner edges of two semicircles are adjusted to just touch.
      • IOP is read by multiplying the dial reading by ten.

Variable force tonometers:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometer → Gold standard
  • Perkins tonometer (hand held version of goldmann)
  • Draeger tonometer (measures wide range of IOP)
  • Draeger tonometer is similar to Perkins
    • It has a different set of prisms
    • It operates with a motor
  • Pulsair (non-contact tonometer)
  • Airpuff (non-contact tonometer)
  • Grolman (non-contact tonometer)
  • Tonopen (based on both indentation and applanation)
  • MacKay Marg (based on both indentation and applanation)
  • Rebound tonometer
  • Transpalpebral Tonometer

Fixed force tonometer:

  1. Maklakov tonometer
  2. Barraquer tonometer

Tonopen (Option C) is a handheld electronic tonometer that measures IOP by using both applanation and indentation method..

Pascal dynamic contour (Option D) tonometer is a newer technology that measures IOP by analyzing the contour of the cornea during gentle deformation.

questions.text: What is the main underlying factor responsible for regular astigmatism when studying the optics of a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Abnormal curvature of the cornea

Explanation:

  • The primary cause of regular astigmatism is an abnormal curvature of the cornea, which results in different refractive powers along different meridians of the eye. This irregularity in corneal shape prevents light rays from focusing on a single point on the retina, causing blurred or distorted vision.
  • Astigmatism: A refractive error where different meridia of the eye have different refractive errors. Divided into 2 types: Regular and irregular
  • I. Regular Astigmatism: When refraction error changes uniformly from one meridian to the other. ( 2 principle meridians present)

Type

Description

With-the-Rule (WTR)

The vertical meridian has greater curvature than the horizontal meridian.

Against-the-Rule (ATR)

The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

Oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are at oblique angles (e.g., 45° and 135°), still perpendicular to each other.

Bi-oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are not perpendicular to each other (e.g., 30° and 100°).

Regular Astigmatism Based on Focal Lines:

Type

Description

Simple Astigmatism

One meridian focuses on the retina; the other focuses in front (simple myopic) or behind (simple hypermetropic).

Compound Astigmatism

Both meridians focus light either in front (compound myopic) or behind (compound hypermetropic) the retina.

Mixed Astigmatism

One meridian focuses in front of the retina (myopic), and the other behind (hypermetropic).

II. Irregular Astigmatism Involves multiple, changing meridians of refractive power, making it geometrically complex.Usually due to Corneal scars.

Excessive eye rubbing (Option B) can irritate the eyes and potentially lead to infections like keratoconjunctivitis.

Prolonged exposure to bright light (Option C) can cause eye strain and discomfort.

Vitamin A deficiency (Option D) can lead to xerophthalmia characterized by night blindness and dryness of the eyes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the instrument shown in the image given below is false?


{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Used to measure the curvature of the cornea

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Measures intraocular pressure.

Explanation:

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Keratometer used to assess the corneal curvature responsible for causing astigmatism. It is based on the size of the image formed by the anterior surface of the cornea i.e., purkinje image I.
  • Intraocular pressure is measured by using a tonometer.

Keratometry

  • An objective method for measuring the curvature of the central cornea (Option A ruled out) to estimate corneal astigmatism (Option B ruled out).
  • Principle of Keratometer: Measures corneal curvature by analyzing the size of the image formed by the anterior corneal surface (Option C ruled out), utilizing visible doubling.
  • Normal Keratometric Values:
    • Average: 45 D
    • Keratoconus >45 D
  • Types of Keratometers:
    • Javal-Schiotz Model
    • Bausch & Lomb Model

Auto refractive Keratometer

questions.text: What is the preferred initial treatment for a 4-year-old boy who initially had facial swelling but now has experienced total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet, and has a urinalysis showing 4+ protein and a urine protein: creatinine ratio of 3?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Prednisolone

Explanation:

  • The boy is likely suffering from nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease, with prednisolone being the initial treatment of choice.
  • Prednisolone, a synthetic glucocorticoid with intermediate potency, is effective in managing minimal change disease.

Duration of Action

Glucocorticoid

Potency

Effects/Uses

Short (8-12 hrs)

Hydrocortisone

Low

 

Physiological replacement therapy, adrenal insufficiency, anti-inflammatory

Incorrect Options:

Cyclophosphamide (Option B) is used in cases of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome or in certain secondary forms of nephrotic syndrome, but it's not the first choice in typical steroid-sensitive cases.

Levamisole (Option C) can be used as an adjunctive therapy for steroid-sensitive nephrotic syndrome if relapses occur, but is not usually the initial treatment.

Cyclosporine (Option D) is used in cases of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome or for severe disease, but it is not typically the first choice in steroid-sensitive cases.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a disease that is typically not found in a country but is brought in from abroad, as seen in the case of a 25-year-old male who was diagnosed with the condition upon arrival at an Indian airport, leading to quarantine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) Exotic

Explanation:

  • Exotic: Disease not native or commonly found in a region, brought from abroad.
  • Scenario: Disease brought to India by 25-year-old male.
  • Classification: Disease is considered exotic due to its foreign origin.

 

Term

Definition

Examples

Epidemic (Option B ruled out)
  • Occurrence of disease clearly in excess of normal expectancy (Mean + 2SD or >80% expected frequency).
  • Occurrence of even a single case of a previously eliminated disease.
  • Occurrence of a single case of an exotic disease. (Option D)

Seasonal influenza outbreaks during winter months.

Endemic (Option A ruled out)

 
  • Constant presence of a disease within a specific population.
  • Epidemiologically linked cases in terms of time, place, or person.

Malaria in Africa, TB in India

Pandemic
  • Global spread of a disease.
  • Defined as an epidemic in a large population.
  • Requires crossing 2 continents and 2 WHO-specific regions.

HIV/AIDS, COVID-19.

Sporadic
  • They occur randomly and unpredictably, without any discernible pattern in time, location, or individual.
  • There's no epidemiological link between the cases.

Tetanus

 

Zoonotic (Option C): Disease transmitted under natural conditions from animal to humans. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Installation and usage of sanitary latrines by general public constitutes which level of prevention:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Health promotion

Explanation:

  • Health promotion encourages healthy behaviors and environments. Installing sanitary latrines promotes hygiene and prevents diseases.

Primary prevention includes:

  • Health promotion: (Option A)
    • Health education camps on exercise and lifestyle diseases.
    • Mental health promotion and counselling in schools and colleges.
    • Implementing strict laws against drinking and driving to prevent road traffic accidents due to impaired driving
  • Specific protection: (Option B ruled out)
    • Administration of MR vaccination to children prevents measles and rubella infection via active immunisation, as the risk of infection is high during childhood
    • Iodisation of salt helps prevent endemic goitre, especially in the Himalayan region, as they lack iodine in their diet

 

 

Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial

To prevent the establishment of risk factors

  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations
  • Health education
  • Family planning
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examinatio

Secondary

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications (Option C ruled out)
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.

Tertiary

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death (Option D ruled out)
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery

questions.text: A study conducted on 46 mothers who delivered deformed babies showed that 41 were found to have thalidomide during their early pregnancy; what kind of study is being done here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C) Case-control study

Explanation:

  • In a case-control study, researchers compare individuals with the outcome of interest (cases) to those without the outcome (controls) to assess the association between exposure and outcome.\

 

Observational studies

Analytical studies
  • Case-control/case reference. (Option C)
  • Ecological/correlational.
  • Cross-sectional/prevalence.
  • Cohort/follow-up. (Options A & B ruled out)

Descriptive studies (Option D ruled out)

Experimental/observational studies

Community trials/community intervention trials.

Field trials.

Non-randomised trials
  • Uncontrolled trials.
  • Natural experiments.
  • Before and after comparison studies.

Randomised controlled trials
  • Trial of aetiological agents.
  • Risk factor trials.
  • Clinical trials.
  • Preventive trials.
  • Cessation experiments.
  • Evaluation of health services.

questions.text: Please recognize the logo displayed in the provided image
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Suraksha Clinic

Explanation:

  • The given logo is the logo of Suraksha Clinic which is under the National AIDS Control Programme.
  • Suraksha Clinic (previously Designated STI/RTI Clinics) is an STI/RTI clinic chain. The National AIDS Control Organisation founded these clinics to provide improved healthcare and to combat HIV/AIDS in India.
